events.id: Lost Wax in Three Sessions - Hard Wax-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Lost Wax in Three Sessions - Hard Wax
events.venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
events.description:
Over three sessions create stunning jewellery using the age-old lost wax technique. This is an excellent opportunity to treat yourself to some creative fun!

This is an excellent opportunity for a best friends' Sunday morning or a self-care session for yourself!

In weeks one and two you'll learn how to work with jeweller's hard wax to create beautiful textures in metal that can be used to create amazing rings or objects. Your waxes will be sent away for casting in the metal of your choice.

Then there’s a week break before the third session, to allow time for everyone's waxes to be cast. The third session covers how to trim, clean and finish your casts, turning them into original jewellery ready to wear!

More advanced students can use these sessions to complete projects in a class setting.

Included in the class fee are all your different types of waxes, sandpaper and courier costs.

Not included are the casting and metal costs which vary from student to student depending on what sized ring they want to make and the type of metal you choose. Small castings can cost around $6.65 - $12 and might cost between $7 to $30 in metals depending on if you use red bronze, white bronze or silver.

This class is great for teens and kids over 12 or so. Anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

events.id: Sea Glass Rings - One Day Jewellery Making Workshop-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Sea Glass Rings - One Day Jewellery Making Workshop
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
Design and create a unique ring with foraged sea glass ‘gems’ while learning and developing core jewellery fabrication techniques. An opportunity to engage in creative recycling by turning seaside flotsam into precious wearable treasures. Experiment with ring textures and forms in silver, brass and/or copper, then set your unique glass ‘gemstone’. Finish up with your choice of polish, including high lustre gloss, steel brushed satin, or darkened antique finishes.

If you can, please beachcomb and bring along some sea glass options - ideally around 1cm wide, and with a flat back.


Techniques:

- Create a ring with one bezel set foraged sea glass ‘gem’
- Use jeweller’s callipers to measure and prepare metal
- Use jeweller’s saws or snips to cut and shape metal
- Use files and sanding to refine and smooth metal edges and surfaces
- Use jeweller’s flame torches to solder join metal pieces
- Use Dremel & bench polishers to refine & finish metal casts into wearable jewellery

Project : 1 Ring with sea glass (silver, brass and copper options)
Materials: Sea Glass, Copper, Brass, Sterling Silver

One hour lunch - bring a packed lunch to have in our historic home or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

Daylong workshop options on either Sunday 20 July or Sunday 24 August.

events.id: Mrs Floss' Winter Sip & Scribble Cafe-Greytown Distilling Co - Judgement Room, Level 2, 110 Main Street, Greytown, Greytown-Event Finder
events.name: Mrs Floss' Winter Sip & Scribble Cafe
events.venue: Greytown Distilling Co - Judgement Room, Level 2, 110 Main Street, Greytown, Greytown
events.description:
THIS EVENT HAS SOLD OUT. Are you after another great Village bookshop event? Check out "Cross Stitch Bookmarks with Mrs Blackwell"
When asked to imagine her perfect cafe, Mrs Floss dreamed of a magical place called The Sip & Scribble. A cafe where you can sit quietly with your journals and your thoughts, surrounded by your fellow travellers.

Where you can sketch, write with your favourite pen, put together pages of your junk journal, or write yourself dreamy lists of places to visit and books to read. It’s a cafe where no one will frown upon your sprawled collection of art supplies or suggest that you're taking up too much space.

Where they deliver sweet treats and bottomless coffee and tea.

Mrs Floss' vision came to life for a sell-out session in February, and we’re bringing it back for one perfect Sunday afternoon session this July!

Your ticket includes:
An ephemera pack containing high-quality papers, stickers, vintage postage stamps and a few other surprises for decorating your journal pages
A generous selection of sweet treats (vegan and gluten-free available)
A bottomless range of teas and filter coffee
Fine company and a morning relaxing with like-minded journal enthusiasts - you bring your own journals and your favourite supplies, all journals and types of journalling are welcome at this event.

We’ll have all the basics like pens, pencils, glue, tape, scissors and some stickers available for you to use.
Extra journalling supplies and stickers will be for sale on the day

Both Mrs Floss and Mrs Blackwell will be on hand if you’d like to ask us any questions, or for help and inspiration.

Suitable for seasoned journallers, as well as those just about getting started.
Accessibility: This event is being held at the Greytown Distilling Company Judgement Room, Level 2, 110 Main Street (upstairs from Blackwell & Sons). Access is by one flight of stairs.

events.id: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Visual Journalling - Drawing for Mindfulness
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
Learn how to use drawing and mark-making for visual journalling, to draw out your inner guidance and resources, and bring a creative form of wellness into your daily life.

Lara Phillips, a creative facilitator trained in Interactive Drawing Therapy, will guide you through simple practices that open our subconscious; a resource we can all tap into, to help ourselves.

Note, this is not therapy or counselling rather a self-care tool that you can integrate alongside other wellbeing practices, such as journalling, walking or meditation.

No drawing skills required, this is more mark making not art making.

Each week combines a mix of guided drawings (where you follow cues), practices with others in the group, and self-guided drawings, using knowledge and tools you can take away.

Week 1: Ground
Learn what sits at the heart of this practice, and how to access your subconscious to draw out what it is you need.

Week 2: Wonder
Explore techniques with others in the group, to learn the power of open cues and different ways to listen to your inner voice.

Week 3: Play
Experiment with different ways of playing with your drawings, to stimulate the subconscious to guide you.

Week 4: Self
Apply your knowledge from the workshop to develop self-guiding skills to continue drawings at home.

What is provided: All necessary materials are provided. This includes A3 paper and coloured crayons, as well as printed resources with guiding cues.

What to bring: (Optional) Any preferred journalling materials of choice, such as large journals, coloured markers or coloured pencils. Feel free to bring an A3 folder/case/wallet.

Homework will be offered to help integrate the practice with your personal life.


Sundays, 11 am - 1 pm, 20 July - 10 August.

events.id: Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins and Wade Reeve Live-13 Pirie Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins and Wade Reeve Live
events.venue: 13 Pirie Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Unforgettable Dinah Washington: Lisa Tomlins & Wade Reeve Live
A Tribute to the Queen of the Blues
Dinah Washington, the self-proclaimed “Queen of the Blues,” was a powerhouse of jazz, blues, and soul whose voice defined an era. Now, her timeless repertoire is being reimagined by Aotearoa’s own queen of soulful expression—the incomparable Lisa Tomlins.
Lisa’s vocal versatility is legendary. Whether interpreting Tower of Power, jazz standards, or contemporary pop, she brings depth, warmth, and unmistakable style. She’s graced stages with L.A.B., Fly My Pretties, Neil Finn, and countless others—earning her place as one of New Zealand’s most beloved vocalists.
Joining her is the ever-tasteful guitarist Wade Reeve, whose intuitive playing complements Lisa’s voice with elegance and restraint. If you caught their stunning set at CubaDupa, you already know the magic this duo creates.
Maybe you'll hear Dinah’s most iconic songs—What a Diff’rence a Day Made, Cold, Cold Heart, September in the Rain, and of course, Unforgettable. This afternoon promises to be just that.
🎟️ Capital Blues Members: $10
🎟️ General Admission: $20
🍷 Members also enjoy 10% off at the bar

events.id: Weaving Workshop with Robyn Parker-Hutt Art Society, 9-11 Myrtle St, Lower Hutt-Event Finder
events.name: Weaving Workshop with Robyn Parker
events.venue: Hutt Art Society, 9-11 Myrtle St, Lower Hutt
events.description:
Over six sessions you will learn the basics of handweaving.
The class will learn on shaft table looms that students will take home with them between classes. The looms are lent free of charge.
The names and function of each part of the loom will be described.
Students will learn how to choose the correct yarn for a particular project, wind a warp and put it on the loom (dress the loom). The warp is made up of individual threads wound around the loom itself.
Over the six lessons, students will first weave a project chosen by the tutor (a simple scarf) and then one or more projects of their own choice. Projects could include scarves, tea towels, small bags, table mats or runners etc. You will be guided in your choice of project, how to choose suitable yarns etc

events.id: Flautist Bridget Douglas with Elouan String Quartet-St Peters Village Hall, Cnr Beach Rd and Ames St, Paekākāriki-Event Finder
events.name: Flautist Bridget Douglas with Elouan String Quartet
events.venue: St Peters Village Hall, Cnr Beach Rd and Ames St, Paekākāriki
events.description:
Although some observers are predicting that classical music is losing popularity, the Mulled Wine Concerts organisation in Paekakariki is finding exactly the opposite. Its 2025 season has produced several sell-out events in Kapiti and the organiser, Mary Gow is in a upbeat mood about the next concert in the series. She notes "The Elouan Quartet who will be appearing at Paekakariki's iconic St Peter's Hall on Sunday July 20th features an outstanding chamber music quartet of principal players from the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra who will be accompanied by the very popular principal flautist, Bridget Douglas".



The Elouan Quartet with Bridget Douglas will present a captivating programme of music for flute and string quartet. Highlights include works by Mozart, Beethoven, Ginastera, Amy Beach, and Selina Fisher.These works are paired together in such a way as to compliment and contrast each other. Many of the works have a strong connection to the natural world, especially water, this most essential and beautiful compound that is our very lifeblood. The quartet comprises Jessica Oddie (violin), Anna Van der Zee (violin), Alexander McFarlane (viola} and Ken Ichinose (cello), names that will be familiar to followers of the NZSO. Bridget Douglas (flute) is also a well-known principal member of the orchestra



Almost every organisation involved in the arts in New Zealand is finding it tough going in 2025. Commercial sponsorship is very difficult to come by, and the grant-funding bodies are all facing cutbacks. But the demand is still there and Mulled Wine Concerts has found that their policy of presenting top-quality music in local venues and keeping ticket costs down as far as possible, is the right way to go. "We have had good audiences for our recent events" says Gow. "People who think twice about going into the capital and paying high prices for travel and tickets like the idea that they can have good music locally". With its popular combination of a string quartet and flute, presented by world-class musicians, Kapiti audiences will certainly appreciate the latest event in the series and it is likely to sell out quickly.



=======ENDS======



Mulled Wine Concerts present: The Elouan Quartet with Bridget Douglas

Sunday July 20, 2025 at 2:30PM at St Peter's Community Hall, Beach Road Paekakariki.



Tickets $35 (Student under 16, $15). Online Sales: marygow@gmail.com



Shop outlets: Magpie Paremata, 99 Mana Esplanade; Finn's Hotel, Paekakariki; Moby Dickens Bookshop, Paraparaumu Beach; Jenoa, 2 Mahara Place, Waikanae.



Info: www.mulledwineconcerts.com

events.id: Kōkā fundraiser - Forest Aid-29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Kōkā fundraiser - Forest Aid
events.venue: 29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Hello! I'm inviting you all to see a great NZ movie with me - Kōkā
I am fundraising to access lifesaving treatment in Spain, for a rare condition that NZ does not treat.
Please look at tinyurl.com/Forest-Aid for more detailed information about my condition and the fundraising effort.
Thanking you for the support.
I have made tiered ticket pricing for those who don't have the means to pay the full price.
There's homemade treats to be enjoyed too
https://tinyurl.com/KokaOAR
Podcast interview with Verity Mackintosh.
About the film:
Under the celestial guidance of Matariki, kuia Hamo (Hinetu Dell) and the troubled Jo (Darneen Christian) form an unlikely bond on a road trip. As they confront painful histories and navigate the weight of their pasts, their shared journey becomes one of healing, community, and reconciliation.
Set against the breathtaking landscapes of Aotearoa, Kōkā marks the debut feature from director Kath Akuhata-Brown (Ngāti Porou) and is the first film told entirely in the original Ngāti Porou dialect - brought to life through the guidance of language and tikanga experts Erana Reedy and Karepe McDonald.
Produced by Verity Mackintosh and Libby Hakaraia, Kōkā was made with a predominantly Māori cast and crew, and nurtured emerging talent through the Māoriland Film Festival’s rangatahi programme
At its heart, this is a story of reconnection — with whenua, with whakapapa, and with each other.

events.id: Songwriter Showcase #104-MOON, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Songwriter Showcase #104
events.venue: MOON, Wellington
events.description:
Songwriter Showcase presents showcase #104, Sun July 20th at Moon bar in Newtown.

Every month we showcase four local songwriters and celebrate the rich culture and depth of talent we have here in Aotearoa.

This month we present our big busy Midwinter Massive, four great acts.. The Overdogs, The Kingston High All Stars, Buffalo Buffalo Buffalo and Janet Muggeridge and Dave Murphy.


The Overdogs
Literate ballads and breezy Americana. Hoe-down stompers on request.
Wellington combo The Overdogs have been playing round the city since 2016. Fronted by poet and songwriter John Newton, with clarinet and fiddle twins Andy Horwood and Jude Douglas, Tony Paine on bass and Liam Prince on drums. Expect dynamic playing and an easy-going vibe, thoughtful tear-in-your-craft-beer ballads and up-tempo country wig-outs.


Kingston High All Stars
Poneke based band weaving the sounds of Sahara Blues, 60s psychedelia and Traditional middle eastern music to create a tapestry of sound to transport listeners to far flung places and times.


BuffaloBuffaloBuffalo
Morphed from a project set up 2 years ago, a herd of instrument addicts with an EP imminent. Buffalo-pop-rock, whimsical, catchy, playful. Songs of road trips, relationships and reality tv.


Janet Muggeridge and Dave Murphy.
When Taranaki’s premier folk mandolinist and habitual jammer teamed up with Wellington blues legend Dave Murphy a number of years ago, they created a unique sound.
At Moon they will present their original songs that have been arranged to showcase their musical strengths. Expect songs from Dave’s time touring on the road, a blues or two, songs about trains, places in Taranaki that are important to Janet.

events.id: Gong Bath at Newtown Community Centre-Colombo Street &, Rintoul Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Gong Bath at Newtown Community Centre
events.venue: Colombo Street &, Rintoul Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.description:
***$20***
Limited door sales for $25
*Please bring a yoga mat, pillow, eye mask and blanket for maximum comfort and warmth*
Discover the transformative effects of sound therapy with this 1-hour gong bath experience.
During this session, participants will be surrounded by the resonant vibrations of gongs, carefully designed to induce deep states of relaxation and calm. As you settle into the experience, allow the soothing tones to wash over you, releasing tension and promoting a sense of inner peace.
Scientific studies have highlighted the benefits of sound therapy, particularly gong baths, in reducing stress and promoting overall well-being. The rhythmic patterns and frequencies of the gongs can help entrain brainwaves, leading to a meditative state and improved mental clarity.
Beyond the immediate effects, many participants report experiencing lasting benefits such as improved sleep, reduced anxiety, and enhanced mood following a gong bath session. By immersing yourself in the healing vibrations of the gongs, you can tap into a deeper sense of relaxation and rejuvenation.
Whether you're looking to unwind after a long day or explore new avenues of self-care, this 1-hour gong bath offers a unique opportunity to reconnect with yourself and find balance amidst the hustle and bustle of daily life. There will be cups of tea available afterwards to help us integrate and ground
**THIS EVENT IS RESTRICTED TO 20 PEOPLE ONLY**
About Me
Erika is a musician and astrologer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She has 30+ years musical experience. Erika has an interest in the healing properties of sound for mental and physical wellbeing, which she currently explores through her gong bathing practice

events.id: Introduction to Restorative Practices-Tararua Tramping Club Clubrooms, 4 Moncrieff St, Mt Victoria, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Introduction to Restorative Practices
events.venue: Tararua Tramping Club Clubrooms, 4 Moncrieff St, Mt Victoria, Wellington
events.description:
Join your trainers Sarah and Haley for a full day in person workshop to learn how restorative practices can foster collaboration, strengthen relationships, and effectively address conflict and harm. This experiential training will equip you with practical tools to build a culture of trust, navigate difficult conversations, and promote accountability—without blame or escalation. You'll gain immediately applicable strategies to improve communication, resolve tensions, and create a more connected and resilient workplace.

Format: In Person, in Wellington, NZ

events.name: Writers on Mondays
events.venue: Te Marae, Te Papa Tongarewa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington
events.description:
The poems in Biggs Family Prize in Poetry winner Nafanua Purcell Kersel’s Black Sugarcane can sting and soothe, revealing a paradise despoiled by climate change and colonisation, and celebrating a people resilient in the face of it all. Mikaela Nyman is from the autonomous, demilitarised Åland Islands in Finland. Her first poetry collection in English, Anatomy of Sand, follows on from her climate fiction novel Sado. These two urgent contemporary voices join Tamara Tulitua in a conversation about rising seas, political and personal poetry, the local and global.

Writers on Mondays is presented with the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Circa Theatre and Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, and is supported by the Letteri Family.

events.id: Wellington Leadership Group: Leading from Within: Servant Leadership Through the Lens of PTSD Recovery-40 Mercer Street, City, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Wellington Leadership Group: Leading from Within: Servant Leadership Through the Lens of PTSD Recovery
events.venue: 40 Mercer Street, City, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Nick Tomlin’s talk, Leading from Within: Servant Leadership Through the Lens of PTSD Recovery, shares a powerful account of how living with PTSD has deepened his understanding and practice of Servant Leadership. By weaving personal experience with leadership insight, he illustrates how vulnerability, empathy, and resilience are not signs of weakness, but powerful tools for healing and leading authentically.
The session encourages leaders to embrace authenticity, support mental well-being, and foster cultures rooted in trust and service. Key points include:
Understanding Servant Leadership and how it differs from traditional authority-driven models
Harnessing vulnerability to build trust and psychological safety within teams
Sustaining resilience while navigating personal and professional adversity
Creating supportive cultures where mental health is valued and people can thrive as their full selves
It’s a compelling reminder that leadership is not about having all the answers—it’s about leading with heart, especially through the hard chapters.
About Nick Tomlin
Born in Kent, England in 1968, [Name] served 25 years across the British Army and Royal Air Force, rising from Combat Medical Technician to Special Forces Commander of the Light Surgical Group. His deployments took him from Northern Ireland to Afghanistan, and he also proudly represented his service in rugby, cricket, and Ironman events.
Following retirement, he became Medical Manager for the London 2012 Olympics before emigrating with his family to New Zealand. Today, he channels his energy into resilience coaching and mental health advocacy, drawing on personal experience after a post-service diagnosis of PTSD.
With gratitude for the support of his wife Fay, their two sons, and the SPARTA Project, he now speaks openly about invisible wounds, the power of vulnerability, and his mission to help others find hope and healing—proving that true strength lies not in silence, but in connection.
About Results Coaching
Founded in 2011, Results Coaching (formerly Setanta Consulting), is one of New Zealand’s fastest growing coaching practices. Our promise is to expand the horizons of our clients measured by observable growth through coaching and training events. As one participant put it, “This is the type of talk I’m looking for at my stage of my career, i.e. focuses on personal development rather than technical skills.”
Please Note: We may photograph or record the event for promotion purposes and may reproduce the image of any person who attends for any purpose without payment.

Authentic Indian cooking classes in Wellington with panaromic views over Wellington Harbour.

In each class, you will learn 4-5 recipes like: potato stuff roti, roasted eggplant curry, wholemeal, roti, naan; shahi paneer; dhal, samosa; palak paneer; gourmet chickpeas; vegetable korma; gulab jamun; kheer; mango lassi; masala chai, and many more...

3) Roasted eggplant curry, plain whole wheat chapatti or roti, jeera aaloo or potato curry, Tuar dahl (split yellow lentil) and Basmati rice with homemade pickle.

4) Palak paneer (creamy spinach curry with cubes of paneer), jeera rice (basmati rice with fragrant spices, panjabi chhole or spicy chickpeas curry and mango lassi. Also fresh paneer making.

events.id: Expressive Watercolour - 8 Week Course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Expressive Watercolour - 8 Week Course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
Watercolour is special because of the fluid properties that produce spontaneous and unique results. The inability to anticipate exactly what the paint will do makes watercolour an exciting medium to work with.

In this course we will learn to set the conditions for surprising and beautiful accidents to occur on the page. By incorporating these looser abstract elements into representational paintings we can convey heightened emotions in our work.

Throughout the term we will cover the following:

- The wet into wet technique to achieve one of a kind paint interactions.
- Learn about transparent colour mixing to create luminosity in your paintings.
- Use marbling to find organic shapes and patterns.
- Study the relationship between line and colour and the different ways they can be combined to find a personal style.
- Experiment with composition through collage.

Each class we will look at examples of historic and contemporary painting, and discuss how to selectively incorporate references into your work. Over the term you will build up a visual style and body of work.

Whether you’re new to watercolour or looking to expand your range, this course offers an opportunity to explore the expressive potential of watercolour.

Basic materials included.

Mornings:
Wednesdays, 10 am - 1 pm.
23 July - 10 September.

Evenings:
Mondays, 6-8 m
21 July - 8 September.

events.id: Dark Sky Business Capability Course – Wairarapa Edition-Masterton District Council, 64 Chapel St, Masterton-Event Finder
events.name: Dark Sky Business Capability Course – Wairarapa Edition
events.venue: Masterton District Council, 64 Chapel St, Masterton
events.description:
Some nights stay with you forever.
A breeze.
A hush.
A sky so full of stars it silences even the noisiest thoughts. Now imagine making it possible for someone else to feel like that.


Learn how to build a science-based, unforgettable stargazing experience for your business. Join the Dark Sky Business Capabilities course!


We are Hari and Sam, and we already run a very successful stargazing business, Star Safari. And if you think of running one too or just incorporating stargazing into your current business, come and learn from our experience. We want people to come to our region again and again to take in the night sky and learn how to look after it. There is space for everyone in this business, but it takes more than just pointing a laser at the stars to navigate the night sky. We know exactly what it takes. Astrotourism is a fantastic opportunity for everyone in Wairarapa, as we have this fantastic International Dark Sky Reserve at our doorstep.

In this course, you’ll learn how to:
- Integrate stargazing into your existing business
- Design unforgettable dark sky experiences
- Use storytelling and science to engage your visitors
- Navigate dark sky regulations, gear, and location logistics

This is a practical, hands-on workshop designed for tourism operators, educators, accommodation providers, and anyone interested in astro-tourism.

Who Should Attend?
- Tourism operators
- Experience-based businesses
- Eco-lodges / glamping / off-grid retreats
- Educators and guides
- Anyone

Why Join?
- Learn from trusted science communicators
- Gain real-world business insights
- Build a credible, high-quality stargazing offer
- Join a growing national network of dark sky professionals

Supported By:
- WellingtonNZ (Course Sponsor)
- Masterton District Council

events.id: Motov8ing Boys - WELLINGTON-MacLaurin Lecture Theatres Wellington, Wellington 6012-Event Brite
events.name: Motov8ing Boys - WELLINGTON
events.venue: MacLaurin Lecture Theatres Wellington, Wellington 6012
events.description:
Do you worry about your sons attitude & behaviour?
Does he need help building courage, confidence & resilience?
Does he struggle to care about or see his potential?
Or are you just tired of repeating yourself over and over again only to get the same result, or even worse…no response at all?

If you answered yes & can relate to some or maybe even all of these then the Motov8ing Boys event is for you and it's time you met John McMahon.

Motov8ing Boys' is an event for Boys aged 11-17 and their parents; the goal is to help them to understand the power of a positive attitude, how to develop competnece & confidence, how to change destructive behaviour, how to identify personal potential & understand the importance of self-respect & respecting others, especially their parents.

One of the biggest deficits seen in young people today is a lack of social & emotional intelligence. This can lead to a whole range of problems with their personal development at home, at school & with friends both on & off line.
It can put unnecessary strain on relationships with siblings & sometimes unsustainable pressure on parents. Leading to everything from arguements, fights, anxiety, stress & depression through to significant family breakdown.
If you can relate to some or maybe even all of these then a Savage Angel event is for you.
Who is John McMahon from Motov8 aka The Rev?
John or Rev as he’s more commonly known is a youth specialist with over 30 years experience working with young people in schools, sporting clubs & families across Australia, NZ & the UK. Through Motov8ing Boys events, seminars & talks delivered in schools, Rev has helped inspire & influence thousands of young people to make smarter more informed decisions.
Boys will be boys" is often used to explain away & excuse why boys say & do silly things. As a coach/mentor and parent himself Rev would rather see this statement reflect a very different sentiment. Rev's aim is to inspire boys to choose to become history making, high achieving & uniquely productive young men. Men of substance, conviction & hopes to do something significant with their lives.
Why This Event - Why Motov8ing Boys?
As parents it is our role to guide and advise our sons but it's for that exact reason they often don't want to listen. Sometimes the same message communicated in a different way and by a different person, is all that's needed to start to turn things around.
This event gives parents the opportunity to expose their sons to real advice about life in terms of when the 'rubber hits the road'. Rev engages young males through the use of motorcycles & draws from his years of rider experience to help them to navigate the twists, turns & obstacles that inevitably come across on the ride of life. This event is about much more than motorcycles so even if that's not you or your sons thing there's still a lot of value to be taken away from it.
Rev's communication style is direct, confronting, hard hitting, relative & impactful on both the boys & their parents. He's as direct as they come but it's his raw vulnerability that earns him the right to say what needs to be said to both boys & parents.
What parents are saying about this event.

Brad & Morgan Thomas We went to the Gold Coast event feeling like we were on our own going through this parenting journey that is raising boys aged 12 and 15. We soon relaised that we were not alone in our pain and frustration. Rev had this way of cutting through games our boys play with us to manipulate things to serve themsleves. We walked away with some very confronting truths to face and embrace. Our boys walked away with some clear areas to improve on and some very strategic answers to excuses and objections they hide behind.

Hayley & Hunter Motov8 and Rev absolutely nailed it at the boys' event in Toowoomba! I went along with my 12-year-old son and his friend, and they were hooked from the get-go. Rev’s hard-hitting, raw truth style - mixed with powerful metaphors about life and motorbikes - really landed with them. They were so engaged they didn’t want to leave at the end and were both keen to chat with Rev afterwards. It’s not often you see two young boys hang off every word like that! Highly recommend for anyone raising boys who need strong, real, and relatable role models.

Claire Kelly A friend suggested it and I just had that immediate gut feeling, that we had to take our boys. So, with real effort we dragged 3 tired boys out, not really knowing what to expect. It was great! When we got in the car afterwards, one of them said: "Now that was surprisingly good, I actually really enjoyed it"; and the other 2 agreed. Win! Thank you Rev! We will def be interested in further workshops.

Seona Maybery My boy really didn't want to go to the workshop. I dragged him there with the attitude that it was going to be boring and so on. He couldn't believe that we would have to sit there for 2hrs but at the end of it he couldn't believe how quickly the time went. The comment was also "that wasn't as bad as I thought it was going to be". A win win situation for me and I really think he'll get something out of it. I know that I learnt some things myself. Thanks for teaching us some great strategies to help with the anger. So much to take away from this workshop.

Sarah Verheyen Thank you. Your words are empowering for our teenagers, as I saw in my own boys tonight. The reflection that I saw in them was astounding, and the little changes that started as soon as we walked in the door were proof of the way that you captured their attention. I myself found it very inspiring to hear the way that you have learned how to be a parent - truly inspiring for people like me who have to teach themselves as they weren't taught from an early age. You have given me some steps to further this journey. Your stories and anecdotes really engaged us all.Thanks Rev.

Aaron & Bree Clifford We've been questioning our parenting for some time, doubting ourselves and our values. We walked into this event and we knew very little about it but it was recomended to us by the wellbeing coordinator at our sons school. It was not like anything we had been to before and in a good way. Everything Rev said connected with us in a deep and real way. We walked out and it was like we were both on the same page again. We know what's best for our son and will parent through the pain to get him where he needs to go. Thanks Rev for having the balls to do what you do and say what you say.

Sonya Carter Thanks for your info tonight, I have to say you connected with my boys (both 12) really well in a short space of time (I didn't expect this!). I was impressed with your matter-of-fact approach to neuro-diversity (and so was my neurodiverse son, he's never heard ASD spoken about so bluntly and he liked it.) The three things you said parents want was spot on and our families best take away. Shining a light on our young men's mental health crisis is so important - thanks for your dedication. Take care

All reviews are posted up exactly as we reicive them, to read more CLICK HERE

Mum's please don’t just send your boys with their dad or your partner, where possible come as a family even if you’re separated. There are things that need to be said to your son & it’s much more impacting on them if you’re there next to them. There are just as import things that need to be said to you in front of them as well.
It's very comon for the same boys who whinge, bitch, protest & complain to their parents about having to come along to also be the first boys to come & show gratitude to Rev & their parents after the event is finished.
So, turn off their tech/screens/headsets & bring your boys out to a night of inspiration, motivation mixed with some TUFF love & good advice that could just change your & their lives forever.
What about the girls & their parents?
We also have a girls event called Savage Angels happening at the same location the following evening at the same time. To find out more CLICK HERE
A bit of a look inside a Motov8ing Bioys event.
Event feedback from parents & boys.

events.description:
Pottery - Throwing: Next Step
A follow-on course for those who have some experience of throwing on the wheel and would like some guidance to take their skills to the next stage.
You’ll learn how to “turn” your pots with more confidence and be able to make a variety of small to medium-sized projects. Basic glazing of your pots will also be covered.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
• Turn a pot
• Make a lidded container
• Make a rounded vase
• Form a reasonable sized bowl
• Do basic glazing
All materials included in course fee. Wear old clothes and footwear suitable for a workshop environment and bring an old towel.
Pottery courses are held at Wellington Potters' Association, 130 Grant Road, Thorndon.  All our courses are scheduled up to a year in advance which means the at times we may need to make changes to the original schedule.  Please make sure you check your emails regularly in case of any changes.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Leadership And Management Part 2-AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Leadership And Management Part 2
events.venue: AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington
events.description: Learn how to make the transition from buddy to boss and lead a successful team. As John F. Kennedy once said, “leadership and learning are indispensable to each other”. Our Leadership & Management courses are designed to help you get the best performance from yourself and your team, providing you with the skills and techniques to become better than you ever perceived you could be. The Leadership & Management Part 2 workshop will equip leaders and managers with the skills to build high performing and highly motivated teams; the skills to communicate effectively as a leader, become more self-aware, provide coaching and mentoring, deal with conflict in a constructive and productive manner along with developing ways to solve problems as a team. This workshop also gives participants an understanding of the key concepts of leadership and leadership styles along with how to choose and implement a leadership style that is authentic and beneficial to both the organisation and the teams they serve. Course Prerequisite: Participants must have a good understanding of leadership and management fundamentals and/or have previously attended the Business Training New Zealand - Leadership & Management Part 1 course. To book: email info@biztrainers.co.nz or call 04 974 8790

events.description:
English in the Community: Johnsonville - Elementary (ESOL Level 2)
English in the Community courses help you to learn more English, get to know your community and meet new people. The groups aim to help you use what you already know, learn more from your tutor and the other students and feel more at home in your local community. 
To enrol in these courses, please contact the CEC office on 04 385 8919 or cec@whs.school.nz.
By the end of the course, you'll: 
• Be more confident in speaking English in everyday situations
• Be able to understand more English, especially “New Zealand English”
• Have increased your vocabulary
• Be able to talk more about living in New Zealand and your local community
The courses are free for NZ residents and citizens. The course fee for non-residents is $149.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
Join us for our untutored life drawing sessions in the historic Inverlochy House on Tuesdays from 10am-1pm.

This is a casual life drawing session where by the following applies:

Inverlochy Art School provides the model organised by Denise Durkin, easels and or drawing horses and an amazing space to create in.

events.id: Painting In Oils - Eight Week Course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Painting In Oils - Eight Week Course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
This class is open to all levels of students interested in exploring the possibilities of this traditional medium. The main exercises will be based on a still life, however students are free to explore subjects of their choice.

This course focuses on the technique of oil painting. You will learn to:

- Choose a colour palette
- Choose and prepare supports on which to paint on with oils
- Create a composition according to the subject selected
- Learn how to render volume and form
- Learn expressive qualities of colour and brushwork
- Students will also learn to stretch their own canvas

If you want to explore the possibilities of painting in oils then this is the course for you.

Tuesday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm. 22 July - 9 September.

events.id: Assertiveness - Stand Up For Yourself-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Assertiveness - Stand Up For Yourself
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.description:
Gain practical skills to help you get what you want out of life and improve your self-esteem.

An opportunity to learn practical skills to assist you in communicating in an assertive healthy manner, as well as improving your self-esteem. We'll work both individually and as a group using this environment to help us grow as we learn.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Speak in a language that commands respect and learn how to say “no”
- Use strategies to allow you not to be manipulated by other people
- Affirm yourself and others
- Express increased self-esteem
- Deal assertively with angry feelings and understand your own and others’ anger
- Interact more effectively in your personal relationships and the workplace


Duration 4 weeks, Tue 5:30 PM – 8:00 PM
(NZ Citizens and residents pay $79 with ID, all others pay $149).

events.name: Cooking: Vietnamese Street Food
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Cooking: Vietnamese Street Food
Join our experienced Vietnamese cook and find out how to create a range of traditional dishes from different parts of Vietnam that you can eat for breakfast, lunch and dinner or at any time of day. Recipes include delicious wraps, pancakes, beef noodle soup, fried rolls with rice noodles and much more.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
• Define what characterises Vietnamese cooking and key ingredients
• Recognise and make popular street food from North to South of Vietnam
• Identify retail outlets which supply Vietnamese ingredients
• More confidently follow recipes provided and prepare those recipes with supervision
• Prepare dishes for home eating or entertaining
All ingredients provided but bring an apron, dish cloth, tea towels and containers to take food home. 
Note:  
Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. While we wish to create an inclusive environment for all participants, it is important to note that our courses are unable to accommodate specific food allergies or deviate from the preplanned dishes and menus.

events.id: Sewing - All Levels-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Sewing - All Levels
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Sewing - All Levels
All levels welcome! Beginning sewers will learn basic skills and techniques and those with some experience will improve their skills and learn tips and tricks.
Beginners - If you're a beginner, you'll start by making a lined bag, which teaches all the basic skills involved. After that you'll move on to a project of your choice, in consultation with the tutor.  Please bring: 1 metre of firm cotton fabric for your bag outer and 1 metre of a lighter cotton fabric for the lining. You'll also need to bring scissors, a Bernina bobbin (this can be purchased from the CEC office on the day of the course for $7), pins, thread to match your outer fabric, an 18 cm zip and tape measure to the first session.
 If you're a returning student, or have already mastered the basic skills, you'll work on your own project so please bring along whatever you're currently working on (or something new) and your sewing kit. 
Please note PDF patterns are not suitable for this course unless you are very experienced in using them;  we strongly recommend patterns from the following companies:  Simplicity, Butterick, New Look or Quicksew.
By the end of the course, you'll have been introduced to basic skills in dressmaking, if beginners, or further skills for the more experienced.
You'll be able to:
• Use all sewing machine equipment and demonstrate basic sewing techniques (basic seams and finishes)
• Begin to read a commercial pattern and select appropriate materials for task
• Cut out and construct a garment using techniques learned
• (In addition), use a variety of advanced sewing techniques e.g. rolled hems, various zip insertions (invisible and standard), make buttonholes or line garments. 
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Writing A Novel-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Writing A Novel
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.description:
Kick start your novel in this series of weekly workshops with practical writing exercises which will build ideas, form the raw material of your book and get you started.

Description
An introductory course for those keen to start writing a novel.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Generate ideas for writing your novel
- Create convincing characters
- Write compelling dialogue
- Develop a strong structure for your story
- Follow the process towards completing your first draft

Bring pen and paper.

This course is designed to help you improve your skills, to develop your unique writer's voice and to encourage you to take risks on the page. It is not a course where you'll be asked to read your work out loud, critique other writers' work, or hand in your writing to the tutor. This is a safe place where you will be supported to do what writers do best - write.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 8 weeks,
Donna Banicevich-Gera

events.id: Jewellery Making - Precious Stones in Cast Rings-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Jewellery Making - Precious Stones in Cast Rings
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Jewellery Making - Precious Stones in Cast Rings
Expanding on our classic Lost Wax Cast Rings class,  in this course you get the opportunity to learn and experiment even further by adding precious gemstones to the cast jewellery making process! 

This beginner-friendly jewellery class is also fun and engaging for returning students to diversify their skills and set stones in new ways.
All materials are supplied in your booking so you won't end up with surprise costs.
Included in your course:
Use of a range of jewellery wax types to create 2 practice rings then 1  main project ring
5 facet-cut precious gemstones to set across your 3 rings (choose from rubies, spinels and sapphires in a range of colours)
Industry standard casting services that we will send your wax models away to so they can be transformed into brass, bronze and sterling silver rings
2 original practice rings cast in bronze or brass
1 main project ring cast in Sterling Silver
During sessions 1-3 you will be guided to sculpt a range of wax ring models and embed precious gemstones, finishing one ring each session ready for casting. 
Between classes your waxes will be transformed into rings for you. You can choose from bronze or yellow brass for your first two rings. These first 2 rings are a great opportunity to practice techniques and experiment with shapes, textures and designs before making your main project ring which will be cast in sterling silver!
In the second half of this course you will discover techniques to trim casting sprues, file, sand, refine and polish your casts into finished jewellery.
The bold, organic forms and textures of the lost wax processes offer a wide range of creative possibilities beyond the scope of fabrication methods alone (soldering metal sheet and wire). Setting faceted stones in wax offers a simpler and more experimental way of adding stones to jewellery compared to fabrication settings. methods. Casdt jewellery techniques and fabrication jewellery techniques can also be combined to great effect, which makes this course a fantastic option for beginners and experienced makers alike.

All materials are included in the course fee. Please bring pen and paper and your reading glasses (if you use these) and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.

By the end of the course you will be able to:
Evolve your jewellery making abilities with new and exciting klost-wax methods
Design and create original sculptural ring designs
Carve hard jeweller’s wax ring master designs to fit a chosen finger size for casting
Sculpt soft jeweller’s wax master design to fit a chosen finger size for casting
Form soft jeweller’s wax to create unique designs ready for casting
Set faceted gemstones in wax for ‘cast-in-place’ setting methods
File, sand and polish metal casts into finished jewellery
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Passchendaele: "Mighty few of the bearers are left"-1 Molesworth Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Passchendaele: "Mighty few of the bearers are left"
events.venue: 1 Molesworth Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011
events.description:
Passchendaele - a word that conjures up the horrors of all wars, especially for those now intimately connected with what was then a small and innocuous village in Flanders, the Flemish region of Belgium. In terms of casualties, the morning of 12 October 1917 was - and is - the worst and bleakest day in New Zealand’s history of warfare. 846 of our young men were killed on that morning alone and, by the end of the day, 2740 were dead, wounded or missing.
To commemorate those who fought and died, our Society Board invites you to join us and other guests as we remember the 1917 battle at Passchendaele.
The function will be hosted at Parliament Buildings by Cameron Brewer MP, Member for Upper Harbour and also a member of the Society.
Our guest speaker will be Dr Graham Howie, PhD, OStJ, a career paramedic and university lecturer in paramedicine. In his talk "Mighty few of the bearers are left" he will tell us about the work of stretcher-bearers at Passchendaele, those early paramedics who laboured under the most dreadful conditions to rescue the dead and wounded.

events.id: The Inner Magnet – Manifesting from the Inside Out-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: The Inner Magnet – Manifesting from the Inside Out
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.description:
Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars

The Inner Magnet – Manifesting from the Inside Out

Why do some desires seem to flow effortlessly into our lives, while others feel blocked at every turn? What if the key to manifestation isn’t about effort, but alignment?

This workshop explores how the wisdom of yoga philosophy can help us shift from the noise of a reactive, conditioned mind into a space of deeper inner alignment. Beyond just rewiring thoughts, yoga offers a map back to the part of us that is steady, clear, and deeply connected — an inner magnet that draws what is truly nourishing for our growth and transformation.

Through reflection, and an informed practice, you’ll be invited to consider how tuning inwards can begin to shape your outer reality in more meaningful ways. Whether you're new to yoga philosophy or have walked this path for a while, this session offers a grounded and enriching perspective on the subtle art of manifestation.

Meet your host, Rasesvari
Rasesvari is an events co-ordinator who loves to bring people together and create a warm and memorable experience. She thrives on connection with others and has a deep desire for a lifestyle of yoga, meditation and holistic healing.

events.id: Intro to 2D Traditional Animation - 8 Session Evening Course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Intro to 2D Traditional Animation - 8 Session Evening Course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
This is a beginners course in 2D animation where you'll learn the time-honoured principles of hand-drawn animation and how to apply them to your own animation project. You may work on a project incorporating your own ideas, or if you'd rather, an assigned a project from your tutor.

You can use any device, ipad or laptop you already own (except a mobile – it's really not big enough to do good animation on). The school does not provide any digital equipment.

Your tutor, Ross Payne, is a 30 year veteran of traditional 2D animation, and loves to share his knowledge about it for you to love it as much as he does.

In each lesson there will be examples and demonstrations of the animation principles with follow up exercises to put your new skills into practice. You'll work on your project both during class and at home, applying the animation principles to your individualised project.

You can choose to draw your animation on paper then scan/capture into your device, or choose to draw your animation digitally, directly into an animation programme. which ever you choose, instructions in class will be provided to give you the skills needed for this step.

Ross will advice you on the a variety of animation apps/programmes available online to use, ranging in price from free to not very much.

Note - A computer mouse can be used for 2D animation but digital pens are much easier to use. Prior to the course commencing, you'll receive details of recommended programmes to use for the course.

Tuesday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm.
22 July - 9 September.

events.id: Savage Angels - WELLINGTON-MacLaurin Lecture Theatres Wellington, Wellington 6012-Event Brite
events.name: Savage Angels - WELLINGTON
events.venue: MacLaurin Lecture Theatres Wellington, Wellington 6012
events.description:
Do you worry about your daughters attitude & behaviour?
Does she strugle with a poor sense of self worth or fail to see her potential?
Does she lack courage, confidence & that spark she used to have?
Is she obsessed with her phone, social media or other tech?
Does she struggle to suuround herself with friends who are good for her?
Or are you just tired of repeating yourself over and over again only to get the same result, or even worse…no response at all?

If you answered yes & can relate to some or maybe even all of these then a Savage Angels event is for you.
Savage Angels is an event for girls aged 11-17 & their parents that's focused on Inspiring, Informing & Instructing them how to make smarter more informed decisions in life. We want to empower girls to hold core values that will allow them to stand strong in the face of social media & peer group influences. We know this event has the potential to make a huge difference in girls lives & their futures.
One of the biggest deficits seen in young people today is a lack of social & emotional intelligence. This can lead to a whole range of problems with their personal development at home, at school & with friends both on & off line.
It can put unnecessary strain on relationships with siblings & sometimes unsustainable pressure on parents. Leading to everything from arguements, fights, anxiety, stress & depression through to significant family breakdown.
The topics addressed at these events are all focused on personal development.
Things like self-esteem, confidence, friendships & relationships, social media & mainstream media influence, anxiety, stress, depression, suicide, mindset, apathy, hope, dreams & the hard work required to kick arse in life.
What parents are saying

Ryan & Torrey Hansel - Rev hit the nail right on the head with everything that was said at the Ipswich event we went to. We came for our girls but both of us parents walked away with just as much if not more than them. What was said about the value girls place on people they don't like or care about & what they say will stay with our younger daughter for life, she was so impressed with that simple concept that was taught. Thank you R, T, M15 & H12

Ele Hosie - Savage angel was such an awesome experience the story’s where so real and it was incredibly inspirational and interesting to hear so many peoples stories I feel savage angel really shows you what people are going through and gives you a different perspective on things

Kirsten Webster - Thanks for a very powerful evening Rev. My 12year old daughter took a lot from the night and I have definitely noticed more peace, respect and contribution from her since! I also took a lot from it, I am absolutely stepping up my consistency with consequences. I highly recommend this to parents of girls who just need a little support with communication.

Lisa Short - Great evening, presentation was down to earth, related well to young audience. I recommend, certainly got nothing to lose so why not go along! it starts conversations.....

Sharon Baptist - The session was very open and honest and encouraging. A lot of the core values we had already discussed at home but hearing from Lana and Jo really impressed our girl!! An amazing night and I highly suggest going

Melanie Nicholls - Well worth taking my daughter to this last night. Some very sad stories helped her to put her own life into perspective and she walked away being able to analise the values of true friendship. I’m grateful that she could hear this talk at a young age. Thankyou.

Belinda Marshall - Thank you so much to everyone involved in Savage Angel; tonight was fantastic! The speakers were so inspiring, all with different stories to tell. My 13yo daughter loved it and we will certainly be attending another event in the future.

Taesha - Hi I’m Taesha and I’m using my mums phone I came to the first event tonight and it definitely has made me feel much braver and inspired me to push myself to be the best I can be. I’m 10 years old and got a lot out of the event. Thanks for the savage angel cap and I will wear it proudly.

Deborah Jean Scott - Wow what an awesome experience for both my girls 12 & 16. We all had tears in our eyes at different parts, even Dad. I can't recommend it more highly and would love to become involved with it, in some way. It will only keep going from strength to strength. Thank you all so much for sharing with us xxxx

All reviews are posted up exactly as we reicive them, to read more CLICK HERE
Our ultimate goal is to influence millions of girls across the planet to blaze their own trail & to do it with a great sense of purpose. To do it like the Savage Angels we know they can become.
Warning: These events are not for the politically correct because young people & parents don't think politically correctly when going through a tough time. We fully intend to say things that we know will challenge & upset both young people & parents so don't come along expecting it to be all marshmallows, unicorns & fairy dust because it will be anything but that. The message will be strong to both girls & their parents because that's how we get the results we do.

Please don't book in with a large group of friends, this is not another girls night out it's much more important than that. This is also not just a mother & daughter event, where possible try to come as a family even if you're separated & it's appropriate to do so.
So turn of the tech, screens & headsets they can do without TikTok, Insta & YouTube for 2hrs. Ignore the potential complaints & objections they wont resent you for bringing them, well not for very long.lol
We hope you can make it along to this very significant event.
The Savage Angel Team

What about the boys & their parents?
We also have a boys event called Motov8ing Boys happening at the same location the night before at the same time. To find out more CLICK HERE

events.name: Night Photography - In the Dark
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Night Photography - In the Dark
This course gives you the opportunity to explore and sharpen both your technical and creative skills, so you have the ability and vision to capture the enchanting world that resides in the darkness.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
• Identify the equipment needed to take photographs at night
• Learn fundamentals of photography composition and editing of night images
• Identify how to use technical photographic tools in a night time context
• Explore techniques that allow you to develop a more creative approach to picture making including: light painting, intentional camera movement and light trails
• Recognise the importance of light and colour in night photography and develop your ability to use it to make dynamic images
Course includes a couple of evening field trips (tutor will advise of suitable dates once course is under way).
You must bring a tripod and, if you have one, a neutral density filter and cable release remote. You need a fully manual DSLR or mirrorless camera and an intermediate understanding of camera functions. Not suitable for point and shoot cameras.
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.

This is the first of three KULT events taking place this winter in Wellington, NZ.

KULT is a tribute to electronic music, a night where local techno artists meet the raw energy of Europe’s rave culture, and where we could all celebrate what matters.

events.id: Courageous Communication™ | 1-day Workshop | Wellington | 23 July 2025-55 Cable Street Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Courageous Communication™ | 1-day Workshop | Wellington | 23 July 2025
events.venue: 55 Cable Street Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.description:
Has this ever happened to you?
You’re sitting in a meeting and there are 50 elephants in the room with you that nobody is mentioning, and you’re doing the strategic plan but everyone knows it’s never going to work because the team don’t have the capability or the capacity and that one person never follows through and that other person thinks her work is better than it is, but nobody says anything and as you leave you think well THAT'S three hours I’m never gonna get back…
It’s hard to say the hard thing.
But saying the hard thing is the only way we can deal with what’s actually going on.
The number one indicator of a lack of courage is an inability to have hard conversations.
Hard conversations are scary. Our hearts start pounding, our tummies clench, our mouths go dry.
Hard conversations feel dangerous. If I say this thing, he’ll be offended! She’ll be angry! I’ll get in trouble!
Hard conversations are tempting to avoid. Nobody else is mentioning these elephants. Why should I?
But what if you were great at them?
What would it mean for your relationships?
What would it mean for your career?
What would it mean for your life?
Kaila Colbin has worked with more than 4,000 people to grow courage as a core competency and a clear framework has emerged from that experience.
In this 1-day workshop, you’ll build the skill and muscle to get great at having hard conversations.
We’ll cover the specific elements of how to communicate and what to communicate.

When: Wednesday, 23 July 2025, 9 am-4:30 pm
Where: Rangimarie Room, Te Papa Museum, 55 Cable Street, Wellington 6011
Lunch, afternoon tea and all-day tea and coffee are included in the registration.

Need help with the cost?
If you are an Educator or at a Not-for-Profit, you can automatically access a special rate of $745 + GST when you register (a $250 discount off our standard General Admission rates).

Our Health and Safety Plan
Boma is committed to delivering safe events. We follow best practices suggested by the New Zealand health authorities and work closely with our suppliers to prioritise health and wellbeing.
Our comprehensive health and safety plans ensure you can book with certainty and attend with confidence.

Our refund policy
For details on event refunds and transfers, please see our refund policy.

About the Kaila Colbin
Kaila Colbin is founder and CEO of Boma, an organisation building a world of intentional, intelligent, courageous leaders.
An award-winning leader renowned for impact, Kaila developed TEDxChristchurch into New Zealand’s flagship TEDx event and brought Singularity University to New Zealand and Australia, supporting thousands of people to engage with exponentially accelerating technologies and their impact on humanity. She trained with Dr Brené Brown as a Certified Dare to Lead™ Facilitator.
As a founder of the non-profit Ministry of Awesome, Kaila played a critical role in developing Christchurch’s startup ecosystem. She has extensive governance experience, and has been involved with mergers, capital raises, and company sales in the US and NZ.
A native New Yorker, Kaila’s work to champion Aotearoa New Zealand on a global stage saw her given the 2022 Kea World Class New Zealand “Friend of New Zealand” award. Her purpose in life is to be an uplifting presence.

If you have any questions about this event, please email us at hello@boma.global.

events.id: START UP: An Introduction to Presenting Yourself & Your Message // 23 July-40 Bowen Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: START UP: An Introduction to Presenting Yourself & Your Message // 23 July
events.venue: 40 Bowen Street, Pipitea, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Do you see presenting as an opportunity or an ordeal?
If it's uncomfortable for you, it's uncomfortable for the people watching or listening.
Let us help you make it an opportunity that you'll enjoy.
am&co’s Start UP is a short, sharp workshop in presenting yourself and your message. It gives you the essential tools and techniques for not only that special presentation but for your everyday communication.
It’s all about bringing out the real you so you are the best you when you have to front up.
The workshop will cover:
How to make a powerful and compelling impression to keep your audience engaged.
Techniques and tips for effective presentations.
How to identify and simplify what you say.
How to get better at communicating ideas and influencing others.
How to prepare yourself, manage the stress and get performance ready.
A practical exercise to test the theory and the techniques.
Limited places available (maximum 14 people).
Feedback: 
“Incredibly effective use of time. Supportive & clear learning objectives.” - Amy Carter, One NZ
“Really safe place created by the trainers - super helpful.” - Sarah Bellett, One NZ
“Clear, concise, engaging and safe.” - Suzannah Winger, One NZ
“It was so awesome, fun and great pace.”- Laureen Reeve, One NZ
About am&co 
am&co is a communications company led by award-winning former TV current affairs reporter and presenter, Amanda Millar. We help grow the best listeners, leaders and speakers. We’re all about creating real communicators.

events.description:
We're bringing back our very popular one-day Quality Relationships in Youth Mentoring programme. This is the second workshop in our Sharing the Kaupapa series. These were last offered around the country in 2023. It is focused on the art of forming and maintaining relationships with young people in mentoring.
Workshop objectives
To learn more about effective mentoring
To develop specialised skills to build relationships with young people
To reintroduce and remind practitioners about the Guide to Effective and Safe Practice in Youth Mentoring (2nd edition)
To expand upon Section 3 of the Guide: The Mentoring Relationship
To provide new frameworks, research and skills to strengthen quality mentoring relationships, available for all levels of mentoring programme delivery, including coordinators, teachers, mentors, youth workers and volunteers.
To strengthen regional and national networks in the well-established youth mentoring community
To have fun!
Who should attend?
This workshop is for people who work with young people, including: mentors, mentor programme providers, youth workers, educators, school counsellors, pastors, central and local government agency staff and community workers.
Registration fee
There is a registration fee of $200 plus GST and booking fee. Catering is included and you will also receive a comprehensive workbook to take back to work with you.
To find out more about the workshop, visit our website https://www.youthmentoring.org.nz/about-our-workshops/

events.id: NAWIC Wellington Site Visit: Whakawhirinaki – The Silverstream Pipe Bridge-Access to Hutt River Cycle Trail Eastern Hutt Road, Silverstream, Upper Hutt 5019, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: NAWIC Wellington Site Visit: Whakawhirinaki – The Silverstream Pipe Bridge
events.venue: Access to Hutt River Cycle Trail Eastern Hutt Road, Silverstream, Upper Hutt 5019, New Zealand
events.description:
NAWIC Wellington Site Visit: Whakawhirinaki – The Silverstream Pipe Bridge
Join NAWIC Wellington for a special site visit to one of the region’s most critical infrastructure projects – the Whakawhirinaki Pipe Bridge in Silverstream.
📍 Location: Whakawhirinaki Pipe Bridge Project Site, Silverstream, Upper Hutt
📅 Date: Wednesday 23 July
🕒 Time: 3:45 PM (approx 1hr duration).
👷‍♀️ PPE Required: Hardhat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, safety glasses, long pants, and long sleeves.
(PPE spares available, so please let us know in your RSVP if you need to borrow any items.)
Kindly hosted by Brian Perry Civil, this behind-the-scenes look at the nearly completed pipe bridge will offer a rare opportunity to see innovative civil construction in action. The visit is strictly limited to 15 places, so get in quick!
Constructed on behalf of Greater Wellington and Wellington Water, the new pipe bridge replaces a seismically vulnerable section of bulk water pipeline that supplies all of Porirua City and North Wellington. The project involves 1000 metres of 1-metre diameter steel pipe across the Te Awa Kairangi / Hutt River and Manor Park golf course – including a striking new three-span pipe bridge with a 100m network arch at the central span.
Named Whakawhirinaki by local iwi during a dawn ceremony, the name reflects the trust and responsibility the bridge carries as it delivers essential water to thousands of people.
Through early contractor involvement and outside-the-box thinking, Brian Perry Civil and other project stakeholders have achieved significant cost savings and carbon reductions, showcasing innovation in both design and delivery.
🎟️ This event is free and open to NAWIC members only
🦺 Spaces are limited. RSVP now to secure your spot!
We look forward to seeing you onsite!
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.
Photo supplied: Brian Perry Civil

events.name: Public Cupping
events.venue: 119 Dixon Street Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.description:
Join us at The Hangar for a public cupping focused on one of the most fascinating parts of coffee production: processing methods
We’ll be tasting coffees processed using washed, natural, honey, and anaerobic methods, each one creating a completely different flavor experience in the cup. From clean and citrusy to jammy and wild, you’ll get to explore how fermentation and drying techniques influence sweetness, acidity, and body
This is a relaxed, interactive session where you can sip, slurp, and chat about what you’re tasting. Whether you're a seasoned coffee nerd or just curious to learn more, this is a great way to build your sensory skills and deepen your appreciation for specialty coffee

events.id: Shared Stories: Asset Mapping for Disaster Preparedness-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Shared Stories: Asset Mapping for Disaster Preparedness
events.venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Shared stories: asset mapping for disaster preparedness
 Join us to create and map together our shared knowledge and assets to build collective community resilience. No prior knowledge needed!
 Anna Brown is a research co-lead of the project Ngā Ngaru Wakapuke; a climate and disaster research project. As part of this mapping exercise she will share her work with several communities in Tairāwhiti, Wairarapa and Ōtautahi/Christchurch around mapping, disaster resilience and storytelling. She describes maps as more than locational tools; as a way to build a common understanding of shared assets.
 Anna will lead us through an exercise to record Wellington CBD’s community points of interest, that will be added to over the course of Critical Signals.
 About the host
Anna Brown is a designer, researcher and educator. She is Professor of Design and Public Good at Massey University’s College of Creative Arts. She founded and leads Toi Āria: Design for Public Good. She uses design to create positive change by bringing together organisations, government, and communities — especially making sure the people most affected by decisions have a say in shaping them.

events.id: Creative Writing - A Tasting Plate-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Creative Writing - A Tasting Plate
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Creative Writing - A Tasting Plate
How often have you said, ‘I wish I could write’? There are many different kinds of writing. Starting is easy so why not give it a go by joining this creative writing ‘tasting plate’.
Each week we’ll focus on a different area of fiction or creative non-fiction. By the end of the programme, you’ll have tried your hand at writing a short story, a narrative poem, a travel memoir, a personal essay drawing from your life, an interview article, a story for children, a short film script and a piece of historical fiction.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
• Create works of fiction 
• Develop creative non-fiction text 
• Explore the natural inner spirit of writing 
• Discover your unique writer’s voice 
• Reflect on your own experiences in writing 
• Investigate different writing strategies
• Discover where your personal writing passions sit and what works for you.
Bring pen and paper or a laptop. 
This course is designed to help you improve your skills, to develop your unique writer's voice and to encourage you to take risks on the page. It is not a course where you'll be asked to read your work out loud, critique other writers work, or hand in your writing to the tutor. This is a safe place where you will be supported to do what writers do best - write.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Conservation Kōrero: Talk Toitoi To Me-ZEALANDIA Eco-Sanctuary, Waiapu Road, Karori, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Conservation Kōrero: Talk Toitoi To Me
events.venue: ZEALANDIA Eco-Sanctuary, Waiapu Road, Karori, Wellington
events.description:
They may be little fish in a big pond, but their growing impact has been sending ripples across Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne.

Toitoi, or common bully, have been translocated across three years from Kohangapiripiri near the Pencarrow Lighthouse to the Roto Māhanga/Upper Reservoir in Zealandia. An endearing little ika, these fish are now thriving at Zealandia, being spotted along Te Māhanga stream, in Roto Kawau/Lower Reservoir, and downstream beyond the fence!

Central to the kaupapa of this project was ongoing improvements to translocating the fish as we worked with mana whenua to incorporate traditional mātauranga Māori methods, and now together we want to share the whole story with you.

Join us for our next Conservation Kōrero, where a panel of participants in the toitoi translocations from 2023-2025 share the development of the translocations and the discoveries we made along the way.

This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 5.45pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.

events.id: Mindfulness Meditation-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Mindfulness Meditation
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Mindfulness Meditation
Meditation can help us with life’s challenges and is a wise way to work with strong emotions and stress, as well as enlivening the ordinary times. It’s simple and doesn’t need any special resources. Often learning to meditate is presented as something esoteric and mysterious but really it should be a straightforward thing based on our everyday experience.
Come along to this course and learn how to put a meditation practice in place in your life. You’ll be introduced to some different meditation and mindfulness techniques and get an insight into the modern psychology and the ancient wisdom that supports a meditation practice.
The four sessions will provide time to practise different styles of meditation, lots of hints about a fruitful approach to take to set up a regular practice in your life and opportunities to discuss progress with others in the group.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Describe some ways in which modern psychology and ancient wisdom support meditation
Understand what you need to do to make time for meditation in your life
Describe practical tips to make meditation fruitful
Practise different kinds of guided and silent meditation
Find resources (books, on-line information, other classes and retreats) to support your meditation
Bring a notepad and pen.

We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
