events.id: Anyone Can Draw - Structural-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Anyone Can Draw - Structural
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
In this course you will examine structural drawing with a careful helpful approach, focusing on simple perspective drawing and the value of geometric shapes and solids. Both these structural approaches contribute greatly to the success of your drawing.

Geometric shapes can simplifying a subject, unify a drawing and make compositions dynamic. Geometric solids will help render any subject in three dimensions and transition to perspective.

A good working knowledge of the concepts of perspective will help you draw any subject with correct dimensionality. It can also help in your realist drawing, painting and invented subjects and environments. These concepts are also used in most two dimensional art because it enables us to realise great spatial effects, making it an invaluable tool to add to your skill set.

In this course you will learn the following:

- Focus on geometric shapes and solids and how they contribute to both realist and abstract drawing
- Form an appreciation of geometry and shapes that can help with constructing a drawing
- The important tools, methods and concepts of one-point, two-point and three-point perspective
- Universal boxing, drawing ellipses
- Hints in locating helpful lines and axis to draw real subjects
- Introductory methods of working that blend perspective knowledge with real drawing situations

All basic materials supplied.

Wednesday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm, 23 July - 10 September.
OR
Friday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm, 25 July - 12 September.

events.id: Qi Gong-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Qi Gong
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Qi Gong
Qigong has both psychological and physical components and involves the regulation of the mind, breath, and body’s movement and posture.
In most forms of qigong:
Breath is slow, long, and deep. Breath patterns may switch from abdominal breathing to breathing combined with speech sounds.
Movements are typically gentle and smooth, aimed for relaxation.
Mind regulation includes focusing one’s attention and visualization.
Dynamic (active) qigong techniques primarily focus on body movements, especially movements of the whole body or arms and legs. Meditative (passive) qigong techniques can be practiced in any posture that can be maintained over time and involve breath and mind exercises, with almost no body movement.
Wear loose, comfortable clothing and bring a bottle of water.
[This is a physical activity that involves an element of risk.  While all possible measures are taken to prevent accidents or injury, please note that participation is at your own risk].

events.id: NZSO — Mana Moana-Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: NZSO — Mana Moana
events.venue: Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
It’s an amalgamation of symphony and song. ‘Mana Moana’ is a unique concert presenting the sounds of the Pacific. The New Zealand Symphony Orchestra has joined forces with the Signature Choir to display traditional and contemporary music from the islands. The Michael Fowler Centre will swell when the 80-strong choir sing songs from Samoa, Tonga, Fiji, Cook Islands, Niue, and Tokelau. 
“We are excited for our communities to see Mana Moana in person. Partnering with a world-class orchestra to sing songs that are prominent and significant to our Pasifika communities provides a huge sense of pride. It’s hard to not get emotional when performing.” says Signature Choir Music Director Helen Tupai. The programme will include ‘Faliu le la’ – a song that depicts the beauty of Samoa’s beautiful landscape. Audiences will also hear ‘Isa lei’ – a Fijian farewell song, and ‘Siueli o e pasifiki’ written by Queen Salote Tupou III. This song proclaims her love for her beloved country.

events.id: The Pipeline of Potential: A welfare-to-work policy report-157 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The Pipeline of Potential: A welfare-to-work policy report
events.venue: 157 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
The Institute for Democratic and Economic Analysis (IDEA) invites you to attend the launch of its first research project: a deep dive into welfare-to-work policy at a light breakfast event on Thursday 24th July.
The Pipeline of Potential report looks at how we could transform the support we offer to unemployed people seeking paid work, simultaneously lifting their prospects and boosting the wider economy. Join us to hear IDEA research director Max Rashbrooke opening up new perspectives on a long neglected policy area. His recommendations outline investments in training and work programmes that could change lives and constitute a key building block for a more robust economy.
Please RSVP for this free event by clicking on "Get tickets". You are welcome to register more than one person.

events.id: Contemporary Realism - 8 Week Painting Course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Contemporary Realism - 8 Week Painting Course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
Whether you work from objects, the figure, or secondary sources, this is an opportunity to explore working more loosely, using oils or acrylics.

Experienced tutor, Justine Turnbull, will guide you through drawing and painting exercises to help loosen you up, and will discuss art historical techniques that may be relevant to your individual artistic style and context.

This course will increase your ability to represent perceived objects in a dynamic, painterly way. You will be guided through drawing and painting exercises to help you achieve accuracy of form, working loosely with oils and acrylics to create fresh contemporary paintings. The emphasis is on working with your chosen source material to create a `next level’ painting. This course is for those who have explored some of the basics of painting such as mixing colours, blending etc, but want to find a process that best expresses your unique approach and ideas. Skills learnt in class can be applied across all genres.

Materials are not included in this course.
Materials: Please bring your preferred range of oils, brushes and supports (paper, canvas, or board). A good basic set of oil paints would include cad and lemon yellow, ultramarine and cerulean blue, and cad red and alizarin crimson. Also, black and white. Inverlochy will supply Liquin and odourless turps. Please also bring a photocopied reference image in both black and white and colour.

Lunch break - 30 minutes. Bring a water bottle and packed lunch to enjoy in the historic Inverlochy House or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

Thursdays, 9:30 - 3 pm.
24 July - 11 September.

events.id: Intro to Watercolour Painting - 8 week course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Intro to Watercolour Painting - 8 week course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
This class is for anyone interested in making realistic watercolour studies of the world around them.

We will be covering the fundamentals of watercolour: washes, edges, colour theory, composition, tonal value, materials, lighting, subtlety and simplification.

Each week there will be a new still life to work from and artist examples to take inspiration from. Students can also bring along items they would like to paint.

No prior painting experience needed.

In this course you will:

- learn all the basics of watercolour painting.
- discover techniques to manage the paint
- build your confidence to start working on your own projects

You will need to purchase your basic materials for this course and bring them to each class. See materials list below.

Material list for this course is as follows:

- Paper: A4 Hahnemühle Brittania Matt 300g Watercolour Paper, 10 sheet pack, or any watercolour paper. (100% cotton cold-pressed best if budget allows).
- Paint: Pebeo Studio Watercolour Paint 12 colour set, or any watercolour paint. [Need these 6 colours: warm red (e.g., cadmium red), cool red (e.g., alizarin crimson), warm yellow (e.g., cadmium yellow), cool yellow (e.g., lemon yellow), warm blue (e.g., ultramarine), cool blue (e.g., cobalt or prussian). Optional colours: raw sienna, burnt sienna, and viridian].
- Brushes: 1 size 12 round synthetic watercolour brush with a fine tip (e.g., Da Vinci Fit Hobby brush round 373/12 is a good option). [Later on, a brush set is useful: large round (size 20 or 30), medium round (size 10 or 12), small round (size 2 or 3), ½ inch flat brush, size 1 rigger brush, & detail brush size 0].
- Also needed expression folding plastic palette or similar
- Masking Tape Delicate 12mm
- A soft pencil (2B or 4B),
- A kneadable eraser

Inverlochy students get a 10% discount from Gordon Harris art supplies shop. Materials can also be purchased from Spotlight, Whitcoulls, Paper Plus, Warehouse Stationery, Takapuna Art Supplies.

Watercolour shown on website - Magnolia in Glass, Mark Adams, 1979

Thursday mornings, 10 am - 1 pm.
24 July - 11 September.

events.id: Whaimana | Support My Decisions Launch-56 The Terrace, Wellington Central, Wellington 6140, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Whaimana | Support My Decisions Launch
events.venue: 56 The Terrace, Wellington Central, Wellington 6140, New Zealand
events.description:
Come along to the launch of ‘Whaimana - Support My Decisions’
When: 11am-12:30pm, 24 July 2025
Where: Online via MS Teams or in person at 56 The Terrace, Aurora Centre, Wellington Central.
Whaimana - Support My Decisions is a website about Supported Decision Making. Supported decision-making helps people make their own choices about their lives, with the support of the people that they choose.
The website has helpful information for:
·       people making choices and decisions (decision-makers)
·       family, whānau, and friends who want to support people
·       paid supporters working for disabled people or older persons with reduced capacity
·       supporters who have may hold legal roles such as EPOA (Enduring Power of Attorney), Welfare Guardian or Property Manager
·       advocates (people who speak up for others).
The launch of Whaimana – Support My Decisions will be celebrated with Hon. Louise Upston, Minister for Disability Issues, and Paula Tesoriero, CE of Whaikaha – Ministry of Disabled People, and advisory group members.
We will take a tour of the website, to show you information, resources, and links. This website was put together by  Whaikaha - Ministry of Disabled People and an advisory group made up of people with dementia, disabled people, tāngata whaikaha Māori, and family/whānau who worked along side non-government organisations, other government agencies,
NZSL interpreters and light catering will be provided.

events.id: Cocktails and Constellations-The White Swan, 109 Main Street, Greytown-Event Finder
events.name: Cocktails and Constellations
events.venue: The White Swan, 109 Main Street, Greytown
events.description:
Hillview Property Investments bring you a very special evening of stars, stories and superb cocktails.

Join us at 5:30pm for a welcome cocktail and canapés. Then, armed with the most excellent time machines, Hari and Sam from Star Safari — an astrobiologist and an astrophysicist — take alien spotting to a whole new level. Using their extra-large telescopes, they’ll take you back in time. You’ll see double when looking at Alpha Centauri, star clusters that make diamonds jealous, and galaxies so far away their light set out before Greytown even existed.

As a bonus — and for your eyes only — you’ll get exclusive access to the Wishing Well Cluster to make a wish (or several).

All this whilst imbibing on delightful Greytown Distilling Company gin cocktails from a private suite at The White Swan. This will be a memorable night indeed.

This is a partially outdoor event so rug up. Restricted, ages 18+. Ticket includes two gin cocktails.
Plus you can get 30% off accommodation at The White Swan - a promotion code will be sent to you after your ticket purchase.

Tickets limited to 15 people per event, to ensure an intimate and engaging experience. If this event is postponed by the organisers, due to unsuitable weather other dates will be offered.

Proudly sponsored by Hillview Property Investments.

events.id: Crochet for Calmness-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Crochet for Calmness
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Crochet for Calmness
The repetitive movements of crochet help the brain make more serotonin, which can decrease tension and feelings of depression. We’ll move through all the steps from the starting slipknot to reading patterns and diagrams and making your first crochet projects.
You’ll learn to make a granny square, change colours and how to increase and decrease. You’ll also find out more about the notations and abbreviations of crochet stitches so you can make those awesome crochet projects you've been waiting to make!
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
• Discuss the benefits of crochet for relaxation and alleviation of mood
• Read a basic crochet pattern and recognise crochet terminology
• Choose yarns and hooks for projects
• Use a range of stitches with confidence
• Complete at least one project of your choice (granny square, keychain, garden decoration)
Suitable for all beginners, both left and right-handers and those who may have struggled to learn to crochet. Initial materials provided but please bring along any yarn or crochet hooks you would like to work with.

events.id: FLINT Wellington: Fintech Futures - From Ideas to Impact-1 Whitmore Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: FLINT Wellington: Fintech Futures - From Ideas to Impact
events.venue: 1 Whitmore Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Join us on July 24th for an electrifying FLINT Fintech panel event that promises to be a game-changer! We're bringing together some of the brightest minds in the industry to discuss the future of financial technology and innovation, specifically aimed at young, aspiring fintech enthusiasts.
Our stellar lineup includes:
Asantha Wijeyeratne, the dynamic CEO and co-founder of Paysource, who’s revolutionizing the way we think about payroll.
Emma Geard, a savvy senior associate from MinterEllisonRuddWatts, with a sharp focus on payments, technology and its legal implications.
Adiraj Gupta is a seasoned fintech entrepreneur across NZ and the US
The visionary GM Startups and Tech Sector at Creative HQ, Colm Kearny, leading the charge in startups from Fintech to climate.
This event is perfect for young people eager to dive into the world of fintech startups. You'll hear about the exciting innovations, the challenges faced, the obstacles to watch out for, and gain the confidence to just go for it. Don't miss this opportunity to gain insights, network with industry leaders, and be part of the conversation shaping the future of fintech. See you there!
We are incredibly thankful to the team at MinterEllisonRuddWatts for their hosting and partnership for this event.
Grab your ticket today! It's FREE for FLINT members (see below how to join). 
We can't wait to welcome you to this fun and interactive session. 
__________________________________
Asantha has over 20 years’ experience of unparalleled focus on helping small businesses navigate the difficult landscape of effective payroll. His formal background in accounting, combined with his ‘people first’ attitude, has seen him successfully build a number of businesses into market leadership positions. Asantha’s obsession is the small business sector, with a technology and customer service focus. He loves seeing someone with determination and passion turn an idea into a business that supports them, their families and the wider community. He gets a lot of enjoyment from making tech work to help business owners succeed. In recognition of his contribution to business and the community, he was awarded a Queen's Service Medal (QSM) in the New Year’s honours list in 2013 and was a finalist in Ernst & Young’s 2021 Entrepreneur of the Year.
Colm is GM of Startups and Tech Sector at Creative HQ, Wellington’s basecamp for bold ideas and entrepreneurial thinking. He leads the team behind the Fintech Lab Accelerator, supporting early-stage fintech founders to validate, grow and scale their ventures – helping turn ambitious ideas into real-world impact.
Creative HQ’s work spans startup acceleration, innovation training, and ecosystem development – with fintech a fast-growing focus. Colm will share insights from the frontline of Aotearoa’s startup scene and spotlight upcoming opportunities for those looking to shape the future of financial services.
Emma is a banking and finance lawyer at MinterEllisonRuddWatts with broad regulatory and advisory experience and particular expertise in payment systems and prudential regulation of banks, non-bank deposit takers and financial markets infrastructure. She has advised financial institutions and financial industry bodies on regulatory change, engaging with the legislative process, compliance and enforcement matters .
Adiraj Gupta is a seasoned fintech entrepreneur across NZ and the US, with ventures in cross-border payments, crypto, and personal finance. His latest venture, Sendd, helps small businesses launch online stores in seconds. He’s Entrepreneur in Residence at The Atom and a tireless connector in Wellington’s startup community
Grab your ticket today! It's FREE for FLINT members (see below how to join). 
We can't wait to welcome you to this fun and interactive session. 
__________________________________
About FLINT
If you’re in the early stages of your digital career and you’re interested in digital technologies, come join the FLINT programme in your local city. We host events, webinars, podcasts and social catch ups that offer valuable networking, learning and growth opportunities. 
Find out more here: Flint - TUANZ

events.name: How To Be A DJ - An Introduction
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki St, Wellington
events.description:
Always wanted to try being a DJ but not sure where to begin? Experienced and professional DJ Shan (Shannon Chng-Rawiri) will teach you all about the technical aspects, equipment and terminology, as well as the industry in general, and enable you to put together a confident short performance.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

- Confidently present a 5 minute performance in class

events.id: Kiki's Delivery Service (魔女の宅急便)-Embassy of Japan, Level 18, 100 Willis Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Kiki's Delivery Service (魔女の宅急便)
events.venue: Embassy of Japan, Level 18, 100 Willis Street, Wellington
events.description:
Come along to our free Japanese Film night, co-organised with the Japan Foundation, Sydney!

Synopsis
Discover Kiki’s Delivery Service, a fantastic coming-of-age tale full of magic, adventure, and self-discovery from the sensational imagination of Academy Award–winning director Hayao Miyazaki (2002, Best Animated Feature, Spirited Away). Kiki is an enterprising young girl who must follow tradition to become a full-fledged witch. Venturing out with only her chatty black cat, Jiji, Kiki flies off for the adventure of a lifetime. Landing in a far-off city, she sets up a high-flying delivery service and begins a wonderful experience of independence and responsibility as she finds her place in the world. Rarely has the animator's art been so brilliantly rendered as in this delightfully imaginative film that will entertain boys and girls everywhere.

Director: MIYAZAKI Hayao / Classification: PG / Year: 1989 Genre: Anime, Children/Family
Language: Japanese with English subtitles

Copyright:© 1989 Eiko Kadono - Studio Ghibli - N

A short Japan Video Topics DVD will be shown from 5:15pm before the start of the film at 5:30pm. Free admission is based on a first-come, first-served basis, with a full theatre capacity of 40 people. No food is permitted in the theatre

events.id: Photography: Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Photography: Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Photography: Unlocking the Secrets to Captivating Images
Elevate your photography from ordinary to extraordinary and ensure your work stands out in the digital age. Creating captivating photographs and understanding what makes a photograph engaging is something every photographer should master. Camera settings are essential, but once you know them, you need to learn how to take photographs that stir emotions, impact your audience, and leave a lasting impression. After all, isn’t that the true purpose of photography? People don’t want to see the same landscapes or flowers they’ve seen thousands of times. But how do you turn what you love into something that makes people go, "Wow"?
 Captivation in photography means stopping a viewer in their tracks, making them look, feel, and connect. It’s about delivering a photograph that enthrals, evokes profound emotions, and shifts perspectives.
In a world brimming with images, only a few have the power to truly captivate and linger in our memories.
 This pioneering course is your gateway to mastering the art of creating captivating photographs at a time when AI-generated images are saturating our visual landscape. Create something genuine and memorable—images that spark curiosity, evoke emotions, and inspire changes in perception. It's time to define your unique style, refine your vision, and make your mark.
 Course Outcomes
 By the end of the five-week course, you’ll be able to: 
Identify the foundational elements that transform an ordinary image into a captivating one.
Create photographs that make people say "Wow" by applying techniques that add a spark of wonder to your shots.
Infuse your photographs with curiosity, making each frame a source of intrigue and interest.
Understand why some images linger in memory and how to make your photographs unforgettable.
Develop a unique style and vision that sets your work apart in the crowded digital landscape.
Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Intro to Acrylic Painting - 8 week course-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Intro to Acrylic Painting - 8 week course
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
This is a foundational class that will enable you to make a painting of your choice! The course is open to people of any level of experience.

Bring in a reference or set up a still life and we will deconstruct how to paint it. You will leave with paintings as well as a toolbox for breaking any subject matter down into simple steps. Personalised tutor feedback will help you refine your skills and develop a unique style. At the beginning of each class there will be a practical demonstration.

Throughout the term we will cover the following:

- Materials and equipment
- Preparing the ground
- Designing the composition
- Colour relationships, warm and cool, colour mixing
- How to simplify the major shadows
- Subtleties of the mid tones
- Highlights, and other finishing touches
- When to stop painting (important!)
- Realism and style

Basic materials included. Students must be at least 18 years of age to attend this course.

Thursday evenings, 6 - 8 pm.
24 July - 11 September.

events.id: Jewellery Making - Lost Wax Cast Rings-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Jewellery Making - Lost Wax Cast Rings
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Jewellery Making - Lost Wax Cast Rings
The lost wax process offers a wide range of creative outcomes such as 3D forms and textures, which are not achievable with fabrication soldering techniques.
You'll get a hands-on opportunity to develop new techniques creating rings with a sculptural and organic flair.
All materials are supplied and included, so you won't end up with surprise "extra" costs.
Included in your course:
Explore using a range of jewellery wax types to create 2 practice rings and 1 X main project ring
Access to industry-standard casting services where we will send your  wax models to be transformed into brass, bronze and sterling silver rings 
2 original practice rings cast in bronze or yellow brass
1 main project ring cast in sterling silver
In sessions 1, 2 and 3 you will be guided to sculpt a range of wax ring models, finishing one each session so it is ready for casting. Between classes your waxes will be transformed into rings for you. You can choose from bronze or yellow brass for your first two rings. These first 2 rings are a great opportunity to practice techniques and experiment with shapes, textures and designs before making your main project ring which will be cast in sterling silver!
In the second half of this course you will discover techniques to trim casting sprues, file, sand, refine and polish your casts into finished jewellery.
This course offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience, it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels!
All materials are included in course fee.  Please bring pen and paper and your reading glasses (if you use these) and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.  
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-          Evolve your jewellery making abilities with new and exciting lost wax methods
-          Develop and create unique sculptural ring designs
-          Carve hard jeweller’s wax ring master designs to fit a chosen finger size for casting
-          Form soft jeweller’s wax master design to fit a chosen finger size for casting
-          Combine hard and soft jeweller’s wax to create unique designs ready for casting
-          File, sand and polish metal casts into finished jewellery
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Inspired: Using Notion for Mindful Productivity-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Inspired: Using Notion for Mindful Productivity
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.description:
Inspired: Using Notion for Mindful Productivity

What if your to-do list felt as nourishing as your breathwork practice?

This is the perfect 60-minute live workshop where Elebreath®️ meets mindful systems—a space to organize your life and business without slipping into hustle mode. We’ll blend somatic awareness with Notion, the all-in-one tool I use to manage my energy, organize my mind, and create with more ease.

Plus - there’s an amazing plant-based dinner & dessert after your event. All included in the ticket price!

This isn’t just about getting things done. It’s about doing it from a regulated, resourced place—so your nervous system feels held every step of the way.

Perfect for:
Soulful entrepreneurs, wellness professionals, creatives, and high-performers craving structure without burnout.

What You’ll Learn:

How your nervous system influences focus, clarity, and creative flow

How I integrate Elebreath®️ to map my energy before taking action

The exact Notion system I use to track tasks, brain dumps, and flow states

How to design a dashboard that moves with your body, not against it

You’ll Walk Away With:

A fully set-up Notion workspace that mirrors your calmest, clearest self

A Daily Flow Tracker + Brain Dump Inbox to release the mental clutter

Tools to show up consistently—even on low-energy days

Included in your ticket:

Lifetime access to the free resources like: guided breathwork, fatigue guide, and many more

My Notion templates & tracker bundle

Bonus PDF: Nervous-System Safe Productivity Rituals

An amazing plant-based dinner & dessert!

This is productivity with breath, intention, and soul.
Come as you are. Leave with clarity, calm, and a system that works with you.

Meet Lynn, your host

Lynn supports visionaries, wellness practitioners, and purpose-driven creatives to return to their bodies, unlock their energetic potential, and grow businesses that feel deeply aligned and regenerative.

Her approach weaves together somatic healing and conscious entrepreneurship—blending breathwork, trauma-informed nervous system care, yogic wisdom, and energetic mastery into my signature modality, Elebreath®️. It’s more than a method—it’s a remembrance of your most embodied, empowered self.

Alongside this deep inner work, Lynn guides Soulful Notion®️ Workshops—where nervous system regulation meets mindful productivity. Using Notion as a soul-aligned system, we co-create space for structure, ease, and clarity—so you can live and work in a way that honors your energy.

Whether you're seeking deeper purpose, more sustainable flow, or a business that mirrors your dharma—my work is here to support your return to truth, breath by breath.

Because success rooted in soul and body is the kind that actually lasts.

Check out Lynn on her Instagram and website

events.id: Yin Yoga & Sound Healing-Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Yin Yoga & Sound Healing
events.venue: Bhakti Lounge Wellington, 1st Floor, 175 Vivian Street, Wellington
events.description:
Yin Yoga & Sound Healing
Slow yoga, soothing sounds, and a nourishing plant-based meal—a grounding evening from start to finish.

Take a pause from the rush and settle into an evening of deep rest and reconnection. This special session combines the stillness of yin yoga with the soothing power of sound healing—an immersive experience to calm the body and quiet the mind.

Yin yoga is a slow, meditative practice where poses are held for several minutes, allowing the body to open gently and the nervous system to reset. It’s a chance to soften, breathe, and listen inward.

As you rest in each pose, you’ll be surrounded by the gentle sounds of healing frequencies. Sound healing works on a vibrational level—helping to release tension, restore balance, and bring a sense of inner peace.

Guided by Nicola’s thoughtful approach to yin and Nizaad’s calming presence with sound, this evening is a space to simply be—to feel, to unwind, and to receive.
To close the night, we’ll share a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert—included in your ticket.

All levels welcome.

events.id: Life Drawing - 8 Week Tutored Art Lessons-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Life Drawing - 8 Week Tutored Art Lessons
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
The figure is an attractive and fascinating subject. In our tutored life drawing class we provide a supportive relaxed environment where you can learn figure drawing and practice from a variety of great models. Enjoy an evening of figure drawing with instruction and effective ideas to develop.

Each week we will examine tested drawing exercises that are great for practicing drawing the figure and valuable to help you problem solve. These exercises are effective and build your observational drawing. They build sensitivity to real shape, to gesture, form and the structure of figures. Our focus is to create figures that are convincing and have life.

Figure drawing is also valuable for extending an artist’s practice at any level. If you are beginning with figure work we will provide instruction, demonstrations and feed back to build your skill level.

All materials provided. Life model fees included in your tuition.

Thursday evenings, 6:30 - 8:30 pm.
24 July - 12 September.

events.id: Deva Mahal - The Future Classics Tour-Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Deva Mahal - The Future Classics Tour
events.venue: Meow, 9 Edward St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Deva Mahal is stoked to present her new album Future Classic live to Aotearoa audiences for the first time. Born with the blues in her blood, Deva Mahal blends powerhouse vocals, soul-drenched songwriting, and genre-crossing artistry into a sound uniquely her own. Raised in Hawai’i and musically rooted in New Zealand, she emerged in New York with her debut album RUN DEEP (2018), and has since built an international career spanning sold-out tours, major festivals, and film appearances.

She has graced legendary stages from the Hollywood Bowl and Carnegie Hall to Bonnaroo and the Montreal Jazz Festival, appeared in David O. Russell’s American Hustle, and contributed to the soundtrack of The Experimenter. A three-time APRA Silver Scroll finalist and A2IM Indie Award nominee, and performed at the 2021 Biden-Harris Inauguration. She also featured and wrote on Ledisi’s Grammy-winning THE WILD CARD; contributed vocals to the new Kojey Radical album.

events.id: Forest & Bird Wellington Cryptics & Crosswords-listening to Birds-The Garden Room at St Peter's on Willis, 170 Victoria St, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Forest & Bird Wellington Cryptics & Crosswords-listening to Birds
events.venue: The Garden Room at St Peter's on Willis, 170 Victoria St, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Register now for “Cryptics and cross words: listening to our native birds”

[NB: This event was postponed from 1 May due to very bad weather and high winds].

When: Thursday, 24 July 2025. 7:00 p.m St Peter’s Church Ground Floor Garden Room accessed via a gate on Ghuznee Street behind the Church, or via 170 Victoria Street, Wellington. [Wheelchair accessible].

Ever wonder – Which bird is that calling? How many of them are there?

Hear from Professor Stephen Marsland about a fascinating application of mathematics to understand bird song and his software designed to answer those questions. Twelve or so years ago Stephen decided that sounds -- specifically bird sounds -- could be described as mathematical objects, and therefore could be used for conservation.

Stephen Marsland is a Professor of Mathematics and Data Science at Victoria University of Wellington. This has given him more opportunities than are reasonable, for a mathematician to work with taonga species of Aotearoa New Zealand. It has also led to the AviaNZ software and research programme, which tries to recognise the calls of New Zealand birds, and turn them into estimates of their abundance in an area. The software is freely available for anybody to use.
When not wrangling kiwi and other birds he works on mathematical questions in evolutionary game theory (including why humans cooperate, and why sexual reproduction arose) and infinite dimensional geometry).
Register for catering purposes here at EventFinda.
Agenda
6:30 p.m. Doors Open and Light refreshments served
7:00 p.m. Talk start
8:30 p.m. Wrap-up.

events.id: The Joy of Improvisation-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: The Joy of Improvisation
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
The Joy of Improvisation
Improv is theatre without a script and a fun way to build your skills in many areas, including team work, public speaking, storytelling and on-your-feet creative thinking.
This is the perfect place for absolute beginners to get acquainted with the joy and art of improvisation, inspired by the generous creative philosophy of Keith Johnstone. It's also a great place to get back into improv if you've been away from it for a while.
WIT has been teaching this course in association with the CEC for almost 20 years now. It uses fun games and structured exercises to teach the foundation skills of improv. These are a prerequisite for further courses and membership of WIT (www.wit.org.nz), as well as useful in themselves.
If you have questions about the course, please contact WIT directly on info@wit.org.nz.
By the end of the course, you'll have: 
• Explored basic principles of improvisation
• Enjoyed interacting in a friendly, positive and supportive environment
• Developed more confidence, presentation and communication skills
• Experienced joyful moments of improvisation
The course will end with a directed demonstration of class exercises for invited friends and family.
[This is a physical activity that involves an element of risk.  While all possible measures are taken to prevent accidents or injury, please note that participation is at your own risk].

events.id: The Royal New Zealand Ballet - Home, Land and Sea-St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: The Royal New Zealand Ballet - Home, Land and Sea
events.venue: St James Theatre, 77-87 Courtenay Place, Wellington
events.description:
Home, Land and Sea presents three ballets inspired by journeys in unknown seas, and what it means to come home.

Moss Te Ururangi Patterson’s new work, Home, Land and Sea, created for six dancers from the RNZB and six from The New Zealand Dance Company.

Moss’s work weaves the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand with historical echoes of Cook’s Endeavour voyages. Drawing inspiration from early European perceptions of this land, Moss integrates the haunting melodies of taonga pūoro—traditional Māori instruments—into a dynamic and poetic performance. Audiences are invited to embark on a reflective journey through time, exploring how shared history shapes present and influences our path forward.

Shaun James Kelly will create a new work titled Chrysalis, inspired by his metamorphosis from young dancer in Scotland to Soloist and Choreographer in Residence in New Zealand.

Stephen Baynes’s The Way Alone A deeply personal response to music by Tchaikovsky completes the programme.

events.id: Anthony Donaldson - Master Drummer - Night 1-Pyramid Club, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Anthony Donaldson - Master Drummer - Night 1
events.venue: Pyramid Club, Wellington
events.description:
Anthony Donaldson is one of this country's great drummers a pioneer of improvised music in Aotearoa. A visual artist before becoming a musician, Anthony's starting point on the drums was in finding tonal colours, rhythms that come from nature, and constructing a drum kit that grew like a living sculpture, Beginning in the late 70s and early 80s with Primitive Art Group, his music making has always centred on free improvisation and collective composition. His musical journey has seen him perform with countless ensembles, often of his own creation, including the Black Sheep, Six Volts, Razorblades, Mean Bones, Flower Orphans, Teeth, Devils Gate Outfit, Rubbernecks, Farewell Spit, Melancholy Babes and the Stinging Nettles. He has been a creative force in Wellington music for over four decades and continues to push the boundaries of accepted musical norms, while encouraging and mentoring younger players.

Pyramid Club is very happy to host Anthony for two nights, performing solo and in collaboration with a large number of outstanding musicians. Gifted with a sparkling musical imagination, alongside his drum kit Anthony will be performing with electronics, 78rpm phonograph player, assorted percussion and spoken word.

For the first of his two night performance residency Anthony will be performing solo and in collaboration with:
trio with Nell Thomas (electronics) / David Long (guitar)

events.id: Lung Cancers in Palliative Care Workshop-331 Suffolk Road Nelson, Nelson 7011-Event Brite
events.name: Lung Cancers in Palliative Care Workshop
events.venue: 331 Suffolk Road Nelson, Nelson 7011
events.description:
In New Zealand, lung cancer causes more deaths than any other cancer, more than breast, prostate and melanoma combined. More than 1800 New Zealanders die from lung cancer each year. The reason that lung cancer has such a high mortality is that 74% of the patients present with advanced lung cancer on initial diagnosis (Cancer Research Trust , NZ).

Symptoms of lung cancer are varied and supporting people with advanced disease requires a holistic approach.

This workshop will look at
Understanding lung cancers and treatment options
Best practice symptom management
Understanding stigma and the social and family/ whānau implications

Presenters:
Toni Phair Community Clinical Nurse Specialist - Respiratory, Health New Zealand Te Whatu Ora
Cath Christmas Oncology Cancer Nurse Coordinator Toni Phair Community Clinical Nurse Specialist - Respiratory, Health New Zealand Te Whatu Ora
Chris Dunn Nurse Educator Palliative Care Nelson Tasman Hospice
Annie Wallace Clinical Nurse Specialist Nelson Tasman Hospice
Facilitated by Nelson Tasman Hospice
Date: Friday 25 July 2025
Time: 0900 - 1500 hrs.
Cost: $80.00 (incl. GST per person) Lunch is not supplied. Please bring your own lunch or you can purchase from our cafe onsite. (Tea, coffee and a light morning tea will be provided).
Target audience: Health Care Professionals in all settings
Limited attendees: Registration is essential
For further information contact the Nelson Tasman Hospice Education Team:
P: (03) 546 3950
E: Barb Thomas Education Administrator: education@nelsonhospice.org.nz

events.venue: Tirohana Estate Vineyard, 42 Puruatanga Rd, Martinborough
events.description:
As the year reaches the half-way point, what better way to keep warm this winter and celebrate with friends and family than by booking a table at Tirohana's Mid-Winter Christmas themed nights (and days) to be held over lunch and dinner over two weekends (June 27-29 and July 25-27).

An annual tradition in Martinborough and the Wairarapa, Tirohana Cellars' Restaurant will be transformed into a magical Christmas winter wonderland, with twinkling fairy lights, mulled wine, Christmas trees, evocative music, the warmth of the open fire - and who knows, we might even get some snow in the vineyard!? :)

There is a festive menu where Christmas turkey and all the trimmings will be on offer (with options for vegetarians/special diets). But there are plenty of other options on the menu available for those who do not want to indulge in Turkey and ham off the bone, plum pudding and other favourites.

Lunch is three courses (starter, main, dessert) for $65 pp and Dinner is $75 pp for five courses (amuse bouche, starter, main, dessert, petit fours)

A wonderful lunch or dinner for a couple or a group, this Tirohana institution is something you won't want to miss. If you're feeling particularly festive, why not dress to suit the occasion - we'll be running a competition on our Facebook page for the best Midwinter photo.

Reservations are essential to secure a table for lunch or dinner.

To book a table please call 06 306 9933 or email makeabooking@tirohanaestate.com or book online https://www.tirohanaestate.com/restaurant/book-a-table/.

events.id: Karetao Wānanga-1 Fell Street Blenheim, Marlborough 7202-Event Brite
events.name: Karetao Wānanga
events.venue: 1 Fell Street Blenheim, Marlborough 7202
events.description:
We are honoured to welcome esteemed cultural practitioners James Webster, Hinemoa Jones, Rikki Solomon, Whetu Silver and Horomona Horo, who will share their immense mātauranga. Karetao are an integral part of Māori culture, despite limited documentation. During the revival of Taonga Pūoro, led by the late Dr. Hirini Melbourne, discussions highlighted the synergy between karetao and Taonga Pūoro. This collaboration enriches the performance and expression of Māori culture, weaving together sound, music, spirit, and storytelling.This wānanga includes a special performance on Friday evening, followed by weekend workshops focused on the creation of karetao.
This event is open to all whānau and community members — from tamariki to kaumātua.
Registrations are essential Cost: $50 per person (all ages)
PĀNUI
Registrations are accepted on a first come, first served basis. Unfortunately, we are unable to reserve or hold places in advance.
Refunds are not available. Your registration fee covers kai, wānanga content, and all materials provided for you to take home.
Accommodation is limited. If you require a noho (overnight stay), please contact us after confirming your registration for the wānanga to secure a spot.
This wānanga is a collaboration between Rangitāne o Wairau and Ngā Pakiaka Mōrehu o te Whenua, facilitated by Nell Kelly.

events.id: Beneath the Surface - Somatic Dance-293 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Beneath the Surface - Somatic Dance
events.venue: 293 Cuba Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
BENEATH THE SURFACE
A somatic dance journey
Join embodiment facilitators Jenna Joan & Sonic Sutra for a cosy, new moon gathering of ceremonial cacao, freeform movement, and live soundscape.
🌑 Friday 25 July
🕕 6–8pm
📍 Thistle Hall Community Venue
🎟️ $35–$45
✨ Sober · Non-judgemental · All welcome · No experience needed
Take a quiet winter evening to slow down, soften your body, and reconnect to your inner world...

Beneath the Surface is a warm, intimate space to move, breathe, and listen deeply to your body—just as it is.
We’ll begin with ceremonial cacao, then drop into a guided movement journey with a live soundscape. There are no steps to learn, no performance—just presence, curiosity, and letting your body do the talking. Barefoot and phone-free, you’re invited to move as you feel—awakening warmth, inner truth, and expression.
Come as you are.
Move as you feel.
Leave feeling more connected, warm, and alive.
Somatic dance is a guided movement practice that helps you tune into your body’s wisdom and move from the inside out. Unlike ecstatic dance, which is typically an open, DJ-led space with no facilitation, somatic dance offers gentle guidance to support you in exploring sensation, emotion, and embodiment in a safe, intentional way. You’re not learning steps or performing—you're being invited into presence, curiosity, and feeling. With a focus on nervous system regulation, personal expression, and inner listening, somatic dance creates a nurturing space to come home to yourself.
Your Hosts...
Jenna Joan | Embodiment Facilitator
Jenna Joan is a somatic therapist, yoga teacher, and group facilitator who has been leading movement spaces for over 15 years. With a background in yoga, somatic dance, and therapeutic embodiment, her work blends play, authenticity, and deep nervous system awareness. Jenna is also a cacao alchemist and ceremonial facilitator, known for creating safe, soulful spaces that invite freedom, connection, and inner exploration. She has been hosting workshops, retreats, and community events for nearly a decade, and also works 1:1 in more therapeutic settings.
Sonic Sutra | Somatic Dance DJ
Sonic Sutra is a sound artist and somatic dance DJ who creates immersive musical journeys designed to support authentic movement, emotional release, and deep embodiment. With a focus on somatic dance and therapeutic soundscapes, their sets are intentionally curated to guide dancers through an inner experience—honouring the body’s natural rhythms and the intelligence within. Their offerings create safe, accessible spaces for people of all bodies, backgrounds, and experience levels to explore movement, presence, and connection. Rooted in play, precision, and deep listening, Sonic Sutra brings music that moves beyond entertainment—into healing and transformation.

events.id: French Film Screening - Petit Pays-78 Victoria Street Level 3 Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
events.name: French Film Screening - Petit Pays
events.venue: 78 Victoria Street Level 3 Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.description:
🎬 Join us for a screening of Petit Pays (Small Country: An African Childhood) – a powerful and deeply moving French drama that explores childhood, identity, and the impact of conflict through the eyes of a young boy growing up in Burundi in the early 1990s.
The plot 👉 Petit Pays tells the story of Gabriel, a 10-year-old boy living a carefree life in a quiet neighborhood of Bujumbura with his French father and Rwandan mother. But as tensions rise in the region and civil war looms, Gabriel’s world begins to unravel, forcing him to confront the complexities of his heritage and the harsh realities of a fractured society.
The trailer 👉 youtube.com/watch?v=FZL-NLhmBsU
Adapted from Gaël Faye’s acclaimed novel, Petit Pays is a poignant film, rich in storytelling and emotional depth.
This film is rated R16 - The film is only for viewers aged 16 and over (Violence, cruelty, offensive language & content that may disturb).
📅 Friday, 25 July 2025 - 6pm
📍 Alliance Française, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎥 French VO with English Subtitles
🎟️ Free entry, Koha donation
🍷 $8 for members | $10 for non-members to include a glass of wine

events.venue: Abandoned Taproom Petone, 38 Fitzherbert St, Petone, Lower Hutt
events.description:
The Eastern are a string band that roars like a punk band, that swings like a gospel band, that drinks like a country band, that works like a bar band, that hopes like folk singers, and sings love songs like union songs, and writes union songs like love songs, and wants to slow dance and stand on tables, all at the same time. Four albums and well over 1000 shows deep The Eastern have played and toured with Fleetwood Mac, Steve Earle
and Old Crow Medicine Show amongst others, ticking off miles, countries and new friends and fans wherever they get to roaming.

‘No Depression’ magazine noted they were “One of the best modern roots acts, from any country”. Both Radio NZ and the NZ Herald described them as “National Treasures” and The Heralds Graham Reid called singer Adam McGrath “NZ’s toughest minded songwriter”. NZ country legend Barry Saunders simply called
them “The Truth.”

Built around the songs of 2024 New Zealand Music Award’s folk artist of the year Adam McGrath and Banjo
legend Jess Shanks, The Eastern continue to prove they are a band of brothers and sisters you can’t help but
believe in.

events.venue: Underworld, Valhalla, Wellington
events.description:
An evening of music for the restless, romantic, and rebellious.

Radar Angel are a four-piece synthfoolery ensemble who blend industrial grit with lush nostalgic sounds from the dawn of the digital age, all with a lavish theatricality and pop sensibility that is guaranteed to get your limbs thrashing.

The Blue Summer are a five-piece surrounding themselves with wisps of funk, post punk, alternative rock, and pop. Like a wave crashing upon the rocks, chaotic and multi-faceted, only to pull back exposing the calm of the depths below. Gracefully twisting and changing shape from ballads to bangers.

Featuring members of Murgatroyd and Opium Eater, Sighthound comes from a pedigree of noise makers. Blending trip hop, lush atmospheres and harsh noise, Sighthound promise a truly unique experience from two proficient maniacs.

Tickets: $10 + booking fee through UTR
$15 on door.

events.id: Anthony Donaldson - Master Drummer - Night 2-Pyramid Club, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Anthony Donaldson - Master Drummer - Night 2
events.venue: Pyramid Club, Wellington
events.description:
Anthony Donaldson is one of this country's great drummers a pioneer of improvised music in Aotearoa. A visual artist before becoming a musician, Anthony's starting point on the drums was in finding tonal colours, rhythms that come from nature, and constructing a drum kit that grew like a living sculpture, Beginning in the late 70s and early 80s with Primitive Art Group, his music making has always centred on free improvisation and collective composition. His musical journey has seen him perform with countless ensembles, often of his own creation, including the Black Sheep, Six Volts, Razorblades, Mean Bones, Flower Orphans, Teeth, Devils Gate Outfit, Rubbernecks, Farewell Spit, Melancholy Babes and the Stinging Nettles. He has been a creative force in Wellington music for over four decades and continues to push the boundaries of accepted musical norms, while encouraging and mentoring younger players.

Pyramid Club is very happy to host Anthony for two nights, performing solo and in collaboration with a large number of outstanding musicians. Gifted with a sparkling musical imagination, alongside his drum kit Anthony will be performing with electronics, 78rpm phonograph player, assorted percussion and spoken word.

The the second of his two night performance residency, Anthony will be performing in collaboration with:
duo with Riki Gooch (percussion/taonga pūoro/electronics)
duo with Alphabethead (turntables)
quartet with Bridget Kelly (reeds) / Toby Laing (trumpet/keys) / Tom Callwood (bass)

Listen here to a recent Dancing in Your Head podcast featuring Anthony playing some of his own music and tracks which he's been listening to.

And to his feature on RNZ's Mixtape a few years back

- - - - - - - -

Presale tickets for Night 2 $20
Presales for a two-night pass $30

events.id: Princess Chelsea's Midwinter Ball-Meow Nui, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Princess Chelsea's Midwinter Ball
events.venue: Meow Nui, Wellington
events.description:
PRINCESS CHELSEA’S MIDWINTER BALL
SWORDS AND SORCERY - Fantasy on The Big Screen
with your host TOM SAINSBURY

SATURDAY 19 JULY - WINTERGARDEN, THE CIVIC, AUCKLAND (ALL AGES) *
SATURDAY 26 JULY - MEOW NUI, WELLINGTON **

With special guests THE CIRCLING SUN & GOLDEN AXE *
GRECCO ROMANK & LUKE BUDA **

‘The Wintergarden will host many, many more incredible events, but it will never host something like the mesmerising Princess Chelsea and Twin Peaks crossover again’ - Rolling Stone

This winter, the Civic Wintergarden (ALL AGES) and Meow Nui (18+) Wellington will be transformed into a world of fantasy! Princess Chelsea’s Midwinter Ball returns, this year with a new theme: SWORDS AND SORCERY - Fantasy on The Big Screen. With your esteemed host comedian Tom Sainsbury, and live performances from Princess Chelsea & The Dream Warriors in both centres, with Auckland guests The Circling Sun & Golden Axe, while Wellington will be treated to sets from Grecco Romank & Luke Buda.

In the shimmering and VHS-heavy age of the early 1980s, a treasure trove of cinematic fantasy was thrust upon us. Gleaming swords and potent spells in Excalibur, the ethereal beauty and terror of Legend, valiant quests of The Sword and The Sorcerer, Ladyhawke, The Beastmaster, Willow, Dragonslayer, and the mighty & muscular quests of Conan The Barbarian. And let us not forget the timeless enchantments of pure fantasy with The Neverending Story, the delightful Princess Bride, the poignant Last Unicorn, and the unforgettable shape of Labyrinth.

So, brave adventurers, will you join us to celebrate this golden age? How will you dress to impress as visions of enchanted lands and heroic feats conjure a costume fit for fantasy?

Called by many as ‘the show of 2024’, last year’s Twin Peaks themed Midwinter Ball was a revelation, and a dress up party for the ages. A sold out Wintergarden heaved with 650 guests dressed as Log Ladies, Agent Dale Coopers, and even a giant slice of cherry pie… and oh, so much more.

Princess Chelsea and her band The Dream Warriors delighted the audience with a blazing set of originals alongside covers of Julee Cruise, Angelo Badalamenti and In Heaven from Lynch’s Eraserhead. This wild and unforgettable night has been lovingly captured and presented as a four song tribute to David Lynch, due for imminent release.
For 2024’s Twin Peaks-themed ball, no expenses were spared on transforming the venue into the quaint town of Twin Peaks. Decoration which featured lasers, an indoor pine forest, a shrine to Laura Palmer and a replica of the infamous Red Room, we can only expect magic and mystery from 2025’s fantasy- themed ball.

“I’m not giving too much away but obviously we will need a medieval sword fight” - Princess Chelsea

If last year’s ball was anything to go by, I don't think she is joking - and further shenanigans will undoubtedly ensue. Expect the Civic and Meow Nui to be transformed into a world of fantasy.

Earlybird tickets are on sale Friday at 10am. Book your evening, and swan down the red carpet dressed in your favourite fantasy-inspired outfits. Portraits will be taken on the night, and prizes for best dressed.

events.id: Crime Writing - An Introduction-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Crime Writing - An Introduction
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Crime Writing - An Introduction
This course is designed to introduce new writers (and more experienced writers) to the world of crime writing. You will be looking at writing basics, crime genres, characters, story construction, research, plotting and story arcs, outlining (yay or nay), heroes and villains and finish with log lines and synopsis writing, among other things.
This is an intense but fun course designed and taught by Cat Connor who teaches writing via Writers Plot Bookshop and is also an internationally published crime writer of multiple books.
The objective is to encourage and support you by imparting knowledge that you can apply going forward and find real enjoyment in writing crime (or whatever you go on to write).
Bring notebook and pens.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Create an outline for a crime novel or short story.
Construct characters’ maps and believable characters.
Demonstrate and recognize active and passive writing.
Develop sound and robust research techniques.
Use plot diagrams to enhance an outline.
Construct loglines, taglines, and blurbs.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. events.id: Get the Job: STARR Interview Technique and Preparation-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Get the Job: STARR Interview Technique and Preparation
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Get the Job: STARR Interview Technique and Preparation
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Meet the demand for excellence in the job market head on. Learn how to utilise the STARR technique in the way that recruiters use it. That is, to define and seek out the skills and qualities of the best candidate. Master the STARR skills and feel confident in your next job interview.

Familarise yourself with the skills needed to ace your next interview. Learn the STARR method as an approach to responding to behavioural based questions. Understand how to use concrete examples from your life as proof that you possess the experience and skills for the job you are applying for. You’ll develop the key interview skill of being able to share your accomplishments through real-life examples.

In this course, you are taught how to identify specific example situations that are unique to you. You’ll learn how to confidently talk about the tasks involved and describe how you completed the key task and met its challenges. We’ll also consider the context of jobs you are interviewing for and how to choose examples that best show the desired skills interviewers are seeking.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Develop a higher level of confidence in approaching job interviews.
- Identify the different components of the STARR acronym and apply them to the job interview context.
- Identify what behavioural based questions are and why recruiters use them.
- Successfully answer behavioural based interview questions by applying the STARR technique.
- Develop skills in using real life examples to show transferable skills in the workplace.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.name: Jewellery Making - Soldered Fidget Rings
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Jewellery Making - Soldered Fidget Rings
In this one-day workshop you are offered a hands-on opportunity to create custom rings with fun mobile components and unique textures. We'll also practice and build experience in the essential jeweller’s fabrication skills of sawing, filing, soldering, sanding and polishing.
What are fidget rings? Also known as spinner rings or stim rings, fidget rings have loose bands attached that can move and swivel around - it's interactive sculpture you can wear!
In this course you’ll be lead through the design and creation of custom copper and silver rings, with copper, brass and silver wire spinner bands adding novelty and movement to a classic ring design.
 This course offers beginners a fun introduction to jewellery making, and for those with some jewellery experience, it offers a great way to advance and expand your making techniques to new levels.
All materials included in course fee.
Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby.  Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. events.name: Knitting for Beginners
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Knitting for Beginners
Come and reap the benefits of a mindful and meditative craft-form.  Meet other people interested in making things with their hands, chat over crafting and find out what the craft craze is all about.
Join crafter Stella Carruthers as she shares her ten years plus knitting experience in this beginner’s knitting class that supports each student as an individual learner.
Master basic knitting techniques, learn how to cast stitches on and off the needles, explore the knit and purl stitches and practice how to hold the needles in a way that is comfortable for you - then learn how to knit in the English style.
Knitting needles and yarn are included in the course fee, but you're welcome to bring along your own 4-ply yarn if you wish. 
By the end of the course you will have created two squares of knitting, one in basic garter stitch and the other utilising both knit and purl stitches to create the knitted fabric called stocking stitch.

events.name: Mindful Awareness Workshop
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Mindful Awareness – One-Day Workshop
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $149 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
 “If we don’t know what we’re doing, how can we do what we want?”
 A hands-on, one-day workshop blending mindfulness, neuroscience, and self-awareness to help you feel better, relate better, and live with more clarity and purpose.
 What you’ll get:
Simple tools to soothe stress and calm your system
Strategies to respond wisely instead of reacting on autopilot
Insight into your feelings, needs and inner patterns
Cutting-edge knowledge of the Vagus nerve and how it shapes your wellbeing
An intro to Parts Work: understand the different parts of you and how they work together
Practical ways to build creativity, clarity and genuine connection
Skills to feel stronger in yourself, your relationships and your work life
Everyday tools for better health, resilience and emotional balance
 Real tools. Real change. Backed by science, grounded in practice.
 Tea and coffee provided, please bring your lunch and snacks, and pen and paper to take notes.
 Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Leadlight Glass Suncatcher Day-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Leadlight Glass Suncatcher Day
events.venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
events.description:
Create gorgeous simple leadlight suncatchers with Lisa Sinclair.

A super fun day-class, ideal as a stand-alone experience, or as a day to get stuck into projects with your tutor at hand.

Beginners choose from a range of achievable patterns and choose their colour palette. They will learn to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant colourful glass project.

The aim of this one day class is to leave with a completed small leadlight glass item.

More experienced students may bring existing projects to work on in class - though emphasis will be placed on focusing on the same techniques of flat, nicely soldered simple designs.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

Your materials for your beginner project are supplied as part of your course fee.
Additional materials and tools are available to purchase.

Not suitable for children. Older teenagers (16+) are welcome.

events.id: Offline Aotearoa!-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Offline Aotearoa!
events.venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
This fun, one day session builds upon a simple thought experiment: Aotearoa wakes up one day disconnected from the Internet, and the rest of the world. However, local infrastructure, from cell towers, to datacentres and fibre networks, remain unscathed. What could (or couldn't) we do with what we have? What of our current network and communications infrastructure, and all our most used sites and services, would function when we’re ‘cut off’ from the rest of civilisation?
  Join us in a playful lab environment helping build the first ‘map’ of what our digital experience would look like if it was just us - from healthcare, to education, banking and the big socials. In doing so, we’ll get a sense of just how infrastructurally independent – and resilient — we are as a nation.
  Participants will learn how to use simple network probing and website analysis to pull websites and networks apart, looking under the hood at just how much is hosted overseas.
  This is a team effort, with no prior knowledge required. Participants should bring a laptop.

events.id: Ōtari Raranga Weavers 2025 Post Matariki Season - Beginners-Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Ōtari Raranga Weavers 2025 Post Matariki Season - Beginners
events.venue: Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush, 160 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington
events.description:
Kua raranga tahi tātou he whariki mō āpōpō
Together we weave the mat for future generations

Nau mai haere mai, all are welcome to attend Ōtari Raranga wānanga (classes).

No experience required and all materials provided. You will walk away with woven taonga at the end of every class.

Over 3-4 classes beginner students should complete a variety of putiputi (flowers), a kōnae (2 corner kete - basket), and a kono (4 sided kete). After completing 4 beginner classes (close together) you may have the skills to move up to our intermediate classes. Please talk with our kaiako and kaiāwhina if this is something you aspire to.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)
- Have the skills to practice at home.

What’s included in your beginners ticket?
- Three hour weaving class with experienced kaiako
- Access to tools and harakeke
- Harakeke is provided for your first two classes and then the tikanga is that you should hauhake (harvest) for yourself.
- If you are unable to harvest for class, we have a $20 ‘Please harvest for me’ option in addition to your ticket at least two days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu), and on occasion our raranga rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua), with support from our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngati Kahungunu, Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia
- At our discretion tickets are fully refundable or transferable
- For tikanga purposes beginner ticket sales close two days before wānanga giving us time to hauhake (harvest) for you
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class
- We offer concession tickets for students, unwaged, seniors, and those with disabilities.
- It is important to us that our classes are accessible to all. If ticket costs are a barrier for you please visit our website to enquire about our reduced cost or free tickets
- We welcome children aged 10-14 but they should be accompanied by an adult with a ticket

Follow us on Facebook or Instagram: Otari Raranga Weavers
For more information about what to expect and what to bring visit our www.otariraranga.co.nz

We mihi to our funders and sponsors Wellington City Council, Wellington Gardens and the Ōtari-Wilton Bush Kaitiaki, Maverick Creative, Good Fortune Coffee and Wellington Apothecary.

Spend your Saturday with fellow creatives at Leah Jane's "Entrepreneurial Skills for Artists" workshop! Let's chat about the skills and experience you need in your self-producing toolkit to bring sustainability, intention and agency to your creative practice.

In this workshop we will be discussing:


Fundraising and financing

Project planning and scheduling

Marketing and brand-building

Value mapping and community building

Pitching yourself and your work

And more!


Leah Jane will be bringing her experience as an independent artist, arts administrator and producer, as well as the knowledge she gained in her two-year Masters of Arts Management and Entrepreneurship (from the New School, New York City). This workshop will be interactive and relaxed so bring yourself, your creative collaborators, and materials to write with. There will be opportunities to network and chat with other creatives, snacks and coffee, and a chance to ask all your burning questions.

$35 full price
$25 concession
$10 current students

All ticket proceeds will be going towards the costs of the event, koha for guests and Leah's fundraising efforts for her next New York adventure.

events.id: After Austen: Em-2/57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: After Austen: Em
events.venue: 2/57 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
We are so excited to welcome award-winning playwright Sam Brooks, to discuss his play Em, a queer retelling of Jane Austen’s masterwork Emma, turned around, flipped and set in our very own Queenstown.
Emmett Woodhouse, handsome, clever and rich, with a comfortable home and a gay disposition has lived nearly [redacted] years in the world with very little to distress or vex him.

Until now.
Em won the Dean Parker Adaptation Award at the 2023 Adam New Zealand Play Awards.
Attendees get an exclusive 10% discount at Unity Books
Bring a friend: purchase 2 or more tickets and get a 10% discount
Sam Brooks is an award-winning and prolific playwright and journalist, who is largely noted for his critically acclaimed LGBTQ+ work, including Riding in Cars with (Mostly Straight) Boys, Queen, and most recently This is My Story of Us, which was co-winner of the 2024 Adam New Zealand Play Award. He won the Bruce Mason Playwright's Award, New Zealand's most prestigious award for playwrights. In 2018 his political work, Burn Her, was performed as part of Q's Matchbox Season and won the Auckland Theatre Excellence Award for Best Overall Production. He has been shortlisted multiple years for the Adam New Zealand Play Award, and won the Dean Parker award in 2023.
As a journalist, he has written for The Spinoff and has had bylines at the Pantrograph Punch, Metro and the NZ Herald.
Who this event is for:
People who love Austen
People who love the theatre
Fans of Sam's work
Writers
Actors
Directors
Afternoon tea provided
(If you have issues paying via credit card you can pay via invoice or contact us - this should be fixed now)
FAQs
Do I need to know about Jane Austen?
No. Everyone is welcome.
Do I need to see the play first?
It hasn't been staged (yet) so I'd be surprised if you had!
Do I need to be a member of the society?
We don't technically have membership, if you turn up we think of you as a member.
I have accessibility or dietary requirements
We aim to meet at venues that are accessible and provide for all dietary requirements. Please check out the accessibility section or contact us if you're unsure. We want you to be there and we want you to be comfortable.
What are the meetings like?
We meet at two/fiftyseven which is accessed via lift. There is a talk, a break with afternoon tea, then we come back together for questions. You can choose to engage with others, or not. We're happy to assign you a buddy for your first meeting too.

events.id: Book Launch: Lofty – The Short Life of Lieutenant Frank Long DFC-Hedleys Bookshop, 150 Queen St, Masterton-Event Finder
events.name: Book Launch: Lofty – The Short Life of Lieutenant Frank Long DFC
events.venue: Hedleys Bookshop, 150 Queen St, Masterton
events.description:
Rick Long invites you to the launch of Lofty: The Short Life of Flight Lieutenant Frank Long DFC, the story of a wartime hero from Masterton, written by local historian, Neil Frances.

In December 1937, 21 year old Masterton man Frank Long joined the Royal Air Force and was flying Whitley Bombers over Nazi Germany shortly after.

For 18 months Frank took part in the RAF’s early bombing campaign against Germany – a time of trial and many errors as the British Empire fought with its back to the wall against an aggressive and triumphant foe.

Drawing on family records, letters and photographs, and a wide range of wartime and official records, author and military historian Neil Frances brings a decorated Masterton pilot to life 80 years after his death in action.

The launch will include a short talk and be followed by a book signing with Rick Long and Neil Frances. The book, Lofty, will be available to purchase on the day.

All are welcome at this free celebratory event, but please RSVP to Hedley’s Books, Masterton on sales@hedleysbooks.co.nz, 06 378 2875 or text 027 281 6421

events.id: Christmas Carnival Grand Finale - thanks to SWDC-Greytown Town Hall, 89 Main St, Greytown-Event Finder
events.name: Christmas Carnival Grand Finale - thanks to SWDC
events.venue: Greytown Town Hall, 89 Main St, Greytown
events.description:
The action kicks off from 3pm for the Grand Finale of Aotearoa’s happiest mid-winter festival. We’re closing off Main Street so you can wander freely, soak up the last flutterings of snow, explore the Night Markets, and eat, drink, and be merry.
When evening falls, get ready for an unforgettable street party and Carnival parade – Wairarapa style! Watch the performers dance past – or if you're feeling inspired, jump in behind them and get your groove on!

Then, to cap off the month of magic, we’re ending with a bang – fireworks will light up the sky at 7:45pm, launching from the Greytown School grounds, making Main St a perfect viewing spot.

It's also your last chance to take advantage of festival deals and offers at our gorgeous boutique stores, and admire their stunning displays. Many will be open late for evening shopping. If you haven't already, make sure you decorate your Hari pup and hang it proudly on the Greytown Lands Trust Community Christmas Tree! Or head along and admire the children's artwork.

So come and celebrate with us, raise a glass of mulled wine (or a hot chocolate) by one of the open fires or outdoor heaters, and toast the end of the 2025 Festival of Christmas.
And the best part? It’s completely free!

Please Note:
The Wairarapa Festival of Christmas features flashing lights and light projections that may affect those with light sensitivity. We love dogs - especially Hari - but please leave them safe at home during busy times. Please listen carefully to our friendly traffic marshals and stay within the designated safe zones.

Representing New Zealand is both an honour and a challenge, and with your support, she’ll be able to take her grit and determination overseas to compete among the world’s elite.

This fundraiser helps cover travel, gear, registration, and associated costs. Every ticket purchased and every drop of sweat brings Amanda one step closer to that start line in Sweden.

Let’s move for a mission. Let’s dance for determination. Let’s help Amanda represent NZ with pride!
Follow the journey on Instagram: @welly2worldsocr

- Explore your pleasure palette, from stunning body art to the latest in intimate gadgets
- Meet talented tattoo artists and get inspired by their creations.
- Discover, shop, and play with products that bring your vibe to life
