events.id: Cheesemaking - Brie and Queso Fresco-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Cheesemaking - Brie and Queso Fresco
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Cheesemaking - Brie and Queso Fresco
The ultimate class in practical cheese making!   Learn all you need to know to replicate making NZ style Brie and Queso Fresco at home.  You will be guided through each step of the cheesemaking process while making your very own round of Brie. Then, while the Brie is ripening and setting (don't worry, all terminology will be explained!), we will make Queso Fresco together.  
All ingredients are provided as are recipes and detailed handouts to take away with you. Bring an apron, a dishcloth, 3 or 4 tea towels, a pen to take notes and a 2 litre container and plastic re-sealable food bags to take your cheese home.
During the workshop, the following topics will also be covered: Milk and where to source it, hygiene and sanitation, equipment required and the origins of the cheeses you are about to make.  You will also receive comprehensive instruction on how to mature your Brie cheese over the next few weeks.
A small break will be provided and you will have the opportunity to purchase equipment and cheesemaking ingredients after the workshop should you wish to replicate the experience at home.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-  Make Brie and Queso Fresco
- Recall the best milk to use and where to source it from
- Name and identify what equipment and ingredients you need to make Brie and Queso Fresco
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Get the Job: CV and Cover Letters-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Get the Job: CV and Cover Letters
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Get the Job: CV and Cover Letters
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Explore how to appropriately structure and polish your CV and cover letter in order to achieve optimum results. This course prioritises you. Identify your key skills and weave these into your CV and cover letter to land you your next job interview.
 Whatever job you are going for, there are key characteristics that should not be missed in your CV and cover letter. The focus of this course is to provide you with the same lens as a recruiter. By learning how your job application is reviewed by a recruiter, you will gain skills to streamline your CV, and improve your cover letter writing. This will increase your chances of being a successful candidate and sets you up to land an interview for your ideal job.
 It doesn’t matter what previous experience you have - everyone has a range of skills that they can offer to their future employer. Fortunately, a strong and realistic CV and cover letter will showcase these skills and increase your chances for job success.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Recognise the features of an effective, well-crafted CV and cover letter and apply these to your own job applications;
- Apply different approaches, styles and techniques while writing your CV and cover letter depending on the context and job;
- Help others with their CV and cover letter writing (friends and whānau).
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
 Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Overcoming Imposter Syndrome for Creatives-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Overcoming Imposter Syndrome for Creatives
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Overcoming Imposter Syndrome for Creatives
There is a widespread ‘lack of confidence’ epidemic among creatives, and if you have ever felt like your work is not good enough, hesitated to submit your art to competitions, or doubted your skills when applying for creative jobs, you are not alone! Creatives often feel imposter syndrome most acutely. Unlike other industries, those in the creative field produce something new every time, and sharing this with the world can be daunting, even for established artists.
 This pervasive self-doubt, known as imposter syndrome, affects countless artists and creators, often holding them back from realising their full potential. This concise workshop is designed to help you uncover the roots of this inner voice of insecurity and provide you with effective tools to overcome it. Through engaging activities and practical exercises, you will learn how to transform self-doubt into a source of strength, empowering you to confidently share your unique talents with the world.
 What you won't find in this masterclass: This is not a session about general self-growth or self-confidence, and it does not include positive affirmations or self-talk. All the information provided is based on scientific research and is applicable to all creative sectors.
Bring along some examples of your work on the day (eg a painting, a photograph of your work, etc).
 By the end of this workshop, you’ll be able to: 
Identify and challenge the origins of your imposter syndrome.
Apply practical techniques to silence your inner critic.
Share your creative work with increased confidence.
Turn self-doubt into a motivational tool.
Recognise and celebrate your achievements as a creative professional.
Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Pelvic Power Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Pelvic Power Workshop
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Pelvic Power Workshop
Apart from assisting with supporting internal organs, and controlling elimination, the pelvic floor is an important part of a woman's overall stability and posture, so you will gain improvement in this respect as well. You'll learn far more than conventional pelvic floor strengthening. 
You'll learn to differentiate different parts of the pelvic floor, and also how the pelvic floor functions in conjunction with breathing and spinal movements.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
• Recognise the anatomy of the pelvic floor, where the muscles are and how they work
• Coordinate the pelvic floor muscles with breathing, and with the spine, and recognise its role in overall good posture
• Discover what habits you have which work against your pelvic floor muscles working well
• Practise exercises designed to help you rehabilitate and strengthen your pelvic floor
Please note that instructions are given verbally rather than by demonstration, so good hearing and understanding of English is required. For women only.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Psychology of Money Management-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Psychology of Money Management
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Psychology of Money Management
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $199 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Managing finances should be empowering and enjoyable, yet traditional methods often make money a stressful, taboo topic—even with your closest loved ones. In this workshop, we're not here to tell you to cut your budget or skip your favourite treats. Instead, we’ll come together to design a financial plan tailored to your unique needs, making you feel confident, excited, and in control.
In this workshop, you’ll explore the psychology of money and how it influences your financial decisions. Through real-life case studies, step-by-step guidance, and collaborative exercises, you’ll design a financial system that suits your lifestyle, reduces stress, and helps you achieve your goals.
If you want to simplify your finances and live without the worry of every dollar spent, then this is the workshop for you!
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
Disclaimer:  The tutor is not a financial advisor. No investments, products nor specific recommendations will be provided.  A step-by-step planning process will be taught by working through a case study.   Any product names or websites used in examples and explanations to help participants understand financial concepts and the planning process are used for clarity only. They are not given as any type of recommendation.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Retirement Reinvented-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Retirement Reinvented
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Retirement Reinvented
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
In your middle years, working, retired or somewhere in between? What’s next? Life is about much more than work or leisure, but most of us have given little thought to what “retirement” might mean.
It’s difficult to speculate what may happen in the future – but we can be proactive and take control.
This course offers insights into how to make the most of our time once we’re less focused on career and/or childrearing. It covers many of the issues people face when considering a move from current employment to a different lifestyle that includes more time to do the things we’ve always promised ourselves we’d do – “when we retire”.
After the workshop, you’ll be able to identify a number of common issues and potential ways to manage them when considering and planning your “rejuvenation”, rather than a retirement. We won’t cover financial planning, but will focus on some of the personal growth opportunities for living and making a conscious contribution to your community.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
By the end of the day, you’ll have:
Developed your own perspective on ageing and retirement in the 21st Century and identified what’s important to you
Completed a personal life audit exercise and considered your values and your strengths
Considered options to include a sense of purpose and explore choices that can provide you with that sense of purpose
Explored possibilities in the major aspects of your life and identified potential challenges and strategies for overcoming them
Begun to develop your blueprint to maximise the best years of your life and have considered a “future proofing” downsizing plan.
Bring pen and paper.
Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting
Join us for a fun day of creature making! Design and sculpt a one-of-a-kind character in your own style from polymer clays in a full spectrum of colours!

Working with oven-cured clays and wrapped wire armatures, this workshop offers a variety of modelling methods and approaches - a great opportunity to turn sketches & ideas into tangible 3D forms. Modern clay inventions mean we can create translucent, glittery, semi-flexible, UV reactive or even glow-in-the-dark elements to add more realism or a touch of the surreal into each creation!

Students will be coached through designing and creating a small-scale creature sculpture, beginning simple, and building to a more complex final form as we get familiar with materials.

The class offers beginner students a fun introduction to sculpting organic forms from scratch, and for those with some hands-on creative experience, it offers a great opportunity to experiment, hone and advance your making skills to new levels.

If you can, bring along some design ideas, sketches or reference images to help kick start the sculpting process on the day.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if you have them.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Beginner's Weekend-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Beginner's Weekend
events.venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
events.description:
A fabulous and fun introduction to jewellery making over two mornings, this is our most popular short workshop! Give yourself a gift of a new hobby and walk out of the class with a unique beautiful piece of jewellery!

The students start with basic ring making in copper or brass. We begin with ring making as this process teaches students many fundamental techniques in one project, measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting, soldering and finishing are all included in this one ring.

Students will learn how to measure their fingers to get an accurately sized ring, later they will also learn how to take sizing from existing rings. They are shown how to use a jeweller’s saw to cut their metal to the correct length, how to form it up and how to solder.

Then they learn how to shape their rings and finish them up into a wearable piece of jewellery, all in the first class!

In the first morning they are also shown how to texture metals, cut and layer shapes, melt balls of silver and other techniques to create decorative elements.

Students can spend their afternoon and evening thinking about and planning their design in silver for the next day. We encourage them to carefully plan this project and think about how they might make their piece before they begin, including creating drawings and notes. (We always say drawings don’t need to be “good”, they just need to make sense to the student and their tutor!). This project can be another ring, or earrings or pendants. We have a great selection of example pieces in the workshop so they can see what’s achievable in the 3 hour time frame. Sometimes students can make more than one silver piece if they have enough time.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, up to 8 grams of sterling silver and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals and chains are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids 12 and up are welcome in this class, any person under 16 years old must be accompanied by an enrolled caregiver.

events.id: Botanical Watercolour on Calf Vellum-101 Glenmore Street, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Botanical Watercolour on Calf Vellum
events.venue: 101 Glenmore Street, Kelburn, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.description:
'Have you ever wondered what all the fuss is about vellum?

Botanical artist, Lesley Alexander will share her knowledge of painting on vellum.
Used as a writing and painting surface since before the Middle Ages, Lesley loves the luminosity and glow that can be achieved working this traditional way.

You will learn:
what vellum is
how it is prepared
it's uses now and in times past
how to prepare the vellum with pumice powder and
watercolour techniques to work on this very beautiful surface before spending the rest of the time painting a small colourful Pohutukawa leaf.
Ideally you will have some experience using watercolour but that is not essential.

Materials provided: 
A small piece of natural vellum

Materials participants need to bring:
A small piece of natural vellum will be supplied, and some art supplies will be available for you to use, but please bring:
Watercolour paper for practicing techniques - a small A5 piece is all you will need
Notebook or paper for taking notes
A4 piece of tracing paper
Watercolour paints - professional quality is best, but bring what you have making sure they are transparent or semi-transparent pigments
White gouache
Watercolour brushes - you will need small sizes such as #00, #1, #2, #4
HB or H pencil
Putty rubber
Masking tape
Board - A4 to tape the vellum to
Scalpel – with rounded blade
Palette
Soft cloth or kitchen roll
Small water container x 2
Magnifying glass
There may be a chance to buy pieces of vellum at the end of the workshop.

events.id: COFFEE & CLAY - Ceramic platter making-100 Tinakori Road Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
events.name: COFFEE & CLAY - Ceramic platter making
events.venue: 100 Tinakori Road Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.description:
Join us at Sophie Florence Ceramics for a relaxed, hands-on workshop where you'll create your own beautiful ceramic platter and a set of trinket plates in a working pottery studio. Over two inspiring hours, you'll learn the basics of hand-building with clay, guided step-by-step by a ceramic artist.
Enjoy fresh coffee and a home-baked morning tea as you shape, decorate, and embellish your pieces. You'll finish by choosing your preferred glaze colours, and we’ll take care of the firing process. Your finished ceramics will be ready to collect approximately four weeks later.
This small group workshop is perfect for absolute beginners—no experience needed. Come solo and meet like-minded creatives, or bring a friend for a fun and mindful morning.
You’ll be amazed at how calming it is to get out of your head and into your hands!

events.id: NZ Species Edit-a-thon 2025-150 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: NZ Species Edit-a-thon 2025
events.venue: 150 Wilton Road, Wilton, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.description:
As the internet is increasingly taken over by sponsored posts and AI-generated content, Wikipedia remains steadfast as a source of verifiable, up-to-date information. It’s one of the most visited websites in the world, maintained by around 120,000 volunteer editors across the globe, and it could use your help.
Over two Saturdays in August, we’re running Wikipedia edit-a-thons to create and improve articles focused on Aotearoa New Zealand's unique native flora and fauna. All are welcome – whether you’re a complete newbie or have experience editing – take this opportunity to develop your skills while contributing to the world's most comprehensive encyclopedia.
Anyone can edit Wikipedia, and you’ll be guided by highly experienced editors along the way. We'll provide all the training and resources you need to get started, and the native vegetation of Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush will provide the perfect location for collaborating with fellow nature enthusiasts to share our unique biodiversity with the world.
Bring a laptop and charger – all other resources are provided.
Whether you want to come along for just one day, or book in for both, we’re looking forward to having you join us.
Dates: Saturday 2nd August 2025 and Saturday 9th August 2025
Time: 10:00–16:00 NZST
Location: Ōtari-Wilton's Bush, Wellington, New Zealand. We will be located in the Leonard Cockayne Centre.
Getting to Ōtari: Take the No 14 bus from the city centre to Gloucester Street, which is just outside Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. You can also come by car and park in the main public car park on Wilton Road or along Churchill Drive. More information at this link.
Tickets are $5NZD which includes morning tea, lunch and afternoon tea. Places are limited.
Further information is available on the event pages for August 2 and August 9.

events.id: Radio Cartography-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Radio Cartography
events.venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description: This one day event will involve getting out and about around Wellington CBD in an attempt to map it for radio shadows (communication blindspots) within the Lower North Island Meshtastic network. The outcome will be a map which identifies areas where we need to install nodes to give coverage across the CBD. These could become mission-critical to reaching loved ones in the event of an earthquake or blackout event. We will meet at Critical Signals, 115 Taranaki Street, then head out into the city, rain or shine.

events.id: Silk Aquatint Printmaking-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Silk Aquatint Printmaking
events.venue: Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington
events.description:
Discover the silk aquatint, an accessible, non-toxic alternative print technique similar to collagraph printing whereby the texture of woven silk on the plate provides a ground to start building a design with varying tonal qualities. The outcome can be wonderfully detailed and painterly.

In this workshop you will learn -

- To identify appropriate silk to create an aquatint plate
- The importance of preparing an appropriate matrix for the silk
- About the different effects created by different types of media applied to the print matrix
- To make an aquatint plate
- To print an aquatint plate

This workshop is open to beginners as well as seasoned printers.

Basic materials included. Bring drawings or designs to help you get started and wear clothes you are not precious about.

Half hour break for lunch. Bring your own packed lunch to have in the historic Inverlochy house or explore the local Te Aro cafes.

You must be at least 16 years of age to attend this course.

Saturday & Sunday, 2-3 August, 10 am - 3 pm daily.

events.description:
The beloved Top Dog Film Festival is back at the Roxy on Saturday 2 Aug, 12.30pm for another heartwarming season, with a brand-new line-up of short films that celebrate the extraordinary connection between dogs and humans.

Touring around NZ, the 2025 festival features tales of adventure, resilience, and canine joy — reminding us why dogs truly are our best friends.

events.id: "Zentangle" Mindful Drawing Workshop-Inverlochy Art School, 3 Inverlochy Place, Wellington-Event Finder

ADVENTURE SCHOOL KIDS CLOTHING GRAB
Sunday 2 August | 2-4pm
Adventure School Hall - Doors open from 1:30pm
Kids clothes
Afternoon tea refreshments provided and 'new to you' clothes and accessories to take home

events.description:
Join us for a relaxed, drop-in style workshop where you’ll craft your own pocket shrine. These miniature altars are made inside small tins and can be dedicated to someone or something meaningful to you. It could be in memory of a loved one, in honour of a favourite artist, pet, place, or even a whimsical nod to the faeries. Anything goes.

Pocket shrines are designed to be carried with you or kept close. You might keep yours on your desk, in your bag, or tucked in your pocket to bring comfort, inspiration, or connection wherever you go.

We’ll have everything you need to bring your shrine to life, including collage materials, fabric scraps, buttons, beads, and more. If you’d like to make a shrine in memory of someone special, you are welcome to bring a small photo of them to include.

events.id: Troy Roberts Masterclass-Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Troy Roberts Masterclass
events.venue: Bedlam and Squalor, Upstairs, 18 Garrett Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
This afternoon is a rare opportunity to catch internationally renowned saxophonist, Troy Roberts presenting a masterclass on topics including improvisation, approaching standards, and a discussion of a life in jazz.

The New York City based Australian immigrant is a prolific leader with sixteen releases to his name. Currently celebrating his latest, Green Lights (featuring John Patitucci, Paul Bollenback and Jimmy Macbride), Roberts maintains a busy recording and performance schedule with his quartet, his original project Nu-Jive, as well as some of the greatest artists of today. Embracing his love for a vast variety of stylistic genres, the three-time GRAMMY nominated saxophonist is quickly becoming one of the most widely recorded touring artists of his time. As a go-to first call saxophonist, his name adorns several essential recordings ranging from the legendary Joey DeFrancesco, the iconic Van Morrison, the quintessential Jeff "Tain" Watts, the tireless Orrin Evans Captain Black Big Band, the critically acclaimed Kurt Elling, the breathtaking Veronica Swift, to numerous other jazz veterans, and newcomers considered tastemakers of their generation.

At 7pm Troy will be performing with Wellington-based artists Duncan Haynes (piano), Seth Boy (acoustic bass), and Mark Lockett (drums).
General admission concert only $30. Student concert only tickets (with Student ID) at the door $20.

events.id: Sacred Pulse - A Journey for Palestine Fundraiser-Beach Road, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Sacred Pulse - A Journey for Palestine Fundraiser
events.venue: Beach Road, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand
events.description:
Join us for an Ecstatic Dance and Sound Journey to raise vital funds for Mahmoud Al-Madhoun and his family, who are from Northern Gaza.
Mahmoud shares four children with his wife, Nour. They have a baby girl named Omnia (age 1), and three sons, Team (3), Ahmed (7) and Faiz (11). Omnia and her mother, Nour, were evacuated from Gaza via ambulance during the last ceasefire, before hostilities resumed. Unfortunately, Mahmoud and Omnia’s three big brothers were denied evacuation. Thus, the boys remain in Gaza with Mahmoud, where things are painfully difficult. Like all Palestinians, they are struggling to survive and the hardships just keep intensifying.
Upon arrival in Cairo, Omnia had to wait weeks for open heart surgery, a life saving treatment that she required at birth. With Gaza under constant bombardment, Omnia was unable to have surgery once her parents learned of her condition shortly after her birth.
Mahmoud and Nour have lost everything, their house, their livelihoods, and have been forced to evacuate multiple times, all while managing the complexities that come with supporting a child with difficult medical needs. Their suffering has been further exacerbated because of them being separated, meaning Mahmoud was unable to support his daughter and wife during surgery. No parent ever should be forced to endure such dire and heartbreaking circumstances.
This event is a call for community, compassion, and action — every dollar raised will go directly to help Mahmoud provide basic necessities and rebuild a sense of safety and hope for his family.
Let’s come together in movement and music to support this family in their time of urgent need. Your presence and contribution can truly make a difference.
Meet the Team:

Kellie Smith— Sound Ceremonialist
Kellie is a sacred space holder and sound practitioner. She completed her Master’s degree in Criminology in 2012, specialising in genocide and international humanitarian law. She draws upon her professional background and experience in trauma support work, blending themes of collective consciousness and justice into her sound offerings.
She brings deep love and wisdom into every tone and vibration she channels. Her sound frequencies and crystal-clear presence invite you into a realm of deep remembering, restoration, and renewal through the power of sound.
Lisa Schady — Voice of the Sacred
Lisa Schady is a captivating performing artist known for curating transformative spaces using her powerful voice and intuitive mic presence. With deep reverence, she guides participants through emotional landscapes with safety and intention. If you’ve ever stepped into one of her temples, you’ll know—Lisa creates sacred containers where what’s alive within can rise and be felt.
Andrzej — Musical Mystic
Andrzej is a musician extraordinaire whose ecstatic dance sets are a journey in themselves. With a rich tapestry of tribal beats, global rhythms, and soul-stirring melodies, he’ll guide us up, in, through, and out—awakening the body, stirring the spirit, and inviting pure, embodied expression. His music opens portals to presence, joy, and freedom. Offering an expansive celebration of dance and movement in the name of peace.
Saxon Brazier holds a Diploma in Music and Event Management. Deeply moved and conflicted by the ongoing genocide in Gaza, she has spearheaded this kaupapa as a way to turn anguish into action—organizing efforts to raise funds and awareness in support of a family’s urgent journey to safety.

events.description:
WJC is excited to announce a special one-off concert featuring Grammy nominated saxophonist, Troy Roberts.

Embracing his love for a vast variety of stylistic genres, three-time GRAMMY nominated saxophonist, Troy Roberts is quickly becoming one of the most widely recorded touring artists of his time. As a go-to first call saxophonist, his name adorns several essential recordings ranging from the legendary Joey DeFrancesco, the iconic Van Morrison, the quintessential Jeff "Tain" Watts, the tireless Orrin Evans’ Captain Black Big Band, the critically acclaimed Kurt Elling, the breathtaking Veronica Swift, including numerous other jazz veterans, and newcomers considered tastemakers of their generation.

The New York City based Australian immigrant is also a prolific leader with sixteen releases to his name. Currently celebrating his latest, Green Lights (featuring John Patitucci, Paul Bollenback and Jimmy Macbride), Roberts maintains a busy recording and performance schedule with his quartet, his original project Nu-Jive, as well as some of the greatest artists of today. With a busy international schedule, it is not often that Roberts finds time to schedule NZ dates, so this show is not to be missed!

Joining Troy Roberts (tenor saxophone), Duncan Haynes (piano), Seth Boy (acoustic bass), Mark Lockett (drums).

Troy Roberts continues to be a master of styles and configurations with this eminently accessible, sonically and rhythmically engaging session, emitting steam and sumptuous harmonic colors along the way. -Glide Magazine

events.id: The Warratahs-11 Logan Street, Ebdentown, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The Warratahs
events.venue: 11 Logan Street, Ebdentown, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand
events.description:
The Warratahs Live at the Upper Hutt Cossie Club – Saturday 2nd August
After nearly four decades on the road, The Warratahs remain one of New Zealand’s most beloved bands — and now they’re returning to the Upper Hutt Cossie Club for a very special show.
With 37 years of touring behind them, The Warratahs have left a deep mark on Kiwi music. Their legacy includes seven studio albums that made the charts, a Tui Music Award for Country Album of the Year in 2017, and performances alongside legends like Johnny Cash & The Highwaymen, Lucinda Williams, and Jackson Browne.
Barry Saunders’ iconic songwriting is woven into the fabric of the New Zealand songbook, and this is your chance to witness the band at their best.
Born out of a simple love for playing music with mates down at the pub, The Warratahs first hit the stage at The Cricketers’ Arms in Wellington in 1986 — never imagining they’d become a national treasure.
Led by the distinctive voice of Barry Saunders and the unmistakable violin of Nik Brown, their sound — forged in 1985 — continues to captivate audiences.
Don’t miss this legendary band live in Upper Hutt!

events.id: InDuna - Go High - EP Release-MOON, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: InDuna - Go High - EP Release
events.venue: MOON, Wellington
events.description:
Join Afro-Kiwi artist InDuna to celebrate the release of his brand new EP, ‘Go High’, live at Moon, Wellington on Saturday 2nd August.

‘Go High’ is a gift from InDuna’s younger self to the artist he is today. It's an uplifting and reflective Afro-pop project inspired by his South African roots and journey of resilience. The EP is a reminder to keep dreaming boldly, no matter the obstacles.

He will also be joined by two incredible acts:

*Tarin* is a soulful Moriori singer-songwriter from Whakatū, now based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Her sound blends dreamy R&B and soul with jazz influences, drawing inspiration from artists like Amy Winehouse and Etta James. With raw, introspective lyrics and a deeply emotive voice, Tarin delivers music that’s personal, expressive, and healing.

*KB the DJ* is a Cape Town-born selector now lighting up Aotearoa with his genre-spanning sets. On the night, KB will be serving deep Afro grooves and infectious rhythms to keep the energy high and the dancefloor moving.

Doors open: 9:00 PM
Show starts: 9:30 PM

Venue: Moon, 167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington
Moon is a wheelchair-accessible venue with both seated and standing options available.

When the NFC ticket bundle is purchased, fans will get exclusive access to a limited edition NFC-enabled EP, featuring the full EP plus unreleased demos and future tracks, delivered directly to your device before they’re available anywhere else. InDuna merchandise will also be available on the night — don’t miss it.

About InDuna:
Self-taught artist and producer InDuna blends Afro-pop with the vibrant spirit of his South African heritage. He was recently honoured with the Young Global Achiever Award at the 2024 Prince’s Trust Awards in London and recognised at Buckingham Palace by King Charles III.

His music has reached global ears, with his track ‘Dreams’, written for the documentary Ink and Gold: An Artist’s Journey to Olympic Glory, winning Best Original Song at the International Online Web Fest and climbing to #6 on the NZ Hot Singles Chart.

events.name: Correct Colour Pencil Techniques for Botanical Drawing
events.venue: Wellington Botanic Garden, 101 Glenmore St, Kelburn, Wellington
events.description:
Colour pencil is an exciting art form when practiced correctly, and works well with creating beautiful botanicals. In this workshop Sandra will share the tips and tricks she has
used in her botanical drawings.

You will learn:
• How to capture the shape and form of your flower or leaf using basic shapes to start with.
• Working with the correct colour for undertone to create light and dark
• How to achieve clean veins and /or fine hairs
• How to achieve highlights
• The most suitable tools for blending.
• Suitable for all skills level ages 15years+

Materials provided:
colour pencils & paper

Materials participants need to bring:
- HB pencil
- Tombow clutch eraser rounded or similar (example: https://www.gordonharris.co.nz/product/22770-tombow-mono-zero-eraser-pen-round?categoryId=1454)
- Double ball stylus or similar (example: https://www.gordonharris.co.nz/product/2777-double-ball-stylus-1-2mm-2-8mm)

Akoranga Learning Pavilion in the Discovery Garden at Wellington Botanic Garden

events.venue: Workspace Ōtaki, 6 Hewson Crescent, Ōtaki
events.description:
Join us for this fabulous introduction to working with colourful molten glass!

This class is a great way for absolute beginners to get a taste of working with glass to produce beautiful beads that can be used in a myriad of ways, including making a unique gift for your loved one (or yourself!).

As one of the earliest forms of human adornment, beads have long functioned as a way to express individuality, and what better way to do that than to learn to make your own unique beads?

Students are shown correct lampworking techniques to produce several decorative beads in just 3 hours! How many beads you make is up to you, some students make up to 10 while others make fewer using trickier techniques.

Kids over 12 (or so) are welcome to take the class but anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

events.id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Treasures from the Gully (Aug 2025)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Treasures from the Gully (Aug 2025)
events.venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.description:
Treasures from the Gully

Tour through a very atmospheric part of the cemetery, with an eclectic mix of stories on an artist, photographer, hat manufacturer, prison reformer and many more! Come and enjoy the beauty of one of the most mystical places in the Cemetery with entertaining stories along the way.
The tour will mostly keep to pathways but some areas are potentially uneven underfoot. A moderate level of fitness is required.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by midday by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
The tour is approximately 1.5 hours long
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

events.id: Planting and Track Maintenance - Working Bee-Manawa Karioi Reserve, Danube Street, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Planting and Track Maintenance - Working Bee
events.venue: Manawa Karioi Reserve, Danube Street, Wellington
events.description:
Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.

Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.

Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

events.id: Nature Journaling-Wellington Botanic Garden, 101 Glenmore St, Kelburn, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Nature Journaling
events.venue: Wellington Botanic Garden, 101 Glenmore St, Kelburn, Wellington
events.description:
A gentle ramble around parts of the botanic gardens with botanical artist Sandra Morris, using careful observation and journalling techniques to record how our personal connection
with our environment changes our perception and wellbeing.
You will learn:
• Different ways to observe and the practice of mindfulness and wellbeing
• Different ways to record visually, eg. diagrams, sketches, careful drawings, maps, graphs
• Different ways to record in words, numbers
• Approaches to page layout
• Suitable for all skill levels- with a desire to learn to observe and connect with the natural world around you.

Materials participants need to bring:
- sketch book A5 or A4 or photocopy paper with backing board with clip for attaching paper to board
- drawing pencils and/or drawing pens
- colour pencils or whatever you prefer to work with

Please note: This event requires a minimum of 8 bookings to go ahead. If fewer than 8 people register, the event will be cancelled and any fees paid will be fully refunded.

events.id: Ghost Trio-Waikanae Memorial Hall, 7 Pehi Kupa St, Waikanae-Event Finder
events.name: Ghost Trio
events.venue: Waikanae Memorial Hall, 7 Pehi Kupa St, Waikanae
events.description:
Programme

Beethoven: Piano Trio, Opus 70, No 1 "The Ghost"
Takemitsu: Between Tides
Glen Downie: Sonata da chiesa
Shostakovich: Piano Trio No 2, Opus 67


The Ghost Trio will perform in Waikanae as part of a Chamber Music New Zealand tour. Popular New Zealand musicians Monique Lapins (violin), Ken Ichinose (cello) and pianist Gabriela Glapska are all familiar faces on the Waikanae stage, having appeared with numerous other chamber ensembles. They have named their group after the work they are about to perform on this tour - Beethoven's Opus 70, No 2 trio which is known as "The Ghost" because of the eerie, ominous sounds in the gloomy second movement. The two outer movements are much brighter, the first bold and energetic, the third witty and playful.

Two brief and contrasting works complete the first half of this varied concert. Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu has been acclaimed as the most important composer in Japanese musical history. His piece "Between Tides" illustrates his great love of nature. New Zealand composer Glen Downie's new work (being premiered on this tour) was inspired by the simplicity of Vivaldi’s cello sonatas and the baroque form known as sonata da chiesa.

The second half of the concert will be dominated by one of the greatest piano trios of the 20th Century - Shostakovich's Opus 67. Written in 1944 amid World War II, the trio responds to the conflicts of those times, but also to the composer's personal circumstances. It is an elegy for the tragic victims of war, but also expresses Shostakovich's grief at the sudden death of his closest friend and mentor Ivan Ivanovich Sollertinsky. The opening movement is bleak and despairing, followed by a lively, almost obsessive Scherzo. The third movement is a starkly beautiful funeral dirge while the last movement brings together themes from the previous movements, also introducing new Russian and Jewish themes.

Door sales will be available for this concert or tickets can be bought from Waikanae New World and Moby Dickens Books in Paraparaumu Beach. Ticket enquiries can be made at 022 345 5316 or from the society's website www.waikanaemusic.org.nz

The Ghost Trio concert is presented as part of Chamber Music New Zealand’s "In Partnership Series".

events.id: Ben Chavasse Unplugged With Strings (support From Bronwyn Wilde)-Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Ben Chavasse Unplugged With Strings (support From Bronwyn Wilde)
events.venue: Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington
events.description:
Indie-folk artist Ben Chavasse is making his first trip to Wellington to celebrate the release of his first two singles. This set will feature stripped back arrangements of his songs accompanied with string arrangements performed by Karen Hu (cello), and Hijiri Yamamoto (violin).

Ben Chavasse is a 26-year-old singer-songwriter based in Tāmaki Makaurau. His lyric-forward approach embraces the indie-folk genre while incorporating rock, punk, and jazz influences. He explores themes of adolescence, mental health, and reconciliation through an introspective, reflective and vulnerable lens. Ben continues to thrive in collaboration with local musicians he met during his studies at the University of Auckland Jazz School.

Bronwyn Wilde grew up across the road from Vogelmorn and can remember performing at the Hall as early as age six (she sang the national anthem at the Ridgway school talent quest - it was not a winning song choice). Today, she is a trustee of the Vogelmorn Community Group and occasionally works behind the bar, where she has been lucky to see so many talented local musicians perform.
She has many fond memories of singing with Ben together in their flat in Auckland during the 2021 lockdown. She is thrilled to be joining him on stage at Vogelmorn, her second home.

events.id: Jane Austen Wrecked My Life (Advance Screening)-29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Jane Austen Wrecked My Life (Advance Screening)
events.venue: 29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Hugely popular at the French Film Festival Aotearoa, Jane Austen Wrecked My Life is being released publicly (14 August 2025) and the Austen Society invites you to an advanced screening!
A French book seller and author at a Jane Austen writing residency - sounds like all our dreams come true.
Plus one attendee will win a free double pass to Lighthouse.
“Jane Austen Wrecked My Life is a romantic comedy for the quiet, thoughtful lovers who yearn for the sincerity of the past."- Jourdain Searles, Roger Ebert
"Jane Austen Wrecked My Life, an amiable new romance written and directed by Laura Piani. Steeped in the filmmaker's love of the writer" - John Powers, NPR
"It is a truth universally acknowledged that Jane Austen has inspired more romcoms than any other author – and nearly all of them feature a modern take on an Austen protagonist, a new Lizzie Bennet or Emma Woodhouse. But this funny and smart French comedy instead gives us a 21st-century Jane Austen. British-French actor Camille Rutherford is terrific as Agathe, an aspiring novelist working in a Paris bookshop who wins a place on a Jane Austen writing retreat run by the author’s descendants." - Cath Clarke, The Guardian
French with English Subtitles, 1h 34m

events.id: Black Flock presents Weird Horror Film Festival-Rintoul Street Wellington, Wellington 6021-Event Brite
events.name: Black Flock presents Weird Horror Film Festival
events.venue: Rintoul Street Wellington, Wellington 6021
events.description:
Welcome to the first annual Horror Film Festival. Bought to you by Black Flock art collective.
The nights are becoming longer, the wind is howling, the black mold is growing, and the world is a pretty scary place.
Why would we want to do this when the world is aleady a scary place?
Watching horror films for many can be a safe way to process fears, dark fantasies and morbid thoughts. Creativity gives us the means to process and express what goes on inside our minds.Community gives us a place to support each other through scary times, and make our own fun!!!
so.....
Get ready for a Sunday Horror evening where the audience support each others15 minutes of... screaming at the top of their lungs until their (fake) eyeballs pop out, or cross your legs and wince as other inventive special effects and use of prosthetics send quivers through your body. Marvel at the kiwi-ingenuity of your mates improvised sets and costumes. Be astounded as you learn that your flatmate has a dark side and is quite skilled with suspense...whatever genre of horror you go for, be it splatter, psychological, slasher, body horror, these are all short films made within a short time frame, and we expect and encourage B-Z grade styles done on the cheap. We will get through this together comrades!
We will have an awards ceremony on the night with various prize categories, including audiences pick.
Be a part of the fun, grab whatever moving picture recording device you can find, and make a horror film to enter.
Registrations for entering a film for this years screening are now closed (as of May 18th)

The Deadline for submitting your final cut in order to be shown is July 20th.

Come join us for a bloody good time at the Newtown Community Centre - Te Whare Hapori o Nga Puna Waiora Sunday, August 3rd!

events.description:
Discover the intricate flavours and subtleties of Taylors and Fonseca Ports celebrated with a full food degustation in our Napoleon Dining Room by a roaring fire.

Devolve on this journey to Portugal, right here in Martinborough Wine Village. These special ports (including some deep from the cellar) will be matched with a six-course degustation from Chef Charles de Villiers, Michelin Star Chef Adam Newell, and the Union Square Bistro kitchen team, made from the freshest locally sourced produce.

What’s in Store:
- An Introduction to the legends of Port: Hear brand ambassador Robert Bower discuss Taylors and Fonseca Ports incredible histories and get insights into how Port is produced, alongside his vision of the future of Port drinkers in Australasia.
- Six Courses of Culinary Excellence: paired with Taylor's White, Fonseca Bin 27 Finest Reserve, Taylors LBV 2019, Fonseca Guimaraens Vintage, Taylors Vintage 2003, Taylors 10YO Tawny, Taylors 20YO Tawny, and Taylors 30YR Tawny, highlighting the unique characteristics of both legendary and newer vintages.

Don’t miss this unique opportunity to savor and learn about Port, indulge in exquisite cuisine, and engage with the brand ambassador.
Limited Seats Available – Book Now!

events.description:
1 or 2 Day Workshop in Wellington
Limited tickets available. Get in now so you don't miss out!
Who's it for? 
Leaders, emerging leaders, professionals who need to create a significant shift in their communication skills, or confident communicators looking to become compelling communicators! 

The ability to inspire and influence, win new business and gain respect from audiences, are essential skills for business leaders everywhere. Presentation training has never been more important.
In this two day course you will learn how to become a more confident, engaging and influential presenter. 
What you will learn:
Day One:
Create Engaging Content: Learn how to use the Effective Speaking SpeakerMap™ to quickly create an engaging presentation that your audience will value.
Design Useful Visuals: Discover the alternatives to “death by bullet-point” and transform your slides to engaging and useful visual content.
Manage your Nervousness: Learn how to manage your feelings of nervousness and stage-fright.
Day Two:
Preparation that makes a difference: Learn how to prepare for your presentation so you feel and sound more confident and relaxed.
Deliver with Impact: Speak to a group with the confidence and ease with which you speak when you’re communicating one-on-one.
Handle that Audience: Learn how to handle any curve-balls the audience throws you!
What past participants say:

"The overall experience of the course far surpassed my expectations. I came in hoping to gain some valuable insights and tips for better public speaking, but what I received was so much more. I developed a newfound confidence in my ability to communicate effectively, learned how to captivate an audience, and discovered strategies for managing nerves and overcoming stage fright. I would recommend this effective speaking course to anyone looking to enhance their communication abilities. It's not just another course; it's a transformative experience that will empower you to become a more confident and persuasive speaker" Alex Goryachev, New Zealand Green Building Council
“This course not only met my expectations, but it completely exceeded them. This has been one of the most transformative courses I’ve attended. Jane totally revolutionised the way I now approach presentations. Having felt fear in the past each time I have to present to large groups, for the first time I now feel like I have the tools, understanding and ability to approach presentations and conquer my fear. I can’t thank Jane enough.” Nadia Marsh, Head of Bids, Tonkin & Taylor
"I have never been in such a well-run course (I've done a lot) Jane was amazing she held our attention from start to finish each day. I feel we all learnt so much and I will definitely be taking her advice on how I can improve myself. This course was well above what I expected, Jane had a great way of communicating. Typically, people tune out or lose interest by the end of the day. This was not the case for us. I honestly thing it’s the best course I’ve been on in my 4 years with WCC." Joshua Harding, Team Leader Consents, Wellington City Council

“The course is awesome. The balance between talk time, practical learning and feedback is perfect. The trainer really made the course for me - she is sensitive and responsive to people’s needs and is genuine in her approach to give the learners as much out of the time as possible. A very polished and well-planned course.” Huia Grey, Department of Conservation
"After reading many books it was great to finally learn an effective and no fuss way of creating a presentation that looks professional and won't put the client to sleep. I can see how the SpeakerMap will be a valuable tool for creating my trainings and presentations in the future. Thanks for the opportunity to present, the feedback I received was really valuable." Shannan Clarke - Business Development Leader - Front-Line Training
“Out of the 117 presenters that spoke at the TechEd conference my final ranking was #9. I absolutely would not have achieved that had it not been for the invaluable speaker training you provided! Thank you so much.” Daniel Bowbyes, Information Architect, Datacom
Choose your package:
Preparation Day Only - 1 day only
Have you got limited time or budget? Then this option may be for you. Come along on the Preparation Day and you will learn the foundation skills behind being an engaging and confident presenter.
You will learn :
How to use the Effective Speaking SpeakerMap™ to quickly create an engaging presentation. This system has helped thousands of New Zealanders learn how to prepare credible, valuable and effective business presentations.
Discover the alternatives to “death by bullet-point” and transform your slides to engaging visual content
Learn how to manage your feelings of nervousness and stage-fright

Are you very nervous about presenting and not quite ready for front of the room coaching? Then this option is for you. Attend both days, and learn how to design your presentation, design engaging PowerPoint slides, manage your nerves and how to prepare. However when it comes to the Delivery - you won't have to get up and present to the group.
You will learn:

This lecture, delivered by Julian Oliver, will introduce participants to the potentials and pitfalls of self-hosted server infrastructure, whether that be a PC-turned-server hosted at home, studio or office, or on a server rented at a datacenter. Starting points for self-hosting will be covered, with an introduction to system administration in the context of digital caretaker, guardian and gardener. events.id: ACT for Everybody, July 2025-21 Hania Street Wellington, Wellington 6011-Event Brite
events.name: ACT for Everybody, July 2025
events.venue: 21 Hania Street Wellington, Wellington 6011
events.description:
Life can be hard.
We want to help you manage life when it’s difficult. And we know that for many people ACT has a profound and positive effect on wellbeing.
ACT for Everybody is a 6 week course where you’ll learn how to interact more helpfully with thoughts, feelings and behaviours that you struggle with. You’ll develop your ability to move towards what matters to you even when you’re feeling bad. And you’ll do this with a small group of others.
We know that people wonder whether groups are for them! We find that discovering ACT in a group provides special opportunities to learn from each other and highlight how all our minds get stuck in struggle at times. The course includes chances to share but you can choose how much or little you contribute. Here is some feedback from a previous participant:
The course gave me scheduled time to stop and reflect in a non-threatening environment. It wasn’t rushed, it wasn’t pressured but there was a lot of skills, knowledge and tools that through the course became part of me. The course opened up struggles within me that I did not know were there and helped me deal with them. It gave me tools to deal with feelings that sent me in a spiral to dark places. It taught me that I can always do something. I went to the course believing that I was not brave enough to live my life and left with the courage to live it.
What is ACT?
We think about Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) as a way of helping people live their lives based on their values, and without painful thoughts and feelings getting in the way.
Emotional pain is a normal and unavoidable part of human experience. Often it is the struggle to avoid painful thoughts and feelings that leads to suffering. ACT is literally about taking action: accepting what you can’t change and committing to what you can.
What can I expect?
ACT for Everybody is a supportive, interesting, safe, confidential and fun course. It’s facilitated by experienced psychologists with between 8 and 14 participants. It runs for 2 hours on Tuesday afternoons, from 4:00pm to 6:00pm.
You need to join us for the first night of the course in order to take part in the rest of the course.


Giselle Bahr is a clinical psychologist and co-founder of ACT Wellington. She has been using ACT in her practice for over 15 years, and has been trained and supervised by many of the world’s leading ACT therapists and researchers. Giselle has worked at Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services, in Private Practice with adults and adolescents, and trained new clinical psychology students at Victoria University of Wellington. Giselle has developed and facilitates a group introducing ACT to Parents.
Tania Stanton works as a clinical psychologist at the Maternal Mental Health Service. She has previously worked in Infant, Child, Adolescent and Family Services where she co-developed and facilitated therapy groups for young people and their parents using ACT. She is enthusiastic about the help that ACT can offer to enhance people's lives.

Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars:
Peace over Panic - Rewiring the Anxious Mind
Transform your relationship with anxiety in just 60 minutes using the revolutionary FasterEFT technique that's helping thousands worldwide break free from the grip of panic and overwhelm.
In "Peace over Panic - Rewiring the Anxious Mind," you'll discover how your mind creates anxiety through unconscious patterns and learn a simple yet powerful tapping method to literally rewire your nervous system for calm and confidence.
Unlike traditional therapy that can take months or years, FasterEFT works at the subconscious level where anxiety is actually created, allowing you to experience immediate relief and lasting change. Whether you struggle with daily worry, panic attacks, or overwhelming stress, this workshop will give you practical tools to take control of your mental state and create the peaceful, confident life you deserve. Leave with a complete system you can use anywhere, anytime to transform anxiety into inner peace.
The seminar will be followed by a delicious plant-based dinner together, all included in your ticket!

Introducing Krishnaloka, who is driven to help others overcome their issues within their mind and pyschology. Her warm and caring nature makes every interaction with her both comforting and transformative.

events.id: Revelation Valley-BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Revelation Valley
events.venue: BATS Theatre, 1 Kent Tce, Wellington
events.description:
Experience the artistry of theatre-maker Lisa Maule and special guests in this poetry premiere.

---
Three years ago surrounded by books and thinking about constitutional change, Pākehā theatre maker Lisa Maule decided to write poetry. "Revelation Valley" is a selection of her writing performed by Lisa with titles such as My Capitalist Stapler, Cohesion is Also a Radical Act and Is it Hate? (a poem about love).

Each night a different invited guest adds to the creativity with a taste of their own work. Guests are Dylan Fa'atui, Eru Moriarty, Aische Arawelo, Jim Moriarty, and Heather Came. The show also features music collaboration with Michelle Scullion.

Embrace unexpected laughs, challenge your norms and immerse yourself in creativity.

"Not a straight town at all, not a straight down. An asphalt zigzag.
Home to hydrangea’s, cats, rats, cars, tartan trinkets, china tea cups
and
traces
of
ancient trees."
(Lisa Maule)

---
Lisa Maule grew up in Wellington where she was born and went to Karori Normal School and Wellington Girls College. Her heritage is English and Scottish. She has two young adult children and two black fluffy dogs. As a theatre maker Lisa started in the 1990s, her first role outside of university was as the technical operator at BATS Theatre on a Red Mole show. Other formative experiences were at Taki Rua Theatre and with women's theatre such as Not Broadcast Quality and Magdalena Aotearoa. She is Producer / Kaihautū at the Maori theatre company Te Rākau Hua o Te Wao Tapu working alongside Jim Moriarty and Helen Pearse-Otene

The creative practice Lisa is best known for is her lighting design work and she also loves to draw, paint and make collage. Lisa has a penchant for collecting chairs and she is good at cutting cardboard.

events.id: Your Parenting ACT, July 2025-21 Hania St Mt Victoria Wellington, 6011-Event Brite
events.name: Your Parenting ACT, July 2025
events.venue: 21 Hania St Mt Victoria Wellington, 6011
events.description:
Parenting can be both a joy and very hard work.
But things get in the way of us being the parents we want to be - including our own thoughts and feelings. These can be about ourselves, about our children, about our parenting, or about what others think about our parenting.
Your Parenting ACT is a 6 week course for parents of school aged children where you can develop a strong foundation for your parenting. It helps you understand your child, develop your self, nurture your relationship with your child and parent in line with your values. It uses principles from ACT — Acceptance and Commitment Training — to help you make room for all your thoughts and feelings, so you can respond more calmly and flexibly as a parent.
ACT uses acceptance, mindfulness and behavioural strategies to help people pursue what matters most to them, including being the parent they want to be.
We know that people wonder whether groups are for them! But we find that discovering ACT with and from people who are having similar experiences such as parenting, is very effective and fun. A recent attendee said:
"I can read all the books, but there's nothing like meeting and hearing from other parents."


The course is held over six consecutive Tuesday evenings from 7:00pm to 9:00pm.
We understand that sometimes things get in the way of plans, and occasionally people can't make a night of the course. But it is essential that you attend the first night of the course in order to take part in the remaining sessions. The course includes invitations to share and experiential exercises that work best when we are able to get to know one another and develop trust in the group.

This course needs a minimum number of parents to go ahead. So if you've decided to come, please sign up! It's very helpful to know that we have enough people to proceed.


Giselle Bahr is a clinical psychologist working in Wellington who continues to parent two adult children. She works primarily with young people and their families in private practice. Before that she spent 15 years working in Wellington's public health system and teaching in a university clinical training programme.
Tania Stanton works as a clinical psychologist at the Maternal Mental Health Service. She has previously worked in Infant, Child, Adolescent and Family Services where she co-developed and facilitated therapy groups for young people and their parents using ACT. She is enthusiastic about the help that ACT can offer to enhance people’s lives.

events.description:
Local opera company Wellington Opera presents a grand production. ‘A Masked Ball’ (Un Ballo in Maschera) is one of Giuseppe Verdi’s great masterpieces. It contrasts the frivolity of a masquerade with high drama. For this production, Wellington Opera has gathered a cast made exclusively of New Zealand opera singers. Madeleine Pierard and Jared Holt return after headlining the 2024 production of ‘Tosca’. Joining them are Julien Van Mellaerts, Natasha Te Rupe Wilson, Kristin Darragh, and Morgan King. 
The opera is based on the true story of the 1792 assassination of King Gustavo III of Sweden. He was shot while attending a masked ball — a result of a political conspiracy. The staging, by Jacqueline Coats, promises to bring the dramatic storyline to life. Brian Castles-Onion will conduct Orchestra Wellington.

events.name: The Big Bad World of Cyber Why SMEs Need to Stay on Guard
events.venue: Otaihanga Road, Paraparaumu, Kāpiti Coast 5036
events.description:
The Big Bad World of Cyber
Why SMEs Need to Stay on Guard
Electra Business Breakfast – B2B networking – Sponsored by Electra – Supported by Business Kāpiti
Nau mai haere mai Electra Business Breakfast is pleased to welcome Jan Thornborough, Founder of Outfox Ltd who trained with the best at New Zealand's National Cyber Security Centre and now helps SMEs navigate the risks of the digital world.  Cyber threats aren’t just a big business problem – small businesses are prime targets too.
In this practical, no-jargon session, Jan will break down what’s really happening in cybercrime, why it matters to your business, and simple steps to stay secure.  Expect real stories, useful insights, and advice you can act on – because staying cyber-safe is simply just smart business these days.
Attend this Breakfast and stay one step ahead of cybercrime.  Outfox understand that a cyber-attack can destroy people’s lives.  They believe that people deserve to feel safe and secure in the knowledge that their organisation is protected.  Jan and team love outfoxing the bad guys and empowering small business to be cyber resilient in their journey of growth.
See you there! Book early to avoid disappointment!
WELLNESS UPDATE
Please don’t attend if you are feeling unwell.  We look forward to seeing you all soon.
------------------------------------------------
ABOUT THE SPEAKER:
Jan Thornborough
Founder & Director, Outfox Ltd
Prior to setting up her own business, Jan was head of the Cyber Resilience Unit at New Zealand’s National Cyber Security Centre, helping nationally significant organisations become more cyber resilient. 
She founded Outfox in 2021 (under its original name of Intelligensia) after realising that although big organisations were dealing with cyber risks, small and medium-sized businesses and not-for-profit organisations were being left behind. 
She helps small businesses make smarter cyber decisions and build their confidence to operate in a risky digital world.  She believes your business deserves better than ‘hope for the best’ cybersecurity.
Electra Business Breakfast is an independent networking programme that seeks to INSPIRE, CONNECT and ENGAGE where everyone is welcome.

#JanThornborough #CyberCrime #CyberThreats #BeCyberSmart #CyberSafe #OutfoxCyberCrime #Economy #BusinessSustainability #KāpitiCoast #EconomicGrowth #Kāpiti #Business #BusinessKāpiti #BusinessGrowth #BusinessDevelopment #BusinessNetworking #Inspire #Connect #Engage #ElectraBusinessBreakfast

events.id: CPD: Mastering Masterspec Specifications WELLINGTON | ⭐ 20 CPD Points-10 Dunlop Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: CPD: Mastering Masterspec Specifications WELLINGTON | ⭐ 20 CPD Points
events.venue: 10 Dunlop Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
⭐ CPD Points: 20
Description
This CPD course, titled "Mastering Masterspec Specifications," is designed to provide specifiers with comprehensive training on effectively utilising the Masterspec platform for specification writing. Participants will learn the ins and outs of navigating the Masterspec platform, setting up their specifications, managing user accounts, and optimising the use of various features such as Office Masters, MasterKey, and mDocs. The course covers essential topics ranging from basic specification setup to advanced specification management techniques, ensuring participants gain practical skills to streamline their specification writing process.
Designed by specifiers for specifiers
This course is designed for specifiers, including architects, designers, engineers, and other professionals involved in the construction industry, who are responsible for creating specifications for building projects. Whether you are new to the Masterspec platform or looking to enhance your proficiency in specification writing, this course provides valuable insights and practical skills to optimise your workflow and maximise the benefits of using Masterspec for specification management.
Why should specifiers take this course
Specifiers should take this course to enhance their proficiency in specification writing and maximise the benefits offered by the Masterspec platform. By mastering the tools and functionalities covered in this course, specifiers can:
Improve Efficiency: Learn how to navigate the Masterspec website and utilise its features effectively, saving time and effort in specification writing tasks.
Ensure Accuracy: Gain insights into best practices for setting up specifications, assigning roles, and managing user accounts to maintain data accuracy and consistency.
Enhance Collaboration: Understand how to collaborate with team members, assign roles, and share specifications seamlessly within the organization, promoting teamwork and productivity.
Stay Updated: Stay abreast of the latest features and updates on the Masterspec platform, ensuring specifiers are equipped with the knowledge to leverage new tools for enhanced specification writing.
Optimise Workflow: Discover advanced techniques for managing specifications, utilising Office Masters, and integrating with drawing sets using MasterKey, leading to streamlined workflow and project efficiency.
Ensure Compliance: Learn about NZCIC guidelines and best practices for adding, editing, and exporting guidelines to ensure compliance with industry standards and regulations.
Boost Professional Development: Acquire valuable skills and knowledge that contribute to professional growth and advancement in the field of specification writing, enhancing career prospects and opportunities.

events.id: Weather Commoning: Chris Berthelsen-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Weather Commoning: Chris Berthelsen
events.venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Critical Signals from the Japanese Government's Moonshot Goal 8 Project
The Japanese government's Moonshot Goal 8 project aims to create a society safe from extreme winds and rains by controlling the weather by 2050. Led by Kosei Yamaguchi (Kyoto University), a key part of the project is developing devices like turbines, curtains, and cloud seeding to calm (not control) extreme rain. The Weather Commons Research Group, led by Tsuyoshi Hatori (Ehime University), is developing and exploring 'weather commoning’. This involves the exploration of symbiotic relationships with weather patterns and disasters, non-normative ethics based on local community practices, and citizen participation in technological development.
Please join weather commons group leader Tsuyoshi Hatori and member Chris Berthelsen (originally Tāmaki Makaurau) for an introduction to the state of weather control, calming, and commoning research and activity in Japan. This is a space for open discussion, but you are also free to sit back and listen.

events.id: From Galileo to Laudato Si’: Why Science Needs Faith - Br. Guy Consolmagno-33 Bunny Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011-Event Brite
events.name: From Galileo to Laudato Si’: Why Science Needs Faith - Br. Guy Consolmagno
events.venue: 33 Bunny Street Wellington, Wellington Region 6011
events.description:
This event is also available online on Zoom.
How we understand faith and science has changed radically from the time of Galileo, as can be seen in how Pope Francis blended science and faith in his encyclical Laudato Si’. Its key insight is that our science, and the technology it spawns, is deeply connected to the flawed but redeemable human persons who do the science, and who make and live with technology... and its consequences
Br. Guy Consolmagno, SJ, is an American Jesuit brother and planetary scientist, currently serving as the Director of the Vatican Observatory and President of the Vatican Observatory Foundation. He is known for his research on meteorites, asteroids, and the evolution of small solar system bodies, as well as his popular writings on astronomy and faith. He holds degrees from MIT (SB, SM) and the University of Arizona (PhD in Planetary Science) and has worked in astronomy at Harvard and MIT before entering the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) in 1989.
Br. Guy has been at the Vatican Observatory since 1993, curating the meteorite collection and conducting research. He was appointed director in September 2015 by Pope Francis. His research focuses on the physical properties of meteorites and asteroids, including their spectra and how they relate to the evolution of the solar system. He is the author of several popular books, including "Turn Left at Orion" (with Dan Davis) and "Would You Baptize an Extraterrestrial?" (with Paul Mueller, SJ). He is also a popular speaker on the topic of faith and science, and serves on the governing boards of various international scientific organizations.
This event is co-hosted by Te Kupenga – the Catholic Leadership Institute, Te Herenga Waka - Victoria University of Wellington and the Wellington Astronomical Society

events.id: Ka Mua, Ka Muri: an Introduction-Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Ka Mua, Ka Muri: an Introduction
events.venue: Wellington Museum, 3 Jervois Quay, Queens Wharf, Wellington
events.description:
Nau mai, haere mai, we are proud to present the Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum Legal Series, an informative lecture series about the purpose, historical significance and ongoing mahi of The Waitangi Tribunal held alongside the exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.

In order to understand our future, we must first understand our past. Therefore, we announce with great pleasure that noted historian Dame Claudia Orange DNZM OBE CRSNZ will present our opening lecture in this series, which focuses on the history of Te Tiriti o Waitangi and the Waitangi Tribunal.

Encouraging discussion on the Treaty of Waitangi is a vital part of continuing efforts to fulfil the promise of the 1840 agreement. Dame Claudia argues that a broad public understanding of the changes that have occurred in the Māori–Crown relationship is essential in order for those relationships to grow. She says that an understanding of history is vital, and informed vigilance is necessary.

Tickets are $35 per session, or $25 for students and SuperGold Card holders, and include one drink and light kai. Doors open 5:30pm. The exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of The Waitangi Tribunal will remain open to view until 8pm.

Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum

Wednesday 6 August | 6pm – 8pm

Tickets $25–$35 | Book tickets: https://bit.ly/4lgFb0F
