events.id: Next-Level BA: half-day workshop (Wellington)-2/318 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Next-Level BA: half-day workshop (Wellington)
events.venue: 2/318 Lambton Quay, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Next-Level BA: How to maximise your value-add
A half-day workshop for Business Analysts looking to take things to the next level.
What this course isn't...
This isn't about your traditional 'BA' skills - we won't be learning to write better requirements, user stories, or processes!
What this course is...
This is a course focused on a mindset shift (with the tools to back it up) to enable you to add more value as a BA. As projects become more ambiguous and agile, the expectations on a BA are changing in a way gives us the opportunity to make a bigger impact - if we have the skills to take advantage...
Workshop scope:
0. Intro / ‘Next-Level BA’ definition
Learn what makes a “Next-Level BA” – someone who jumps into projects early, stays focused on outcomes, regularly steps back to see the bigger picture, acts with purpose, and takes the initiative to lead. This introduction pushes BAs to move beyond the limiting “I’m just a BA” mindset and embrace a more proactive approach that doesn’t require formal authority to make an impact.
1. The evolving role of a BA
See how the BA role has changed from working on clearly defined, waterfall projects to handling small, ambiguous initiatives with constant change. We’ll look at how design now happens alongside build, how BAs wear multiple hats, and why organisations need BAs to be leaders who can handle uncertainty rather than just task-executors. Understand the difference between working “in” versus “on” a project to maximise your value.
2. Setting up good decision-making in a project
Develop ways to establish what success looks like from day one of any project. This practical framework drives better outcomes by creating alignment, building trust, and enabling smarter decisions throughout the project. You’ll create your own set of ready-to-use success criteria that you can bring out in workshops to guide projects toward meaningful outcomes rather than just outputs.
3. Defining the pathway for problem solving
Get to grips with “definedness” – understanding where your project sits on the spectrum from well-defined to highly undefined problems. Build a playbook for tackling different types of problems, knowing when to use existing approaches, when to adapt them, and when to create new ones. This thoughtful approach buys you time while you learn more about complex problems and increases your chances of success.
4. Ensuring the right things are being worked on
Go beyond “I delivered what I was asked to” and make sure you’re not just doing things right, but doing the right things. Create a practical checklist to assess whether initiatives will truly add value, address root problems, and align with what the business can actually implement. Learn to question scope consistently and push back when necessary to avoid wasting time on projects that won’t deliver real benefits.
5. Risk tolerance / ensuring you are adding value
Find the sweet spot between risk and cost by knowing when you’ve gathered enough information to proceed. Avoid analysis paralysis by tailoring your approach based on who will be affected, what systems are involved, how easily changes can be reversed, and your organisation’s history with similar work. Design approaches that reduce the impact of mistakes, allowing for faster, more cost-effective decision-making.
6. ‘Selling’ in the decision-making process
Build a clear approach to influencing decisions through effective storytelling. Learn to establish the need for change, reinforce what success looks like, address potential barriers upfront, present your solution convincingly, and provide a clear path forward. Create decision-maker profiles to help customise your approach to different stakeholders based on whether they focus more on the journey or destination, respond to emotion or logic, and other key characteristics.
7. Other potential stumbling blocks (plus how to look after yourself!)
Understand that projects don’t exist in isolation – organisational culture, maturity, history, and competing priorities all affect your ability to deliver. Learn to assess these factors systematically and adjust your approach accordingly. Recognise your circles of influence and control to protect yourself from burnout when facing organisational barriers that can’t be changed, accepting that some challenges simply can’t be overcome!
8. Recap
Bring together all aspects of being a Next-Level BA, committing to consciously developing and applying these skills in your work. Remember that while these concepts aren’t complicated, deliberately putting them into practice will significantly improve your effectiveness and impact as a BA.
Who's the workshop for?
This course is designed for experienced Business Analysts. If you are used to working ‘in’ projects but are ready to take more control in shaping them, then this is the perfect course for you!
What will you get out of the course?
You will walk out of this workshop with some genuinely practical skills to help put you in a leadership position within a project environment (shaping the approach, and course that the project takes). 
Course structure
The course will run 1:00 – 5:00 with afternoon tea provided.
Venue
Venue is Urban Hub - Level 4 (Kent) meeting room.

events.id: Permacomputing 101-115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Permacomputing 101
events.venue: 115 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
This light-hearted talk will introduce some old, some new and some eccentric ideas for keeping computers and their software running for as long as we can. Come and learn some tricks to fight planned obsolescence and also build new things that might survive the onslaught of corporate capture. We’ll be streaming this talk from aboard a little sailboat adrift somewhere in the Pacific! No prior knowledge of computing required.
About the host, Devine Lu Linvega
Vagabond, lifelong student and co-founder of Hundred Rabbits. Currently drifting somewhere along the foggy coast of the Pacific North West. I enjoy living on the water, moving with the seasons, growing food in far flung places, and reading by the woodstove when it rains.

events.id: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks-Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington-Event Finder
events.name: Tuesday Jewellery-Making in 8 Weeks
events.venue: Workspace Studios Ltd, 65 Abel Smith St, Wellington
events.description:
Our popular weeknight classes are the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment. It starts on Tue 12 August and runs for 8 weeks until Tue 30 September, 5.30-8pm.

Beginners will focus on cabochon stone set ring. The stone setting process teaches you many fundamental techniques in one project!

We start with basic ring making in copper or brass, students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering.
Then we move on to making a practice ring set with a cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top).

Once your first setting is completed you can move to working in silver and produce another stone set ring with more interesting design elements.

Advanced: Chain Making and other projects.

Please see the link on the Regular Classes page for more detail on course content.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, up to 8 grams of sterling silver, an extra $8 for stones and fine silver and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals and materials are available for purchase in the studio.

events.id: Tales of the Unexpected - WELLINGTON-11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Tales of the Unexpected - WELLINGTON
events.venue: 11 Turnbull Street, Thorndon, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Royal Society Te Apārangi are delighted to present the 2024 Rutherford Medal winner in a special public talk.  Don’t miss this opportunity to hear from one of New Zealand’s leading researchers - this promises to be a fascinating and thought-provoking evening. 
Professor Richard Beasley CNZM FRSNZ, the 2024 Rutherford Medal winner, will highlight ten influential research programmes that have challenged long-held clinical assumptions, advanced medical knowledge, and directly influenced patient care:
Should fever be treated?
What is the optimal amount of oxygen for critically ill patients?
Are party pills safe, and do they affect driving performance?
Does smoking cannabis cause lung cancer?
Is sitting for long periods at work or during recreation a risk factor for blood clots?
Should preservatives be included in asthma nebuliser solutions?
Is ‘watchful waiting’ preferable to surgery for a collapsed lung?
What are the underlying disease processes of asthma?
What was the cause of the epidemic of asthma deaths in New Zealand?
Are adult asthma treatments suitable for children?
The answers to many of these research questions were unexpected. The research raises significant regulatory and legal issues. It also exposes the limited evidence of the benefit and safety of many fundamental approaches to the clinical management of common disorders, and the gaps in knowledge, particularly in children.
Join us for this fascinating presentation that will illustrate the unpredictable nature of research and its influence to reshape our understanding.
Biography
Professor Richard Beasley, renown academic, physician, and researcher, is the founder and director of the Medical Research Institute of New Zealand (MRINZ). Richard is committed to challenging medical dogma and increasing knowledge through undertaking high quality clinical research which has the real potential to change clinical practice and reduce the burden of disease in Aotearoa New Zealand and globally.
Alongside his role at the MRINZ, Richard is a physician at Wellington Regional Hospital, and maintains close academic links through his professorial appointments at the University of Southampton, UK, Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington, and the University of Otago. Richard was Deputy Chair of the Health Research Council of New Zealand from 2010 to 2016 and has had a longstanding medical advisory role with the Asthma and Respiratory Foundation of New Zealand, chairing the adolescent and adult asthma guidelines group. He is dedicated to workforce training, having supervised and mentored hundreds of medical research fellows over the last three decades, many of whom obtained postgraduate MD and PhD degrees and now hold prominent academic and clinical positions in Aotearoa New Zealand and around the world.
Richard is one of New Zealand’s most experienced clinician researchers, with over 780 publications, including many high impact publications in the Lancet and the New England Journal of Medicine. Richard was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit for services to medical research in 2008; elected a Fellow of the Royal Society Te Apārangi of New Zealand in 2015; awarded the Sir Charles Hercus Medal in 2016 in recognition of the impact of his research, the Beaven Medal in 2019 in recognition of his translational research, and was awarded the Rutherford Medal by the Royal Society Te Apārangi in 2024 for revolutionising the treatment of asthma worldwide.
Seats are limited, so book early to avoid missing out.

Supported by Royal Society Te Apārangi and the Medical Research Institute of New Zealand (MRINZ)

events.id: Mamma Mia!-St James Theatre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Mamma Mia!
events.venue: St James Theatre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
Gimme, gimme, gimme a night of song and dance. Mamma Mia is the ultimate feel-good show. The stage musical has been wowing audiences since 1999. It’s due to wow Wellington audiences in 2025. Based on the songs of Swedish super-group ABBA, it features non-stop laughs and explosive dance numbers. 
This sunny, funny, musical unfolds on a Greek island paradise. On the eve of her wedding, a young woman plots to discover the identity of her father. She invites three men from her mother’s past to visit the island. The result is hilarious, joyful, and soul-searching. Get ready to tap your toe to some of ABBA’s most famous songs. You’ll hear hits like Voulez-Vous, Dancing Queen, Knowing Me Knowing You, Take a Chance on Me, Money, Money, Money, and The Winner Takes It All. Filled with timeless music this show has been translated into 16 languages. 70 million people can’t be wrong. Be a super trouper and go see it.

events.id: Whānau Mārama New Zealand International Film Festival--Wellington NZ
events.name: Whānau Mārama New Zealand International Film Festival
events.description:
Lights, camera, action — the largest film festival in the country is back. Celebrating 57 years, the Whānau Mārama New Zealand International Film Festival is gearing up for 10 action-packed days in August. The annual festival presents over 150 feature films, short films, and documentaries. 
There’s always a huge and diverse selection of films to choose from. Artistic Director Paolo Bertolin and his team of film curators have scoured the world for independent, quirky, and award-winning movies. These include a politically charged near-future drama from Brazil, an Australian animated queer space opera, and a restored ‘70s horror classic. There’s also a haunting psychological drama set in remote Aotearoa. 
Paolo says these films are indicative of the energy shaping this year’s festival. They provide a taste of the adventurous and memorable stories awaiting audiences. “These films speak powerfully to the moment we are living in. They ask big questions, take risks, and remind us why cinema matters more than ever.”

events.id: Corrella Skeletons Winter Tour - Wellington-San Fran, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Corrella Skeletons Winter Tour - Wellington
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.description:
Corrella Skeletons Winter Tour - Wellington

Friday, August 15 @ San Fran- Wellington

With special guests Valley Kids

Loop, The Edge and Mai FM are stoked to present Corrella and their upcoming Skeletons Winter Tour!

After a massive summer of festivals and touring alongside L.A.B across Aotearoa and Australia, Corrella are hitting the road this August for their biggest headline tour yet — bringing their new album Skeletons to the stage for the very first time.

Skeletons marks the next chapter for the band as they continue to cement their place in the New Zealand and Australian music scenes. The album follows their breakout debut Road From 26, which featured the sleeper hit Blue Eyed Māori—a track that now holds the record for the most weeks ever spent at Number One on the NZ Singles Chart.

Since their debut, Corrella have sold out shows nationwide, become festival favourites, and picked up multiple Aotearoa Music Awards and Waiata Māori Music Awards.

This run of shows will be their biggest headline tour to date. See Corrella live as they hit the road in August for their Skeletons Winter Tour taking on Auckland's Tuning Fork, Hamilton’s Factory, Wellington’s San Fran, Christchurch’s The Church & Dunedin’s Erricks, presented by Loop. Support for each show to be announced.

Presented by Loop, Mai, The Edge, with thanks to Mānuka Phuel.

Tickets are on sale 10am Wednesday 28 March from Loop.co.nz

events.id: Explorers — The Age of Discovery with James May-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Explorers — The Age of Discovery with James May
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
Learn about famous and not-so-famous explorers from Ice Age migrations through to space travel. In ‘Explorers — The Age of Discovery with James May’, the lives of great voyagers come to life on stage. James May will unravel breathtaking tales. Explore the earliest wanderings of ancient hunter-gatherers to intrepid, often obsessive, modern-day explorers. He covers people like Leif Erikson, John Cabot, James Cook’s navigator Tupaia, Stanley and Livingstone, and Gertrude Bell. There’s also time and space for, well, time and space. Talk about moonwalkers, astronauts, and the seemingly impossible challenges of interplanetary travel. 
James May is a British television presenter and award-winning journalist. He’s best known as a co-presenter of the motoring show ‘Top Gear’. He’s also known for his charisma live on stage and on screen. His storytelling combines with some exciting theatrical techniques. He will help you traverse deserts, scale mountains, and sail into the unknown. Those with an insatiable curiosity and an unquenchable thirst for discovery will be thoroughly entertained.
The show will feature haze and room scents for an immersive event experience.

events.id: First Draft-12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: First Draft
events.venue: 12 Cambridge Terrace, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
FULL PROGRAM HERE
From 15-17 August, The Magnificent Weirdos is teaming up with writers in the early stages of creating new work to present rehearsed readings of these works in progress for the public, followed by audience kōrero with each writer/creator.

All the work is created by writers and devisers with lived experience of disability, neurodivergence, d/Deafness or mental distress.
Each work of approximately 20 minutes will be presented once over the weekend. Each reading will be followed by a 30 minute chat with the writer, facilitated by the director. It's an exciting and creative way to develop new work, both for writers, who receive feedback at an early stage, and for audiences who get to water the seed from which the fruit will eventually grow.
We will also be hosting an industry workshop led by Playmarket, leading a conversation on opportunities, processes and accessibility for new playwrights. Playwrights will need to register for this free workshop which has 20 spaces.
The whole event is NZSL interpreted. Accessible to blind/low vision folks without audio description.
You can check out the program for more details of each play, content notes and pre show information, but here's a quick glance over the weekend. Each event runs for approximately 1 hour.
15 Aug
6 pm- Cryptid Hunters of Aotearoa New Zealand by Rem Wigmore
Tensions rise when a group of friends seek the fabled Fiordland moose.
7.30pm- This is Going to Ruin the Sing-Along by Hamish Boyle
Three artists struggle to let go of the past and are unsure if they even should.
16 Aug
11 am- Playmarket hosts a workshop for writers
a conversation on opportunities, processes and accessibility for new playwrights. Free, registration required.
12.45pm- Rongo's First Day by Rahera Solomon
This wordless play follows a young Māori boy with takiwātanga as he navigates his first day at school.
3pm- Never Tried to Kill the Woman With the Golden Gun by Emma Maguire
The description is in the title! They Never Tried to Kill the Woman With the Golden Gun!
4.30pm- The Eagle Leaves a Scar by Sam Pretious
Ancient myth informs this allegory for our current times.
17 Aug
12.45pm- Forgot the Music by Ethan Rodgers
Two friends wake up in a recording studio with no memory of the night before.
3pm- As the Sun Sets by Tee Wood
A woman shares past secrets with unseen guardians of a graveyard.
4.30pm- Per Second Per Second by Shaun Swain
A time traveller must learn to trust the audience to prevent a time paradox that may/may not have/has/had/is already happened/happens/happening

events.id: Best of the Bee Gees Saturday Night Fever and the George Ellis Orchestra-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Best of the Bee Gees Saturday Night Fever and the George Ellis Orchestra
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
You’re invited to put on your boogie shoes and salute the Bee Gees album ‘Saturday Night Fever’. Released in 1977, the album defined a disco generation. Tribute act Best of the Bee Gees Saturday Night Fever and the George Ellis Orchestra come to The Opera House in August 2025. They’ll play chart-busters from that album plus songs from other bands from the 70s like K.C. & The Sunshine Band, and The Trammps. Special guests Debora McLane (niece of the Bee Gees) and Roslyn Loxton join the tribute band on stage. 
In a two-act orchestrated performance, you’ll hear some of the best songs written by the Gibb brothers. Groove along to tracks like You Should Be Dancing, Stayin’ Alive, Jive Talkin’, Disco Inferno, More Than A Woman, Warm Ride, and so much more. 
The album ‘Saturday Night Fever’ was the biggest-selling sound recording between 1977 and 1980. It was awarded Album of the Year at the 1979 Grammys and stayed in the Top 200 for 29 consecutive months. It made Barry Gibb the first solo songwriter in history to have three consecutive number ones, and four songs in the top ten simultaneously.

events.id: Adobe InDesign - Beginners-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Adobe InDesign - Beginners
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Adobe InDesign
This introduction to Adobe's InDesign program will cover: setting preferences; understanding the frame-based approach through exploration of frame creation, properties and use; placing and editing text (with styles); placing graphics; defining and applying colour and print considerations.
By the end of the workshop, you'll have been introduced to InDesign. You'll be shown the program and the main features of its desktop, and then be taken through how to create and work with the main publishing items (text and graphics) in order to create your own publication. 
Note: All computer courses are run in the school computer labs and you are required to use the school desktops for the duration of the course (you are not able to use your own laptop).  Some of the courses may require you to login onto the network. 
By the end of the course you'll be able to:
• Describe the features of InDesign and how to work with them
• Create text frames, connect text frames and format text
• Create shapes and frames and format them
• Import pictures into publications
• Use rulers, guides and the pasteboard to lay out pages
• Finish off, check and then print 
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Jewellery Making - Faceted Gemstone Settings-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Jewellery Making - Faceted Gemstone Settings
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Jewellery Making - Faceted Gemstone Settings
In this challenging and exciting workshop students will learn to set glimmering round-cut faceted gemstones into brass, copper and/or silver. Create a stone set jewellery project from a choice of simple earrings, a pendant, or a ring.
Students who have already done a Lost Wax Cast Rings class may bring their cast rings and try their hand at setting stones in those instead of starting a new project.
Students will learn ‘Flush Setting’, a method of embedding gems into the surface of metal without the need for solder or joins. The process is adaptable to a number of jewellery types and styles. Students with prior Flush Setting and soldering experience may advance to other methods and to try their hand at learning ‘Bead Setting’, or a simple form of ‘Prong Setting’.
Students may choose from lab-created Sapphires, Rubies and other high strength stones such as Cubic Zirconia in a range of colours.
The workshop is especially satisfying for the magpie in all of us, adding extra colour and shine to jewellery making.
While both beginners and returning students are welcome in the class, be aware that the tools and techniques require a level of fine motor skills, keen eye for detail, and strong hand control which take some patience, practice and perseverance to get the best results. 
Our magnifying headsets, work clamps, and patient tutor will help you along the way. 
Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if you have them.
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
Develop jewellery making skills with introductory faceted stone setting methods
Create a simple stone set project - either earrings, a pendant, or a ring.
Use Vernier Calipers to measure and calculate metal dimensions
Use files to shape brass, copper and/or silver components
Use a soldering torch to attach metal components such as jump rings
File, sand and polish brass, copper and/or silver creations into finished jewellery
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. Discover the mesmerising techniques that turn every canvas into a unique masterpiece. Dive into the world of colour theory, unlocking the secrets of blending, contrast, and harmony. Aimee, will lead you through the exciting process, helping you unleash your creative potential. But it's not just about learning – it's about having fun! Enjoy a relaxed, stress-free environment where you can experiment, laugh, and create vibrant art.

events.name: Speaking to an Audience
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Speaking to an Audience
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Build your skills and confidence in speaking to an audience, whether it’s for a work presentation, a more
formal speech, or part of a performance. In this experiential course, we’ll explore and practise skills to
be better prepared to speak, build rapport with your audience, and deliver content effectively.
By the end of the day’s session, you’ll be given:
Essential elements of a great talk—from impromptu talks to formal presentations.
Tools to prepare, organise, practice, and deliver a meaningful, persuasive, and effective
presentation.
Actions that build rapport with your audience.
Strategies to maximise the impact of your words, voice, and body language.
Mindsets and actions to reduce stage-fright and appear more confident.
Memory techniques and strategies for impromptu speaking.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

events.id: Zentangle® Method - Beginners-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Zentangle® Method - Beginners
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Zentangle® Method - Beginners
The Zentangle® method is an easy-to-learn, relaxing and fun method to create amazing images by drawing structured patterns.
In this course you will learn to make beautiful art, following the 8 steps of the Zentangle® method from a certified Zentangle teacher.
Discover your creative side, even if you think you don’t have one. You might surprise yourself!  If you can hold a pen, you can do this.
Creating Zentangle patterns is super relaxing and a creative form of mindfulness. Increase your awareness and focus, get absorbed and feel more confident while making your own unique and original art.
Learn about borders, strings, and shading. Learn your first tangles and discover the world of Crescent Moon, Hollibaugh, Printemps, and Florz. It feels great to have creativity flowing. Anything is possible one stroke at a time. There are no mistakes to make here!
After a step-by-step introduction you will take home your amazing images and have discovered a new way to relax.
All art materials are included in course fee.  Tea and coffee is available but please bring your lunch/snacks.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
-    follow the 8 steps of the Zentangle® method.
-    make beautiful structured black and white drawings.
-    explain why creating Zentangle patterns is a relaxing form of creative mindfulness.

events.id: On a Good Day - EP launch - Hihi & The Stitchbirds-167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: On a Good Day - EP launch - Hihi & The Stitchbirds
events.venue: 167 Riddiford Street, Newtown, Wellington 6021, New Zealand
events.description:
Come celebrate Hihi & The Stitchbirds' first EP - On a Good Day - an exploration of love, and loss, and the pieces in between.
7:00pm - Doors
7:30pm - The Bidibids
8:30pm - Hihi & The Stitchbirds
After a whirlwind 18 months as a five-piece folk band, Hihi & The Stitchbirds are delighted to release their debut EP with five original songs that will make you feel soothed and seen. Written by band members Tess Luff, Elena Saunders and Ellie Stewart, this group of talented musicians invite you into contemplative corners of their brains with a set of gentle and jovial numbers that will entertain and delight.
They will be joined on stage by their friends the Bidibids.
About Hihi & The Stitchbirds:
Hihi & The Stitchbirds are an exciting five-piece musical experiment, based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Pairing rich vocal harmonies with vibrant original music inspired by the folk and Americana playbooks, this band brings something for everyone.
Hihi & The Stitchbirds are:
Elena Saunders - vocals and vibes
Chris Goldsbury - guitar, clarinet and vocals
Tess Luff - guitar, banjo uke and vocals
Matt Hutton - bass uke and vocals
Ellie Stewart - fiddle and vocals
About the Bidibids:
With lush harmonies, intricate arrangements, and beguiling melodies, the Bidibids explore what it means to play folk music in New Zealand. The Bidibids are Sarah August on banjo and guitar, Simon Carryer on cello-banjo, and Brendan Schenk on mandolin and guitar. The trio came together at the 2020 Wellington Folk Festival, where they were each supposed to be playing in different groups. Since then, the Wellington-based band have become regulars at some of the region’s best venues for folk music, including the Mussel Inn, Moon, and the Wellington Bluegrass Society.
Driven by Sarah’s honest, intimate songwriting and Brendan’s blazing musicianship, the Bidibids balance soulful ballads that will tug your heart-strings with upbeat numbers which will get your toes tapping. Influenced by American bluegrass and folk bands like Watchhouse and Nickel Creek, they’re also inspired by local acts like the Eastern and Marlon Williams who are forging an authentic New Zealand folk tradition. You can listen to the Bidibids' debut EP here: https://open.spotify.com/album/6Q8HW5g0FzDl3VYz44OZU5?si=4gIRmfaRSiOUlgxJnVUbuw.

events.id: Sue Dyson - Welcome To Our Lounge Tour - 16 August-Hilltop Private House Concerts, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Sue Dyson - Welcome To Our Lounge Tour - 16 August
events.venue: Hilltop Private House Concerts, Wellington
events.description:
Featuring songs from Linda Ronstadt & Carole King
Gate opens 6.30pm Music Starts 7pm Saturday 16 August 2025
Sue Dyson, a gifted vocalist known for her warm and captivating stage presence, backed by talented pianist Mitch Dean to offer an extraordinary musical experience that celebrates the enduring legacies of Linda Ronstadt and Carole King. Set in Hilltop's laid-back intimate atmosphere, their performances promise an engaging experience where the audience will tap their feet to the classics that have defined generations. Sue has graced the stage of New Zealand's 'Good Morning Show' multiple times, showcasing her vocal prowess and musical versatility. Additionally, Sue has lent her voice as a backup vocalist at the prestigious New Zealand Music Awards and has enjoyed significant success with her original country music in Australia.
Mitch Dean complements Sue's voice with his extensive expertise as a guitarist and pianist, cultivated over more than 20 years of performing in diverse musical settings. Notably, he played keys and guitar in the acclaimed Wellington Fleetwood Mac Experience, contributing to their successful tour. Mitch’s deep understanding of music, combined with his skillful instrumentation, enriches the duo's sound and enhances the overall performance.
Together, Sue and Mitch create a harmonious blend of nostalgia and artistry, celebrating the timeless contributions of Ronstadt and King. Their performances promise to be an unforgettable evening of music that not only bridges generations but also stirs the soul, inviting audiences to revel in the rich tapestry of these legendary artists' works. Join them for a memorable experience that resonates long after the final note has been played.
Not for profit, supporting our dedicated musicians. Suggested donation $30
Teas, Coffee and Snacks provided. You're welcome to bring anything you'd like to eat or drink.
Parking available in the Coupon zones of Upland Rd & Glasgow St free after 6pm weekdays, and free all through the weekends. The Wilson Carpark at the top of the Cable Car charges 24/7.

events.id: Orangefarm and Warm Regards-Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Orangefarm and Warm Regards
events.venue: Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington
events.description:
Orangefarm and Warm Regards Live at Vogelmorn Upstairs.

Vogelmorn Upstairs comes alive on Saturday 16 August with an electric double bill featuring local favourites Warm Regards and Orangefarm.

Warm Regards is a band that epitomizes style, comfort, economy, and power — a sleek sedan equally at home on the racetrack or with the family bundled safely in the back. Blending indie rock, pop, folk, and jazz-country flair, their infectious sound and high-energy performances have earned them a dedicated local following. With frontman Tom Watson (Cassette, Terror of the Deep, HLAH) leading the charge, Warm Regards deliver introspective lyrics, tight grooves, and lush harmonies that promise an unforgettable live experience.
Orangefarm brings a distinct mix of shimmering guitars, melodic hooks, and lyrical wit that’s become their signature sound. Known for their dynamic sets and warm stage presence, the band has quietly carved out a niche as one of Wellington’s most engaging live acts.
Don’t miss this night of standout local talent in the intimate upstairs space at Vogelmorn. Doors from 7:00 PM. Music starts 8:00PM or earlier if you’re there!

events.id: Greytown Makeup Masterclass - 17.08 @9:15am-89 Main Street, Greytown 5712, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Greytown Makeup Masterclass - 17.08 @9:15am
events.venue: 89 Main Street, Greytown 5712, New Zealand
events.description:
About this event
Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.
During the class, Nikki will demonstrate step-by-step techniques on a model while you get to apply your own makeup. You'll have access to professional products and tools to follow along and create your flawless everyday look. It’s fun, interactive, and designed for all skill levels.
"I can’t wait to share my knowledge with you and help you create a makeup routine that leaves you feeling fabulous and confident every day!" – Nikki
What You Need to Know:
No equipment required! We’ll provide all makeup products, brushes, and mirrors.
Bring a willingness to learn and a positive attitude.
Classes are capped at 12-15 participants to ensure personalised guidance.
Arrive 10–15 minutes early to get settled.
Please come with a clean, makeup-free face so you can get the best results.

events.name: Chuck Chuck Baby fundraiser - Forest Aid
events.venue: 29 Wigan Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Hello! I'm inviting you all to see a touching film with me - Chuck Chuck Baby
I am fundraising to access lifesaving treatment in Spain, for a rare condition that NZ does not treat.
Please look at tinyurl.com/Forest-Aid for more detailed information about my condition and the fundraising effort.
Thanking you for the support.
I have made tiered ticket pricing for those who don't have the means to pay the full price.
There's homemade treats to be enjoyed too
About the film:
A 2023 British musical romance film, written and directed by Janis Pugh, winning two BAFTA Cymru awards in 2024 for Best feature and Breakthrough, and Official Selection at Toronto International Film Festival.
Chuck Chuck Baby is a film of love, loss and music set amongst the falling feathers of a chicken factory.
Set in present day industrial North Wales, Helen (Louise Brealey, Sherlock) spends her nights packing chickens and her days caring for a dying mother-figure Gwen (Sorcha Cusack, Father Brown).
Helen’s world takes an unexpected turn with the return of a teenage crush, from twenty years ago.
She has inner turmoil and must find the bravery to open her heart.
Book your tickets now for this bittersweet, cathartic rush of a romantic comedy-drama.
R13 Domestic abuse, sexual references, drug use & offensive language

events.id: BSLA | University of Canterbury, Cohort 5 Wellington workshop: 18th and 19th August 2025-147 The Terrace, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: BSLA | University of Canterbury, Cohort 5 Wellington workshop: 18th and 19th August 2025
events.venue: 147 The Terrace, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
This registration is for the two-day in-person workshop on 18th August and 19th August 2025 in Wellington at the James Cook Hotel Grand Chancellor.
The in-person workshop will run from 9.00am - 3.30pm both days. You must also attend a 3rd day online on 4 September OR 5 September (select one date for 3rd day session) as part of this PLD.
Catering for the in-person workshops will be provided, but this PLD does not include transport costs or accommodation.
When registering, you will need to select from one of our tailored learning options, so we can best cater our content to your role. The options are:
Option One: Class Teaching (Years 0-3) in BSLA Structured Literacy Teaching: Most suitable for teachers working with learners in Phase 1 of the ELA curriculum; year 0-3 learners.

Option Two: Class Teaching (Years 4-8) in BSLA Structured Literacy Teaching: Most suitable for teachers working with learners in Phase 2 and 3 of the ELA curriculum; year 4-8 learners.

Option Three: Literacy Leadership (Years 0-8) in BSLA Structured Literacy Teaching: Most suitable for roles with responsibility for literacy leadership and literacy support within or across schools (e.g., RTLits, RTLBs, literacy leads, SENCOs, LSCs, APs, DPs or principals).
You will also need to provide your ARN number (this was sent to your school in an email confirming your funding and looks like SLA_PLD_App-000XXXXX) to complete your workshop registration.
Our amazing team of facilitators are so excited to guide you through this PLD.

events.id: Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions-1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Porirua 5024, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Dine with a Doc - The power of plant-based nutrition and lifestyle interventions
events.venue: 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Porirua 5024, New Zealand
events.description:
Doctors For Nutrition and MTM Charity invite you to an evening of inspiration, education, and connection at our next ‘Dine with a Doc’ dinner.
Join us for a presentation on ‘The Power of Plant-Based Nutrition and Lifestyle Interventions for Preventing Chronic Disease’—an event designed to empower everyone from healthcare professionals to health-conscious community members. You will also be the first to hear about the new MTM charity, and about their mission. 
When: 6:30pm – 9:30pm, Tuesday, 19th August 2025
Where: Location: Gear Homestead, 1 Okowai Road, Aotea, Wellington
Price: $50 (includes dinner)
At this event, Dr Heleen Haitjema will take you on a journey through the clinical benefits of whole food, plant-based (WFPB) nutrition. Through easy-to-understand explanations of key concepts - such as endothelial dysfunction, intramyocellular lipid accumulation, and calorie density - you’ll discover how WFPB eating can dramatically improve health outcomes and transform lives. 
After the presentation, join us for a panel discussion and a Q&A session with Dr Haitjema and Dr Luke Wilson. 
The evening continues with a plant-based dinner curated by the chefs from MTM charity, served in the elegant setting of Gear Homestead. Enjoy the opportunity to connect and network with leading dietitians, specialists, GPs, and passionate members of New Zealand’s plant-based community.
Buy your tickets now; spaces are strictly limited!

events.id: Jenny Mitchell - The Forest House Tour-Old St Paul's, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Jenny Mitchell - The Forest House Tour
events.venue: Old St Paul's, Wellington
events.description:
Presented by Strung Out Touring

Jenny Mitchell - The Forest House Tour

After opening for Kasey Chambers around Australia, award-winning songwriter Jenny Mitchell returns home for a national tour celebrating her acclaimed album Forest House.

An Aotearoa Music Award Winner and 2 x Australian Golden Guitar nominee, Jenny is a gifted storyteller from the deep south of New Zealand. Now based in Melbourne, the AU Review describes Jenny’s music as a “sublime slice of folk” and her new highly anticipated album, Forest House, is capturing fans across the motu and the globe.

“Forest House - 10/10,” Newstalk ZB

Every so often, an artist emerges who has everything it takes to reach the pinnacle of country music success. Jenny Mitchell is a star.” Country Music Capital News

Jenny is thrilled to welcome very special guest Katie Thompson to The Forest House Tour. Hailing from New Zealand’s West Coast, Katie is a captivating alt-country artist known for her soul-stirring storytelling and rich, emotive voice. A 2024 finalist for Best Country Song, Katie has shared stages with legends like Sir Elton John and Don McLean, leaving lasting impressions with her raw honesty and polished edge.

WELLINGTON
? Old St Paul's
? Sunday 18 August
⏰ Doors open at 7pm
? Support from Katie Thompson

NZ TOUR DETAILS
SAT 17 AUGUST - Errick's Venue, Dunedin
SUN 18 AUGUST - Old St Paul's
THURS 21 AUGUST - The Piano, Christchurch
FRI 22 AUGUST - The Tuning Fork, Auckland

For more information please visit www.jennymitchell.co.nz.

ABOUT JENNY MITCHELL
NZ Best Country Artist Winner and 2 x Golden Guitar nominee, Jenny Mitchell, is a storyteller from the deep south of New Zealand with impactful songs full of grace and grit. Her last album ‘Tug of War’ included the pivotal release of the 2022 APRA NZ Best Country Song ‘Trouble Finds a Girl’ and was described by Rolling Stone as an album, “worthy of every award it will inevitably collect.”

No stranger to the road, Jenny was recently awarded a scholarship to perform at Nashville’s iconic AmericanaFest and has toured Australia and New Zealand extensively over the last decade - supporting artists including Fanny Lumsden (AU), Tami Neilson (NZ) and Nadia Reid (NZ) along the way. Her most recent touring project, The Bush & the Birds Tour, travelled throughout NZ in support of conservation organisation; Forest & Bird. An ode to her late Grandfather’s love of the land, the tour generated over $2000 in donations for Forest & Bird.

Jenny grew up in a home and family of music and often tours with her sisters, The Mitchell Twins, and country music loving Dad, Ron Mitchell. After growing up with a musical diet of The Chicks, Hank Williams and Dolly Parton, Jenny penned her first songs at the age of 11 after a trip to Ireland where she connected with her Irish heritage and explored the immigration story of her Irish born Grandparents. A few years down the track, Jenny performed original work on the TV show New Zealand's Got Talent, was placed 3rd and went onto crowdfund and release her first album at the age of 15. In 2017, she was crowned the overall winner of the NZ Gold Guitar Awards which kickstarted the professional chapter of her career, leading to her Aotearoa Music Award Winning album 'Wildfires’ produced by Tasmania’s Matt Fell.

With a sound that No Depression describes as, “poetry that dominates a beautiful melody,” Jenny Mitchell is comfortable with a country twang or softly spoken ballad and is rapidly capturing fans across the globe.

events.id: Kiwibank business insights: The commercial advantage of sustainability-level 8/20 Customhouse Quay, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Kiwibank business insights: The commercial advantage of sustainability
events.venue: level 8/20 Customhouse Quay, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
“ 60% of consumers are now actively investing time and money in brands that do good, while nearly half have dropped products over environmental impact” (Kantar Better Futures 2025) 
Discover how sustainability can drive profits, reduce costs, and open new markets.
In today’s economic climate, businesses are under more pressure than ever to cut costs, stay competitive, and grow revenue. The good news? Embracing sustainability can help you do just that.
Co-hosted by Kiwibank, WellingtonNZ and the Sustainable Business Network (SBN). At this practical and business-focused event you’ll learn how smart sustainability strategies can help your business thrive. From reducing energy bills by electrifying your operations, to winning new customers by reporting on your emissions, sustainability is no longer just the right thing to do; it’s a commercial advantage.
What to expect:
Insights from the Sustainable Business Network on the real, bottom-line benefits of sustainability
A keynote from Mike Casey, Founder of Rewiring Aotearoa, on how electrification is helping Kiwi businesses cut costs and future-proof against rising energy prices
Real-world examples and tips you can apply now
The opportunity to connect with other business leaders tackling the same challenges
About the hosts
At Kiwibank, we're proud to be B-Corp certified, joining a global movement of businesses committed to balancing purpose and profit. Sustainability is core to how we operate—from reducing our own carbon footprint to helping Kiwi businesses fund their low-emissions future. We’re investing $2 billion in sustainable finance by 2030 and offering tools to help our customers track and cut their emissions. As a purpose-led bank, we’re here to back businesses that are building a better Aotearoa.
WellingtonNZ is the Economic Development Agency for the Wellington region, supporting businesses to grow, innovate and thrive. WellingtonNZ is committed to building a sustainable region - supporting initiatives that protect the wellbeing of the people and environment, both now and in the future. 
SBN supports a network of more than 400 organisations working towards a future where people and nature thrive.

events.description:
Most professionals think they have a time problem. But what they actually have… is an energy problem.
You know the feeling—your calendar’s full, your to-do list is endless, and no matter how many apps, planners, or productivity hacks you try, the results never quite stick. It’s exhausting. And it’s costing more than you think—in clarity, performance, and profitability.
Here’s the truth: Time management is outdated. Energy management is the new competitive advantage.
Join us for a game-changing 2 hour workshop designed for business owners, general managers, and high-performing teams who are ready to lead with energy, not just effort.
 In this hands-on session, you’ll:
✅ Crack the Code on Productivity Fatigue
Understand why managing your energy—not just your time—will shift how you work (and feel) every day.
✅ Map Your Personal Energy Rhythm
Discover your natural performance peaks and dips so you can schedule smarter and get more done—without working longer hours.
✅ Stop the Drain Before It Starts
Learn how to spot hidden energy leaks and implement quick, sustainable strategies to prevent burnout and stay focused.
This isn’t another time management talk. It’s a reset button.
Because when you align your work with your energy, everything changes: your clarity sharpens, your creativity flows, and your leadership becomes magnetic.

events.id: Take Up Space - HAMILTON - Any gender-Hamilton-Humanitix
events.name: Take Up Space - HAMILTON - Any gender
events.venue: Hamilton
events.description:
Is self-doubt is making your life small?
Self-doubt is exhausting because you’re busy second guessing yourself the whole time. And while you do that, you’re missing out on the chance to say what you really mean and be who you really are.
Maybe some of these things sound familiar?
You don’t feel you’ve the right to pursue your dreams
You don’t have the confidence to speak up and share ideas
You’d love to dress differently but you’re scared what people will say.
You feel the ‘professional’ person you are at work isn’t the real you.
You’re doing what’s expected of you, but it feels like you’re leading someone else’s life.
No more. You only get one life. It’s time to take up space.

This workshop is for you
If lack of confidence is holding you back
If you’re struggling with leadership
If you’ve been told you’re too much

What we'll cover in the workshop
Build a foundation that’ll empower you to take risks, overcome fear and self-doubt, and do the things you’ve always wanted to do. Here’s some of the great stuff we’ll cover.
Trust yourself. Change the way you think and feel about yourself.
Deal with challenges. Become more resilient whatever life serves up.
Lead authentically. Become the sort of leader who helps others take up space too.
Go for your dreams. Learn how to go after what you want in life.
A fun day of laughter and connection for anyone who wants to explore how they can take up more space in the world. Be less apologetic and less self-conscious. Feel confident knowing you can stand comfortably anywhere you choose.
9:00am start
Lunch included
3:00pm finish & head for a drink
Everyone welcome. No more of this diminutive bullshit. Take. Up. Space.

Move past self-doubt into self-confidence
We’re running this workshop because we meet so many people hiding away, playing small, not standing in their full power.
And it breaks our heart that so many people can’t see how brilliant they are.
Partly that’s because in New Zealand it’s a bit dirty to be proud of yourself. We say fuck that. But often it’s more. Maybe people who should have backed you cut you down and you’ve internalised their BS ever since.
But that’s enough. It’s time to take up space.

Ticket price
$299 + booking fee
Everyone welcome. Lunch included.
Meet your irreverent badass hosts
Miraka (Shelly) Davies
Described as the lovechild of Brené Brown and P!nk, aged 37, Shelly walked away from her family’s five-generation commitment to conservative Christianity and started the exploratory period of her life, also known as “fucking shit up.” A people pleaser in recovery, she infiltrates organisations on the pretext of giving writing training and subverts teams to question the rules, while using her hard-won lessons in badassery to inspire you to know yourself, love yourself, find power, and have joy.
Belinda Thomas
The Veuve Cliquot of the professional development world, with a bag of Bluebird chips on the side, Belinda is expert in the neuroscience of success but gives few fucks about corporate bluster. Growing up on a Hawkes Bay sheep farm, she’s as comfortable sitting at a boardroom table as she is having tequila shots off the back of a ute at your local A&P show. She’s raised two amazing humans, taught Shelly to swear, has an intimate relationship with her boat, and lives to give mediocrity the bird.

events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Social Media Marketing for Small Enterprises: Visual Impact
Whether you are just starting out or already running a business, having an online and social media presence is essential. While most of us know in theory that we need a marketing plan, a social media strategy, a consistent post schedule, and engaging reels for TikTok, the reality is that every business is unique, and your approach should reflect that.
 One constant across all online presences is the importance of visuals—photographs, images, and graphics. With attention spans shorter than ever, your audience will move on within seconds if they are not engaged—they see images first and then only start reading the text. If you can't captivate their attention, you risk losing potential customers. Generic and overused stock images, or AI-generated visuals, can do more harm than good, even if they seem like an affordable option.
 In this course, we will explore different types of content suitable for your specific needs and audiences, how to create it or where to source it, how to develop the right visual strategy for your online presence, what tools to use, and how to implement it immediately. By the end of the course, you will have an outstanding online presence.
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo id when you attend the workshop.
 By the end of the four-week course, you’ll be able to:
 Recognise the critical role of visuals in social media marketing.
Choose the most effective type of visual content for your brand.
Produce high-quality, engaging visuals using various tools and techniques.
Implement a cohesive visual strategy across multiple social media platforms.
Assess and refine your visual strategy to maximise engagement and build trust with your audience.

events.id: Sachi | Wellington-San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: Sachi | Wellington
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.description:
One of New Zealand's most celebrated live acts, dance music duo SACHI have today announced two shows across Pōneke and Tāmaki Makaurau. August will see SACHI head to Pōneke, Wellington’s San Fran on Thursday, August 21, followed by Tāmaki Makaurau, Auckland’s Studio the Venue on Saturday, August 23. 

Tickets for SACHI’s shows in Wellington and Auckland will be available to purchase by the General Public on Tuesday, July 15 at 12pm local time.
Mastercard cardholders have special access to presale tickets in New Zealand. Mastercard Presale starts Friday, July 11 at 12pm and ends on Monday, July 14 at 12pm local. Plus, Preferred ticket access to some of the best tickets are available from Tuesday, July 15 at 1pm. Check out priceless.com/music  for details.
One NZ customers can be among the first to secure tickets during a 48-hour presale starting Friday, July 11 at 12pm. Head to one.nz/music.
 
My Live Nation members will also be able to secure tickets during the presale which commences on Monday, July 14 at 1pm until Tuesday, July 15 at 11am local time. Fans can register for access at livenation.co.nz. 
Dominating festivals not only in New Zealand but around the world, their success has even seen the pair become the first New Zealand act to play at Belgium’s Tomorrowland festival — one of the most prestigious electronic music festivals in the world.
One of the duo’s earliest champions was renowned producer Diplo. The duo, consisting of Will Thomas and Nick Chrisp, found him on the streets of Auckland, New Zealand and slipped a USB through the window of his SUV. Their efforts paid off when he soon responded and offered a coveted co-sign by playing early tracks “No More” and “Hold On” on his Diplo & Friends BBC Radio 1 Show. In the aftermath, SACHI exploded as a homegrown phenomenon, achieving two chart-topping platinum-certified singles, “No More” and “Shelter,” as well as an official remix of Lorde’s hit single “Green Light” alongside Montell2099.
Between 2016 and 2021, SACHI rolled out a series of three EPs: Lunch With Bianca, Nights With Ruby, and Breakfast With Ella, amassing more than 50 million streams across the trio of projects. Each of the EPs’ title characters represents a different phase of SACHI’s discography — from their introduction on Lunch With Bianca, to establishing themselves internationally on Nights With Ruby (created while living in LA pre-pandemic), to the full-circle evolution of their most refined and lustrous body of work to date, Breakfast With Ella. While each project takes listeners on an eclectic journey traversing club-ready BPMs from dazzling four-on-the-floor disco-house rhythms to euphoric powerhouse dance-pop hooks, the thread tying each installment of the celebrated trilogy together is found in SACHI’s intention to create dance music whose emotion is as convincing as its ability to make you move.
2023 saw SACHI tour their headline show across their home territory to sold-out crowds and introduced “CLUB SACHI” — a sold-out three-date 360 club experience for fans. Collaborating closely with Human Person, the LA-based creative house behind Swedish House Mafia, SZA, and Billie Eilish’s touring live shows, SACHI’s live show has been elevated to surreal new heights. “Ever since we started making music, we wanted to create moments to share with friends,” the boys explain. “We want to give everyone an uplifting and euphoric experience. Our music paints this picture of different energies coming together as a whole.”
After back-to-back New Zealand festival headline sets this past summer, SACHI are working towards their highly anticipated new music, which promises to return to the heart of their rave-oriented roots while always continuing to keep their audience guessing — they might even get a sneak peek of this magic during these upcoming tour dates.
SACHI - WELLINGTON AND AUCKLAND AUGUST 2025 
 Presented by Live Nation and George FM
SAN FRAN, WELLINGTON                      THURSDAY, AUGUST 21
STUDIO THE VENUE, AUCKLAND         SATURDAY, AUGUST 23

events.id: LHPC Antenatal Class 8 2025-12 Britannia Street Lower Hutt, Wellington 5012-Event Brite
events.name: LHPC Antenatal Class 8 2025
events.venue: 12 Britannia Street Lower Hutt, Wellington 5012
events.description:
Welcome to Lower Hutt Parents Centre, where parenting is everything.We are a group of parents helping new parents in our community. Lower Hutt Parents Centre ispart of a national voluntary-led, not-for-profit organisation who provide high quality ChildbirthEducation Classes (Antenatal Classes), Baby & You Classes and other Parent EducationClasses for Hutt Valley families.
CHILDBIRTH EDUCATION
Pregnancy and parenthood can be an exciting but daunting time! We are here to help. Our comprehensive Antenatal Classes lead by qualified Childbirth Educators will help you prepare for labour, birth and the early days with a newborn.
All Childbirth Education classes and Parent Education classes are held at St Augustine's Church Annexe (Britannia St, Petone). Each Childbirth Education course runs for six weeks, one evening per week, from 6.45pm - 9.15pm. From time to time a 'weekend intensive' course which runs for two full days is held on consecutive Saturdays.
Courses cost $220 (including booking fee)
The course covers:
• Nutrition and exercise during pregnancy
• Labour signs and stagesWe
• Pain relief options and interventions
• The birth process
• Breastfeeding and newborn care
• Transition to Parenthood and practical parenting
• A tour of Hutt Hospital maternity unit, either physical or virtual tour
We encourage you to enrol early to ensure you get a spot. We limit course numbers to 13 couples. In order to enrol, you must complete our registration form, and make payment for the course.

events.id: 2025 Big Breakfast & Charity Auction for Big Brothers Big Sisters-42 Udy Street, Petone, Lower Hutt 5012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: 2025 Big Breakfast & Charity Auction for Big Brothers Big Sisters
events.venue: 42 Udy Street, Petone, Lower Hutt 5012, New Zealand
events.description:
Join Big Brothers Big Sisters of Wellington and Guest Speaker Glen Denham on Friday 22 August at the Petone Club, Udy Street, Petone for a delicious buffet breakfast, exciting live auction, raffles and more!
Glen Denham is the Principal of Wellington College, where he channels his lifelong passion for teaching and school leadership. Raised in a single-parent home, Glen's experiences growing up shaped his resilience and drive to succeed. Throughout his distinguished career, he has accumulated a wealth of diverse experiences, each adding a unique dimension to his approach to education.
Before transitioning into teaching, Glen was a national basketball player, earning a spot as a Tall Black for 16 years during the 1980s and 1990s. As team captain for 13 of those years, he was regarded as one of New Zealand’s top players and a key figure in the country's basketball legacy. His journey from professional athlete to educator has shaped his dynamic leadership style, blending discipline, resilience, and teamwork with a deep commitment to nurturing youth.
All proceeds from this event stay in your community and support Big Brothers Big Sisters of Wellington so don’t forget to have your bids ready for the exciting live auction.
Doors open at 6.30 am, for a 7.00 am start.

events.id: Ash Grunwald at St Peters Village Hall-Beach Road, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Ash Grunwald at St Peters Village Hall
events.venue: Beach Road, Paekākāriki 5034, New Zealand
events.description:
"Grunwald's performance was more than just a gig; it was an experience - a testament to his prowess as a live musician." - Bugle Ap Geringong
"Whoever said men can only do one thing at a time have never seen Ash Grunwald play."  The Rock PIt
"Grunwald is a showman who rises to another level when performing live" -The Music
Rolling Stone Australia: Praised Ash's innovative approach to blues music, calling him a "blues modernist" pushing the genre's boundaries.
The Sydney Morning Herald: Described his shows as "crowd-frenzied" with a signature sound that "captures the soul of blues and the heartbeat of modern music."
Rhythms Magazine: Named Ash one of the most important voices in Australian blues.
Australia’s premier bluesman embarks on his first ever full length tour ofNew Zealand!
Renowned for his electrifying live shows, Ash Grunwald has inspired a generation to hit the road in an old van to ‘surf by day jam by night’.
The festival favourite brings a high energy, vibrant live show with stacks of guitars and foot stomping blues. Part troubadour, part storyteller -Ash has been selling out shows all over the world!
Don’t miss this chance to see live blues music at it’s finest!
Enshrined by Australian folklore, live on stage, Grunwald rocks the house yet touches the soul, serving a tsunami of dance, beats, roots, bass ‘n’ blues. He has supported legends James Brown, The BlackKeys, Jack Johnson, Xavier Rudd, and Keith Urban, among numerous others, and played sold out festivals across Europe, Japan, and North America.
With six Australian Top-50 albums to his credit, alongside five ARIA and four AIR Award Nominations, two APRA Awards, and gong for BestInternational Act at the LA Music Critic Awards in 2014, Grunwald is cast in bronze among Australia’s most successful blues musicians.

events.description:
Relive some of the best anthems of the 80s and 90s. The Bruce Springsteen Experience is a show dedicated to honouring the timeless music of Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band. Featuring a nine-piece band, this electrifying performance will deliver a brilliant blend of live music and visuals. 2025 marks the 50th anniversary of the release of Bruce’s iconic album ‘Born to Run’.  This tribute concert will perform the album in its entirety, along with a selection of The Boss’s greatest hits. 
Enjoy all his best songs like Thunder Road, Jungleland, She’s the One, Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out, and plenty more.

events.id: The Morning Shift — Is That Us!?-Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: The Morning Shift — Is That Us!?
events.venue: Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
Real people and real talk. That’s what the three creators of The Morning Shift offer. Jordan Vaha’akolo, Brook Ruscoe, and Marc Peard have been having a yarn on their podcast five days a week for two years. They talk about culture, entertainment, and sports. It can be funny and thought-provoking. Now they’re taking the podcast on the road and visiting Wellington’s Michael Fowler Centre. You can expect all the stuff you’re used to: deep kōrero , big laughs, and a few tears. It’s also likely there’ll be some spontaneous (and questionable) singing. 
From humble beginnings in a garage, The Morning Shift has had an amazing rise to the upper reaches of the podcast charts in Aotearoa. The trio’s brand of humorous and honest musings has earned them thousands of daily listeners. Rally the crew, book the babysitter, and get ready for a night that promises to shift you. As Jordan says, “I want people to leave with laughter still in their belly and hope in their hearts. Lessspushhhh.”

events.id: Barista Champs 2025 - attendees FREE-836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt Central, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Barista Champs 2025 - attendees FREE
events.venue: 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt Central, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand
events.description:
Come along and watch the NZ Barista Championship. This truly is the main event for Baristas in New Zealand.
Coffee connoisseurs are welcome to witness the search for the country’s top barista at the Meadow Fresh Aotearoa | NZ Barista Champs 2025.
New Zealand's most talented baristas will be brewing to win the national title in Upper Hutt on Saturday 23 and Sunday 24 August. They are also in the running to win “The People’s Champion” where you can be the judge.
Onstage, each barista will give a 15-minute demonstration scored on the taste of beverages served, cleanliness, creativity, technical skill, and presentation. Competitors each prepare four espressos, four milk drinks, and four original signature drinks to exacting standards set to their own music.
The “signature drink” allows baristas to stretch their imagination and the judges’ palates to incorporate a wealth of coffee knowledge into an expression of their individual tastes and experiences.
After two days of competition, the barista named Aotearoa Barista Champion 2025 will win flights and accommodation to represent New Zealand at the World Barista Championship 2026, in Panama.
🌏 With Thanks to Our Principal Sponsor – Meadow Fresh
Supporting the journey from Aotearoa to the world stage:
Champion: 🏆 $2,000 to assist with world travel, training, and practice milk
(Ambassador role with Meadow Fresh to be confirmed)
Runner-Up: 🥈 $1,000
Third Place: 🥉 $500
Proudly backing excellence in specialty coffee and the incredible baristas who drive it.
🎉 The People's Champion
Walks away with bragging rights, assorted goodies, and a bar tab — because the people will always have their own champion.

___________________________________________________________________________________________
The World Barista Championship organization (WBC) has licensed The New Zealand Specialty Coffee Association (NZSCA) to run the New Zealand Barista Championships from 2008 into the future.
NZSCA is committed to running the event in close accordance with WBC standards. Our focus is on producing a field of finalists capable of competing successfully at an international level, and of course, a winner who can excel at the world finals.
Dates and venue: Expressions Arts and Entertainment Centre, 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt
Saturday 23 August – National heats 
Sunday 24 August – Final
___________________________________________________________________________________________
Competitors, trainers, mentors, and judges, make sure you read up on the WBC Rules, Scoresheets, and Code of Conduct.
Machines: La Marzocco, 2 group, Linea PB the temperate of the two group machines, as per the rules, is set at the mid-point between 90.5 - 96c. The baskets are 17g La Marzocco precision baskets. 
Grinder: Hey Cafe Buddy
Code of Conduct and NZBC Rules.
Follow updates of the championship on Facebook, Instagram, and our newsletters
Any curly questions regarding the champs? Contact emma@nzsca.org at 021 415 810
------------------------------------

events.venue: 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt Central, Upper Hutt 5018, New Zealand
events.description:
Ticket sales will open Monday the 28th April 9am for all. 
Entry: Places to compete, member company $400 + GST & Non-Member $500 + GST
-------------------------------------
The Road to the Aotearoa Barista Champs 2025
The main event — the Aotearoa Barista Champs 2025 — will take place this October, four months after the regional competitions.
You do not need to compete at regionals to enter Nationals; however, spots to compete are limited. Priority will be given to the top four competitors from each regional event, who will have first access to entry.
🏅 Regional Champions automatically secure a place at Nationals as part of their prize package.
🥈 2nd to 4th place finishers will also have spots reserved for them and receive 50% off their entry fee.
These reserved spots must be claimed via a special entry channel before general entries open on the 28 April. Details on how to register will be shared directly with place-getters after each regional event.
Who Will Be Crowned the Aotearoa Barista Champion 2025?
This is New Zealand’s most prestigious coffee competition — the pinnacle of barista craft, skill, and passion.
The winner will go on to represent Aotearoa at the World Barista Championship 2026, with flights and accommodation included as part of the prize.
With Thanks to Our Principal Sponsor – Meadow Fresh
Supporting the journey from Aotearoa to the world stage:
Champion: 🏆 $2,000 to assist with world travel, training, and practice milk
(Ambassador role with Meadow Fresh to be confirmed)
Runner-Up: 🥈 $1,000 contribution
Third Place: 🥉 $500 contribution
Proudly backing excellence in specialty coffee and the incredible baristas who drive it.
The People's Champion
Walks away with bragging rights, assorted goodies, and a bar tab — because the people will always have their own champion.
------------------------------------
The World Barista Championship organization (WBC) has licensed The New Zealand Specialty Coffee Association (NZSCA) to run the New Zealand Barista Championships since 2008 into the future.
The NZSCA is committed to running the event in close accordance with WBC standards. Our focus is on producing a field of finalists capable of competing successfully at an international level, and of course, a winner who can excel at the world finals.
If you are keen to compete, there are a few things you should consider. Running to the WBC standards is time-consuming and means we can put only 20 contestants through in a day. If there are more than 20 entrants for the championship, we will conduct a selection process, awarding entry to those competitors we consider best able to excel in competition conditions. Information provided by entrants at the time of entry is essential to help us make a sound selection.
Dates and venue: Whirinaki Whare Toanga Arts and Entertainment Centre, 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt
Saturday 23 August – National heats
Sunday 24 August – Final
Competitors, trainers, mentors, and judges, ensure you read the WBC Rules, Scoresheets, and Code of Conduct.
Machines: La Marzocco two group Linea PB.  Per the rules, the two group machines' temperatures are set at the mid-point between 90.5 - 96c. The baskets are 17g La Marzocco precision baskets. Other than the practice times that will be noted on the schedule, there are no practice times available or time on the machine on-site or in the Wellington region.
Grinders: Hey Cafe Buddy

events.id: NiBS 2025 Round 4 - Wellington-235 Willis Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: NiBS 2025 Round 4 - Wellington
events.venue: 235 Willis Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Get your gains in the capital for the NiBS grand finale. NiBS at Faultline in 2024 was the biggest climbing event ever in NZ so don’t miss out.
Major format update for 2025 - please read the rules and info page!
Start and Finish Times
Participants can choose from one of four main rounds on Saturday, or the Youth Round on Sunday morning.
Saturday 9.30am - 11.30am - registration opens 9am
Saturday 12pm - 2pm - registration opens 11.30am, or
Saturday 2.30pm - 4.30pm - registration opens 2pm, or
Saturday 5pm - 7pm - registration opens 4.30pm
Sunday 9am - 11am - registration opens 8.30am (Youth Round)
Finals will be at approximately 7.30pm for the top 5 female and top 5 male entrants after the Saturday main rounds.
Sunday Youth Round
The Sunday Youth round will be open only to competitors in the U11, U13, and U15 categories and any parents/caregivers who prefer to climb in the same round as their kids.
U11, U13 & U15 participants can only climb in the Sunday Youth round and will require an adult (who can be climbing) to help keep them safe and record their scores on their behalf.
Adults who aren't parents/caregivers can't climb in the Sunday Youth round.
We will run prizegiving for the U11, U13 and U15 categories at the end of the Sunday Youth round. Caregivers climbing in other categories (Opens, Masters, Veterans) will still qualify for series points, but if you want to make the podium you’ll need to climb in a Saturday round as prizegiving will be held for these categories before the finals at 7pm.
Registration Fees
$30 for NZAC members with ID
$40 for everyone else
Preregistration and payment is required to confirm your place as the events regularly sell out - don’t leave it to the day of the event!
