events.name: Faith-Based Practice PD Day
events.venue: 136 Randwick Road, Moera, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.description:
"Ko te Wairua Tapu te Puna o te Hauora": the Holy Spirit is the wellspring of wellbeing.
All welcome to a day growing our faith-based counselling competence and bicultural relationships.
Learn from the Te Kakano o te Aroah team about their approach to Māori mental health: with Rev. Te Tokaia Nohotima and Molly Raupi Kino.
Reflect on your theology of counselling with Revs Diane Gilliam-Weeks and Reg Weeks
Be part of NZCCA's bicultural journey and learn about our new name: Te Rōpū Tohutohu Karaitiana o Aotearoa
Be refreshed in worship and prayer and friendship.
Cost is $65, including lunch.
1/2 price for students!
This is a training event of the Wellington branch of Te Rōpū Tohutohu Karaitiana o Aotearoa, New Zealand Christian Counsellors Association.
Diane and Reg are both Presbyterian ministers, based in Eastbourne. Between them they bring rich experience in ministry, chaplaincy, Spiritual Direction, supervision and leadership. They will lead an afternoon session with us, reflecting on:
1. What does it mean to be a professional with faith?
2. What tools are in the box of our practice and in our clients’ lives that can contribute to wholeness?
3. What unhelpful beliefs might need to be brought into the light for the benefit of our clients?
Photo is of the Baptism font at Te Kakano o te Aroha Presbyterian Church, Moera, Lower Hutt.

events.id: Jewellery Making - Vintage Silver Charms-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Jewellery Making - Vintage Silver Charms
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Whether you want to commemorate a special occasion, make friendship bracelets with your BFF, or craft a unique gift, you’ll come out of this workshop with jewellery to be treasured for years to come. You’ll not only produce fantastic charms but gain essential silversmithing skills such as soldering, shaping and polishing, as well as learning top tips for how to create stunning and meaningful jewellery on a budget.
 This workshop is ideal for both beginners and those returning to further develop their skills. Charm bracelets are back in fashion and these make wonderful gifts for any occasion.
 Everything you need is provided to make up to 3 silver charms. You can bring your own bracelet to adorn with the charms you make, or if you choose you can purchase one of our top-quality NZ made silver bracelets directly from the tutor in class ($25 cash please if you wish to purchase a bracelet).
 By the end of the course you’ll be able to:
Design and create a set of 3 silver charms using fine jewellery-making techniques
Use a jeweller’s saw to cut sheet silver into simple shapes
Use jeweller’s files and sandpapers to refine silver forms hammers and steel punches to imprint letters, symbols and textures into sheet silver
Use jewellery pliers to bend silver hoops and/or a soldering torch to connect charms to your bracelet
Use polishing tools to shine and finish your silver jewellery creations
Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby.  Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Junk Journaling-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Junk Journaling
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Junk Journaling
Do you have boxes and drawers full of 2-dimensional items that are special to you but you don’t know what to do with and never really look at? Turn them into a work of art by creating a junk journal!
A junk journal is a book that is handmade from recycled materials and ephemera. Instead of discarding items from your everyday life, give them new meaning and purpose in this altered book. You will come away from this experience with a completed junk journal full of fun embellishments and surprising elements. You will also learn skills and techniques to continue making journals as a mindful activity, for crafting with friends, or to make a gift for someone that is tailored to include the things they love!
These journals are a wonderful way to showcase special moments, celebrate your favourite hobby, person or place and organise your loose items into a beautiful book. They are an excellent visual aid if you are learning a language, planning a holiday or keen to take your photo albums to the next level!
Journaling supplies will be provided, sourced locally from recycled materials.
Please bring along any photos or small 2D mementos you may wish to include in your journal, scissors suitable for cutting paper, a ruler, a pen and a glue stick.  If you have a hole punch, stapler and coloured felt pens or pencils, you are welcome to bring these along as well. Please note mementos need to be flat enough to include in a book.
Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.description:
Makeup Makeover for Mature Skin
Aimed at beginners, we’ll look at basic skincare, choosing colours that suit your complexion and skin and how to apply makeup to create a professional look. There’ll be a demonstration to start with followed by a practice where everyone will get a chance to try out makeup colours and techniques.
 By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
-  Select appropriate makeup and colours to achieve your desired look
-  Apply makeup and use techniques demonstrated  
-  Remove your makeup entirely
-  Maintain and clean makeup utensils professionally
Makeup included but a list of what else to bring will be emailed when workshop numbers are confirmed (approx. cost $40 depending on what you have already at home).

events.description:
Patterns from Favourite Garments
Love a piece of clothing but can't find a pattern?  Bring along clothes you want to take patterns off and learn some useful tips and sizing rules. You'll make a pattern for at least one garment and get help on how to get going with others.
A list of what else to bring will be sent out when course numbers are confirmed. Tea and coffee provided but bring your lunch.

events.id: The English Locust & Antü Mãrama Play The Shed-46a Victoria Street, Alicetown, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: The English Locust & Antü Mãrama Play The Shed
events.venue: 46a Victoria Street, Alicetown, Lower Hutt 5010, New Zealand
events.description:
The English Locust is the folk/blues solo project of Wellington musician Jim Bailey. The English Locust describes his sound as " Bob Dylan if he was goth", fusing the melancholy poeticism of groups like the Smiths and Joy Division with the musical stylings of folk and Delta Blues.
 Jim is a veteran of the Wellington Music scene, holding a bachelor's degree in commercial music. His previous band The Vermillion Poets, placed second in the national New Zealand battle of the bands in 2019 where he also won an award for best vocalist. With his current group SHE, he has released three singles to critical acclaim from NZ Music.net and was the organiser for their festival SPECTRE FEST for two years. With his solo project The English Locust, he was a regional finalist in this years Battle of the bands, being the only soloist to make it that far in this years competition. He plans to release his debut single late 2025 or early 2026. 
Antü Mārama is a musical collaboration between Paulette Mankoch Soriano (Chile), Jim Bailey (UK) Claudio (Chile), Andres del Vilar (Chile), David (Canary islands) and Catherine Ireland (NZ). The band evolved from a previous incarnation, The flying jaranas, who played primarily Son Jarocho, a traditional music from Veracruz on the East Coast of Mexico. Since then, members have come and gone, and Antü Mārama has broadened its horizons to play folk music from all around Latin America, as well as original compositions written by lead singer Paulette. The group's ethos is represented by the name - Antü is the Mabudungun word for sun, while Mārama is the Te reo Māori word for Moon. The group combines both the life-giving energy and vitality of the sun with the deeper emotions and more reflective energy of the Moon. Antü Mārama is a synthesis of the group's diverse backgrounds and musical experiences, united by a love of playing music, and a desire to share the rich folk tradition of Latin America with a local audience.

events.id: Greta O'Leary - River Dark Album Release Tour-Sacred Heart Church, Featherston, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: Greta O'Leary - River Dark Album Release Tour
events.venue: Sacred Heart Church, Featherston, Wellington
events.description:
This August 23rd join alt-folk songwriter Greta O'Leary (trio) for one intimate and special show at Sacred Heart Church, Greytown, performing O’Learys debut record 'River Dark'.

‘A folk-rooted aesthetic that feels almost gothic’ (RNZ).

Taking her brand new album on tour for the first time this winter, Greta O'Leary performs 'River Dark' across the motu in celebration of its release. 'River Dark' is O'Leary's debut. ‘Tender, steadfast and unraveling’, it shot to #9 on the Aotearoa Official Albums Chart, features the SRN #1 singles 'Baby I'm a Singer' and 'Baptised at the Desktop Computer' and has been featured by RNZ, the SRN and Rolling Stone Magazine. O’Leary will be joined in Pōneke by her trio, Amy Borovich (HINA, Anna Coddington) and Nava Tekela-Pule (Erny Belle, LEAO).

Tāmaki Makaurau singer-songwriter and musician GRETA O'LEARY writes with clarity of vision, making introspective observations that seamlessly interlock with her spare, spacious and enthralling songcraft. Through soaring instrumentation, astute and occasionally absurd lyrics of self-reflection and her poignant voice, her debut is ‘slightly spooky, wryly funny, and expertly written’ (Tony Stamp).

Celebrated local songwriter GRETA O'LEARY is releasing her highly anticipated debut album RIVER DARK. The obscure, dreamlike record was created alongside producer Jol Mulholland at LAB Studios, with Greta's hypnotic songwriting and unmistakable vocals accentuated through the skillful musicianship of instrumentalists Cass Basil (Tiny Ruins, The Veils), Alastair Deverick (Boycrush), Callum Passells (Hans Pucket) and Anita Clark (Motte). Listeners are invited deeper into Greta’s immersive and enthralling world.

“My first record, a collection of personal, ridiculous and truth telling songs. It took a long time to get here. I was a child shy and unclear, completely confused, absolutely not onboard with future, with goals or activity. I was in the field below the house, I was at the pond with the dog, I played make believe longer than most. I was taught to be quiet.”

*****************************************

River Dark the album - https://music.drm.co.nz/river-dark

Baby I’m a Singer Music Video (Greta O’Leary) -
https://youtu.be/Wjy8xmq6JKs?si=c5xnXtxQ6-Yfzk5x

events.id: The Wellington City Shake-em-on-Downers-Rogue and Vagabond, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: The Wellington City Shake-em-on-Downers
events.venue: Rogue and Vagabond, Wellington
events.description:
From amidst the wreckage of our capitalist wasteland they rise, like a phoenix soaring through a bowl of molasses... The Wellington City Shake-em-on-Downers ARE BACK proving themselves to be the most resilient life form on the planet, giving even the cockroaches a run for their money. Middle New Zealand's favourite dadaist swing cult phenomenon are back with a vengeance, serving up a fiery primordial soup of fresh tunes for your listening and dancing 'pleasure'. Prepare for the stupidest gags, hottest horn solos, stonkiest grooves and pea-brained banter as we reign supreme in the battle of wits and people's attention against the existential crisis rectangle, otherwise know as the iPhone. Don't miss this exuberant show, or you may regret it for the rest of your miserable life.

----------------------------------------

General Admission: $15 +BF ($20 on the door)
Students/Unwaged: $10 +BF ($15 on the door)

LIVE at The Rogue & Vagabond, Wellington - Saturday 23rd August.

events.id: Ash Grunwald tickets-Meow Nui, Wellington, New Zealand-Ticketek
events.name: Ash Grunwald tickets
events.venue: Meow Nui, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
Australia’s premier bluesman, Ash Grunwald embarks on his first ever full length tour of New Zealand!
Renowned for his electrifying live shows, Ash Grunwald has inspired a generation to hit the road in an old van to ‘surf by day jam by night’.
The festival favourite brings a high energy, vibrant live show with stacks of guitars and foot stomping blues. Part troubadour, part storyteller - Ash has been selling out shows all over the world!
Don’t miss this chance to see live blues music at it’s finest!
Enshrined by Australian folklore, live on stage, Grunwald rocks the house yet touches the soul, serving a tsunami of dance, beats, roots, bass ‘n’ blues. He has supported legends James Brown, The Black Keys, Jack Johnson, Xavier Rudd, and Keith Urban, among numerous others, and played sold out festivals across Europe, Japan, and North America.
With six Australian Top-50 albums to his credit, alongside five ARIA and four AIR Award Nominations, two APRA Awards, and gong for Best International Act at the LA Music Critic Awards in 2014, Grunwald is cast in bronze among Australia’s most successful blues musicians.

events.id: Nurse John — Short Staffed Tour-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Nurse John — Short Staffed Tour
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
It only hurts when you laugh. The medical-themed comedy of John Dela Cruz is likely to leave you crying, screaming, and laughing. His alter-ego, Nurse John, portrays life working in the healthcare industry. The ‘Nurse John — Short Staffed Tour’ is a delightful romp through the ups and downs of caring for people. It’s proven hilariously relatable to those both in and out of the industry. 
John is a content creator and Los Angeles-based nurse. He’s amassed over 10 million followers across his social media platforms. He’s known for his positive presence online as he documents his day-to-day life. Translating online comedy into a live stage show has proved successful and he now tours regularly. Nurse John’s combination of reality, truth, and entertainment has proved a winner. He inspires millions around the world to believe that with enough caffeine, medication, and hydration…you too can make it to your next shift.

events.id: Huntress x A Lady Butcher : Whole Hog Workshop + Wine-Martinborough 5711, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Huntress x A Lady Butcher : Whole Hog Workshop + Wine
events.venue: Martinborough 5711, New Zealand
events.description:
Step into a unique fusion of skills, storytelling, and indulgence with Huntress and A Lady Butcher. This immersive event combines a hands-on butchery workshop with the luxury of wine pairing & artisan charcuterie to match. You’ll learn how these two worlds—vinification & butchery—intersect, while enjoying a curated selection of wines & charcuterie that embody the spirit of the land.
What to Expect:
Huntress Experience:
Guided by "The Huntress", Jannine Rickards, a passionate advocate for sustainable living and wild wine, you’ll be introduced to a deep, meaningful connection between the land, the food we consume, and the wines we enjoy. Shaped by a childhood spent in the hills of the Coromandel Peninsula and years of honing her skills in the Wairarapa, Jannine brings a lifetime of knowledge to the table.
This workshop is about honoring the land’s intricate balance and how that is showcased in wine. Alongside her teachings, you’ll discover how Huntress Wines reflect indigenous food-growing practices and how each bottle celebrates the connection between the land’s cycles and the wines that grow from them.
A Lady Butcher Experience:
While immersing yourself in the art of wine making, Hannah Miller Childs, aka. A Lady Butcher will guide you through the ancient craft of butchery and curing meat. She’ll show you how to break down a whole poaka before methodically curing it into what will become coppa, all the while offering valuable tips on everything from ethical sourcing to the most efficient techniques. Whether you’re a seasoned chef or a complete novice, this session will leave you with practical skills to take home—plus a deeper understanding of the land-to-table journey.
Wine Pairing:
As you absorb all the knowledge from the Huntress and Butcher, you’ll enjoy expertly paired wines throughout the experience. Huntress Wines have been carefully chosen to complement each stage of the workshop, with a focus on organic, terroir-driven bottles that reflect the spirit of the land and match exquisitely with the charcuterie selection prepared. Sip on hand-picked reds, whites, and rosés while snacking on a selection of cured meats and engaging with the instructors and fellow participants.
What to Bring:
Comfortable attire (workshop may involve handling tools and light physical activity)
An open mind and a love of new experiences
Limited Spots Available!
Join us for a memorable Sunday afternoon of skill-building, wine tasting, and a deeper connection to the land. This is a one-of-a-kind workshop that celebrates sustainable practices, the art of butchery, and the symbiotic relationship between the food we eat and the wine we drink.
Reserve Your Spot Now!

events.id: Greta O’Leary and Goodnight My Darling - River Dark Tour-San Fran, Wellington-Ticket Master
events.name: Greta O’Leary and Goodnight My Darling - River Dark Tour
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.description:
This August 24th join alt-folk songwriter Greta O'Leary & Te Whanganui a Tara artist Goodnight My Darling for one intimate and special show at San Fran, performing new and recently released works in celebration of emergence and O’Learys debut record 'River Dark'.
‘A folk-rooted aesthetic that feels almost gothic’ (RNZ). 
Taking her brand new album on tour for the first time this winter, Greta O'Leary performs 'River Dark' across the motu in celebration of its release. River Dark' is O'Leary's debut. ‘Tender, steadfast and unraveling’, it shot to #9 on the Aotearoa Official Albums Chart, features the SRN #1 singles 'Baby I'm a Singer' and 'Baptised at the Desktop Computer' and has been featured by RNZ, the SRN and Rolling Stone Magazine. O’Leary will be joined in Pōneke by her trio, Amy Borovich (HINA, Anna Coddington) and Nava Tekela-Pule (Erny Belle, LEAO).

Tāmaki Makaurau singer-songwriter and musician GRETA O'LEARY writes with clarity of vision, making introspective observations that seamlessly interlock with her spare, spacious and enthralling songcraft. Through soaring instrumentation, astute and occasionally absurd lyrics of self-reflection and her poignant voice, her debut is ‘slightly spooky, wryly funny, and expertly written’ (Tony Stamp).

Celebrated local songwriter GRETA O'LEARY is releasing her highly anticipated debut album RIVER DARK. The obscure, dreamlike record was created alongside producer Jol Mulholland at LAB Studios, with Greta's hypnotic songwriting and unmistakable vocals accentuated through the skillful musicianship of instrumentalists Cass Basil (Tiny Ruins, The Veils), Alastair Deverick (Boycrush), Callum Passells (Hans Pucket) and Anita Clark (Motte). Listeners are invited deeper into Greta’s immersive and enthralling world.

“My first record, a collection of personal, ridiculous and truth telling songs. It took a long time to get here. I was a child shy and unclear, completely confused, absolutely not onboard with future, with goals or activity. I was in the field below the house, I was at the pond with the dog, I played make believe longer than most. I was taught to be quiet.”

*****************************************

Goodnight My Darling is the vision and project of up and coming Te Whanganui a Tara based singer-songwriter Maxine Macaulay.
With elements of shoegaze, folk and dreamy melody, Macaulay says her ever evolving vibe is a poetic expression of her life and the places around her. Her songs take you on a cinematic journey, while her ethereal vocals lull you into a quiet sense of peace and appreciation.
Her 2022 nine-track self-titled album, is a mix of soul-stirring tunes including ode to love, loss and rebirth ‘The Carriage’, ‘Until I Return’ and the story of a relationship’s end in ‘The Trees Have Eyes’

Since 2022 GMD has released singles ‘Ruby’ and ‘The Empress’ speaking to creative repression, Motherhood and female empowerment.
Joining her for her first show since becoming a Mother are band Mitch Kirk, Kim Andrews, Bella Florence and Shaun Blackwell (Hemi Hemingway & John the Baptist). 
With plans to further morph and develop her experiential sound, Goodnight My Darling is certainly one to watch.

Doors: 5.30PM
Show: 6.00PM
Seated show

Ruby Music Video (Goodnight My Darling)  - https://youtu.be/hTrQ57GzfWY?si=ygDovdkrXZQhyAqe
River Dark the album - https://music.drm.co.nz/river-dark
Baby I’m a Singer Music Video (Greta O’Leary) - https://youtu.be/Wjy8xmq6JKs?si=c5xnXtxQ6-Yfzk5x

events.id: Management Essentials Training 26 - 27 August 2025-5, ANZAC House 181 Willis Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Management Essentials Training 26 - 27 August 2025
events.venue: 5, ANZAC House 181 Willis Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
The Management Essentials Training has been developed by Clubs New Zealand and is aimed at upskilling Managers who would like to improve their knowledge around compliance issues and obtain a detailed understanding of the various components clubs traditionally earn revenue from.
WHO IS IT FOR?
The course is aimed at anyone who is new to club management, moving into club management or even those who have years of experience and want to refresh their knowledge and skills.
WHAT DOES IT COVER?
The course provides numerous opportunities for discussion and to explore ideas, issues or questions participants have, some of the topics covered on the course include;
Who is Clubs New Zealand and what we can assist with via our website or in person,
Basic accounting requirements for your club – Audits, Gaming accounts, “KISS”,
Legislation that effects your club - The Sale & Supply of Alcohol Act 2012, Incorporated Societies Act, Food Bill etc.,
Gaming – best practices,
Business Partners – making them work for your Club.
HOW LONG IS IT?
Two days 
COST?
The cost of the two day course is $190.00 per person (plus accommodation and travel).

events.id: From the Shadows to the Spotlight-Level 28/100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: From the Shadows to the Spotlight
events.venue: Level 28/100 Willis Street, Wellington Central, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
An exclusive evening of leadership, transformation, and untold stories with Stew Darling - former covert operator and founder of Unstoppable Force. This is not a seminar.
It’s a call to emergence.
Join a select group of leaders ready to step beyond titles, beyond certainty, and into the next version of themselves.
Because some of us weren’t built to stay in the shadows.
5pm - Networking, canapés (provided by Everybody Eats), and drinks
5:45pm - From the Shadows to the Spotlight
This is a free event by Unstoppable Force (unstoppableforce.co.nz), with optional donation to our partners Big Brothers Big Sisters.
This event is being hosted in collaboration with Cliftons Event Solutions (cliftons.com/venues/wellington)

events.id: Wellington Leaders Day-22 Tennyson Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Wellington Leaders Day
events.venue: 22 Tennyson Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011, New Zealand
events.description:
Laidlaw Centre for Church Leadership exists to love and serve the Church of Aotearoa New Zealand by providing her leaders with the tools, support, and guidance they need to flourish. 
Join us for a one day conference as we gather with leaders from across the region to connect, be inspired and encouraged, and discuss issues relevant to the Church in Aotearoa. The event runs from 9am to 2:30pm. Morning tea and lunch is included.
Theme: Stewarding Renewal
Our 2025 Leaders Days explore emerging reports across New Zealand and the globe of increasing openness to faith in Christ, and in some cases significant growth in church attendance and baptisms, led by younger generations; and how church leaders might respond.
"In churches across society something amazing is happening, challenging long held predictions about the future of Christianity in the twenty-first century. Where we once saw ageing congregations and a steady decline in attendance, we now see dramatic growth, led by the young. Where we once saw apathy or even hostility to Christianity and the Bible we see increased openness." - Bible Society UK
In the United States a similar trend is emerging:
"Undeniably there is renewed interest in Jesus," says David Kinnaman, CEO of Barna. "This is the clearest trend we've seen in more than a decade pointing to spiritual renewal — and it's the first time Barna has recorded such spiritual interest being led by younger generations." - Barna Group, USA
On Easter Sunday in New Zealand, St Patricks Cathedral in Auckland baptized 350 people. Testimonies are emerging from churches across Aotearoa of an openness to faith, responses from people previously not interested in church, and a curiosity about Christ and Christianity among non-believers, particularly young people.
As church and Christian leaders in Aotearoa New Zealand, how might we respond in our contexts?
How could we participate in what the Spirit is doing? What does this mean for sustainability of people and programmes, and for our discipleship teams? How can we discern the best response to the opportunities presented by this context? How can we stir hunger for renewal in our time and place, without unhealthy comparison?
We are gathering leaders from across Aotearoa in four locations for a one day conference to discuss these questions. There will be opportunity to hear testimonies of renewal happening in churches in Aotearoa, and share your thoughts with other leaders as we gather — we pray you will walk away encouraged, inspired, and with fresh vision for the days ahead.
We hope to see you there!
Programme:
Session One: Emerging Renewal
More and more, stories are emerging of green shoots in surprising places: tales of people without church backgrounds turning up at church quite unexpectedly, more frequent conversations with those curious about Jesus, dramatic spiritual encounters that we could never have facilitated. There is a sense that the upheaval of Covid, global political shifts, and financial uncertainty in recent years has shifted something: the fragmentation and failure of secularism and new atheism was perhaps preparing the ground. It seems like something is happening - a quiet renewal.
What does this mean for the communities we lead? How can we, as leaders, steward these firstfruits of renewal? How can we lean in to what the Spirit is doing in our own contexts?
Session Two: Stories of Renewal
In this panel discussion, local pastors and leaders share stories of how they are seeing that God has been moving — stirring renewal and hope, unexpected shifts in discipleship and salvations, and how they are responding.
Session Three: Renewal and Fruitfulness
Time and time again throughout history, renewal has come through small communities making radical commitments to the way of Jesus. What can renewal movements throughout history teach us about renewal in our own moment? What helps? What doesn't? What does it look like to be faithful in our time and place?
Session Four: Renewal Conversations
What does it look like to steward renewal in our churches? This session focuses on practical responses to renewal and discussion around how the Church in Aotearoa can partner with what the Spirit is doing.
Speakers:
Sam Harvey, 24-7 Prayer New Zealand
Sam Harvey is the founding and Lead Pastor of Bay Vineyard Church and the National Coordinator for 24-7 Prayer NZ. He has been in full-time ministry since graduating from BCNZ (now Laidlaw) in 2003. He is passionate about coming alongside church leaders to encourage strong prayer cultures in churches. His 24-7 role gives him a front row seat to a lot of what God is doing among our churches. Sam is married to Jenn and they have three lively sons. Sam loves good food, good music and good waves. We are excited to have him with us!
Roshan Allpress, Laidlaw College
Dr Roshan Allpress has led Laidlaw College as National Principal/Chief Executive since 2017. He holds History degrees from Canterbury and Oxford, focusing on religious reform, philanthropy, and theology’s social impact. He co-founded the Compass (now Venn) Foundation and has extensive experience in non-profit leadership. Raised in Ōtautahi Christchurch, he and his wife Lottie have three children and now live in Auckland.
Local Panels
In each location we will be joined by local pastors and leaders sharing experiences of renewal from their contexts. More information coming soon!

events.name: Candlelit Concerts - it's a night out that feels good and does good!
events.venue: 87 Oxford Street, Levin 5510, New Zealand
events.description:
Step into an evening of warmth, wonder, and world-class music at our exclusive Candlelit Concert Series — a magical event that happens only four times a year.
Once each season, our beautifully historic local church is transformed into an intimate haven, softly illuminated by the glow of 200 flickering candles and a gentle wash of laser light. The result? A truly enchanting atmosphere that invites you to pause, breathe, and connect.
Before the music begins, you’ll be welcomed with light refreshments and dessert nibbles, setting the tone for a relaxing, uplifting night. Then settle in for 75 minutes of exquisite acoustic music, carefully curated to soothe the soul and spark joy.
🎟️ Limited to just 100 guests, this is a rare opportunity to enjoy extraordinary live music in a cozy, welcoming setting.
💰 Tickets: $35 each
🕰️ Doors open at 7:00pm, with music starting shortly after 7:30pm — the perfect way to unwind after dinner.
📍 Venue: Our beautifully historic local church, lovingly transformed for the night.
Guest Artists: The Kugels
Take two former New Zealand Symphony Orchestra players, a virtuoso accordionist, and a renowned bass player — and you have The Kugels!
Featuring national champion accordionist Rebekah Greig, former NZSO members Robin Perks (violin) and Debbie Rawson (clarinet), and RNZ classical and jazz expert Nick Tipping (double bass), The Kugels have been captivating audiences across Aotearoa for over 15 years.
Their music draws deeply from Eastern European traditions and beyond, with a special focus on klezmer — a genre that swings between soul-stirring melancholy and infectious joy, moving audiences to laugh, cry, and even dance in the aisles. After nationwide tours with Arts on Tour NZ and Chamber Music New Zealand, and performances at major festivals, The Kugels continue to enchant and inspire wherever they play.
Even more special, each concert helps support valuable community programmes and initiatives — making your night out one that feels good and does good.
Whether you come for the spellbinding music, the magical candlelit setting, or the sense of connection and community, we promise an evening you’ll never forget — and one you’ll want to return to, season after season.
✨ Book your tickets now and be part of this unforgettable experience. ✨
Please note: These concerts are designed for adult audiences; we kindly ask that no children under 10 attend so everyone can fully enjoy the atmosphere.

Take a walk back in time to enjoy some of the most famous music of the 60s and 70s. Creedence Clearwater Revival was a juggernaut of phenomenal proportions. From their album debut in 1968 to their last album in 1972 the band produced some highly memorable songs. Many of them are still regularly played today. The Creedence Clearwater Collective recreates the success of the original band. The Opera House stage in Wellington will come alive with a six-piece tribute band. events.id: Your Life’s Purpose – Discover Your Emotional Needs and Core Values-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Your Life’s Purpose – Discover Your Emotional Needs and Core Values
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Your Life’s Purpose – Discover Your Emotional Needs and Core Values
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
Put in the hard work on this one day Saturday workshop and experience the benefits of self-knowledge. Let the emotional knowledge you gain inform not only how you live your life but also how you feel about living it. You’ll be asking the big questions about not only how you live your life, but also why. Discover the tools and scientifically based information to inform the exploration of your life’s purpose.
Consider your emotional needs and how they relate to personal meaning. You’ll unwrap the concepts of emotional nutrition and be shown how to be guided by your values and start to think of them as a compass directing the journey of your life. To do this you’ll identify your values hierarchy and learn about how this framework can inform how you live your life. Once you can apply a spirit of consistency to your self-identified larger purpose, as well as your needs, then your life’s purpose, emotional needs and core values, will align. It’s quite a transformational day!
Bring pen and paper.  Tea and coffee provided, please bring your lunch/snacks.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Develop a Life Purpose Statement
Perform an Emotional Needs Self-Assessment
Elicit Your Core Values
Align your goals with your life purpose, emotional needs and core values
Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Bike Maintenance for Beginners-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Bike Maintenance for Beginners
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Bicycle Maintenance for Beginners
Have you recently started riding a bicycle and want to make sure you can take care of it properly? Or have you been riding for ages, but have always been scared to fix anything yourself?
Are you unsure of how to pump your tyres, or how much oil your chain needs? Find yourself fumbling for words when trying to describe that clunking sound to the guy in the bike shop?
This one day course lays bare the nuts and bolts of bicycle mechanics for absolute beginners, as well as those with a little experience. Through practical experience working with your own bicycle, you will find out what needs to be done to keep it running smoothly. We’ll cover what to look out for when things start to wear out, and how to check for problems, so you can be confident your bicycle is safe to ride. You will also learn how to fix some of the most common mechanical problems, and learn about the correct terminology and tools to use.
Those who feel intimidated in bike shops are especially welcome in this course. No question is a stupid question!
Bringing a bike to work on is essential, preferably one that you are riding regularly, because the best way to learn is by building familiarity with your own ride. E-bikes are welcome, although the extra weight can mean they are more challenging to work on. Regardless of whether your bike is in pristine condition, or desperately in need of TLC, it is welcome on the course – bikes showing a bit more wear can be useful for the learning of the whole group.
Bring your pushbike along on the day.  If you have the following, please bring them as well:  A multi-tool and pump; chain oil and rag; lightweight close-fitting gardening or rubber gloves.
Note: A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
(Please note this course is not exhaustive and is not a professional training course).
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Name most parts of a bicycle correctly
- Perform a quick safety check on any bicycle
- Fix a flat tyre
- Adjust your bike to fit your body
- Oil and clean your chain
- Identify and fix some common brake problems
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Cooking: Lentils – Types, Recipes and How to Cook Them
The lentil is perhaps the world’s most versatile and indestructible food. It has significant health benefits from lowering cholesterol to supporting weight loss – and lentils are delicious when cooked well. Enjoy this half-day course that will show you how to cook lentils properly and make the most of this nutritious staple ingredient. Discover spices to complement and enhance lentils and create some mouth-watering dishes.
All ingredients included in course fee.  Please bring your apron, a couple of tea-towels, a sharp knife and leak-proof containers to take your food home in.
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Recognise some different types of lentils.
Cook some delicious lentil dishes.
Understand some spices that will work well with lentils.
Follow simple recipes.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.name: Creative Writing - From Idea to Page
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Creative Writing - From Idea to Page
“Just write!”
That’s the advice given to every newbie writer… but what happens when you
struggle to get words on the page?
In this one-day course, we’ll brainstorm ideas, complete writing exercises and
discuss strategies for keeping up writing momentum.
Please bring pen and paper.  Tea and coffee available for your breaks, please bring lunch and any snacks you may need.  
By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Identify different brainstorming methods
- Complete writing exercises to develop ideas
- Describe your own writing process, and identify what works for you
- Apply strategies to keep up writing momentum

events.id: Knitting - Next Level-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Knitting - Next Level
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Knitting - Next Level
Build on your learning from the Beginner’s Knitting class. Come and discover tips and tricks needed to take your knitting to the next level. Learn about some of the technical aspects of knitting to better understand both the processes involved in the craft as well as the final product created. 
Learn how to read a knitting ball band and knitting pattern as well as gain a basic understanding of knitting abbreviations. Practice determining yarn weight using the wraps per inch method and the rules of substituting yarn. Learn what tension is in knitting, why it is important and how to alter it as needed. 
By the end of the course, you will have a set of notes guiding you in the basic technicalities of knitting for best practice going forward in your crafting journey.  You will have practiced the wraps per inch method, practiced a couple of techniques as outlined by knitting abbreviations and understand tension as both a principle and practical guide in the craft of knitting.
Bring pen and paper to take notes, a 30cm ruler, a pair of 4mm knitting needles and 1 ball of 4 ply yarn for practicing techniques.
By the end of the session you’ll be able to:
Read a knitting ball band
Know how to determine yarn weight using the wraps per inch method
Read a basic knitting pattern
Run through of basic knitting abbreviations (reference sheet provided)
Understand tension: what is it, why you make tension swatches and how to alter tension as needed.
Explore the rules of substituting yarn

events.id: Oil Painting Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Oil Painting Workshop
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Oil Painting Workshop
In this course we will learn about painting with oils: one of the oldest and most interesting mediums, and one which has an undeserved reputation for being slow or intimidating! By the end of this workshop you will find it to be a forgiving, easy, and even quick medium to create beautiful art with.
In this workshop we will learn some quick methods for getting started in oils, using “alla prima” (wet on wet) methods to develop an understanding of the painting process. In addition to learning about the practical side of the medium, there will also be opportunities to learn a bit about the extraordinary history of painting in oils.
Most materials included in course fee - you will need to bring your own bristle brushes and an idea for your painting.  Basic paint colours provided, you're welcome to bring along any that you may already have at home.  Please wear clothing suitable for working in a messy environment, and prepare a means of transporting your wet painting home.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
- Paint pictures quickly using ‘alla prima’ methods.
- Effectively prepare a surface for painting.
- Prepare some basic colour mixes and methods of creating tone and contrast.
- Develop transparent glazes and washes over your painting.
- Recognise the difference between pigment, binder, solvent etc.
- Discuss the extensive history of painting methods

If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.id: Women's Health and Aging Workshop-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Women's Health and Aging Workshop
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Women's Health and Aging Workshop
This course is free for NZ citizens and residents.  Please enrol online and bring photo ID when attending the workshop.
If you are not a NZ citizen or resident, a fee of $109 applies and you must phone the office on 04 385 8919 to register.
An interactive workshop presented by experienced physiotherapist Sara Dore, focusing on how movement and function can be challenging for women as they age. Particularly for women, there is more to the core than abdominal muscles and strength and we explore these broader aspects.  Most importantly, you will come to understand that movement is medicine and we can make a difference.
You will be able to make a positive difference for yourself! The objective of this workshop is to give you knowledge and understanding about how you can manage the effects on your health and wellbeing as we age as women.  Knowledge is power!
In this one-day workshop you will discover:
- The base of the pelvic floor. Anatomy of the pelvic floor, and the common conditions urinary incontinence, and pelvic organ prolapse will be discussed. Education on basic pelvic floor advice and management as well as appropriate exercises will also be covered.
- The middle deep abdominal muscles. Trunk stability versus core strength as we age and the impact on our other core muscles and pelvic floor will be discussed. The principles of Clinical Pilates versus traditional Pilates will be presented together with the key principles of movement is medicine.
-The importance of the diaphragm and breathing well will also be discussed to enhance optimal movement and function for women.
Please wear comfortable clothes and socks as this is an interactive workshop, and bring a yoga mat or beach towel.
Tea and coffee provided, please bring your lunch and snacks.
NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.
Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Zine Making - Introduction
In this workshop you will be guided in making a classic cut and fold 8-page zine from a standard A4 sheet of paper - this is a clever design you can easily photocopy and reproduce later! You will be introduced to a range of techniques and approaches such as cut and paste photos and text, collage and drawing on paper.
If you’re keen to make more zines and share them with the world, there's a broad and growing community of Zine-makers and traders, as well as the well-attended annual Wellington Zinefest!
Paper, newspapers, magazines and basic drawing materials will be provided. We recommend you bring along a sketch book and any favourite drawing materials, newspapers, magazines or other interesting paper material to cut up and collage with in class.
Tea and coffee provided, please bring your lunch.
 By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
Cut and fold a classic 8-page zine format from a single sheet of paper
Brainstorm content ideas for your personalised zine publications
Arrange & compose text and images to fit a classic 8-page zine layout
Combine cut & paste magazine content with hand drawn/ written content
Create a draft zine of your personal interests

events.id: Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Christchurch-456 Papanui Road, Christchurch-Humanitix
events.name: Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Christchurch
events.venue: 456 Papanui Road, Christchurch
events.description:
We're pleased to invite you to join us for this workshop on Building resilience and unlocking the power of the mind.
Why this matters:
In our rapidly changing world, resilience emerges as a fundamental skill. It's not just about bouncing back from adversity but confidently navigating change. Resilience enables individuals to navigate uncertainty with confidence and adaptability. This 90-minute workshop delves into the profound significance of resilience, offering participants practical insights and actionable strategies to cultivate resilience and harness the potential of the mind. By equipping individuals with these tools, the workshop empowers them to not only weather storms but also thrive in dynamic environments.
What to expect:
During this interactive workshop, participants will explore the core concepts of resilience and the mind-body connection through engaging discussions, experiential exercises, and practical demonstrations. They will learn evidence-based techniques to enhance their resilience, manage stress effectively, and cultivate a positive mindset amidst adversity. By the end of the session, attendees will emerge with a comprehensive toolkit to fortify their mental resilience and embrace change with confidence.
Who this is for:
This workshop caters to individuals across all organisational levels who are eager to enhance their resilience and cultivate a resilient mindset. Whether you're an owner, manager, chef, senior staff member, or junior employee, this workshop offers invaluable insights and practical strategies to bolster resilience and thrive in today's fast-paced world.
About the presenter, Sarah Robb
Sarah is a certified coach, counselor, and Master Practitioner of NLP (neuro-linguistic programming) holding a Bachelor's degree in Psychology.
With a passion for transformation, she guides individuals through retraining their brains and breaking free from limiting beliefs and patterns. Drawing on her extensive lived experience, Sarah has collaborated with over 200 clients and organisations, empowering them to apply practical tools and strategies for significant improvements in their mental health.
Sarah is motivated to continue creating positive change and to educate people about the power of the mind and how to use life's challenges as an opportunity for growth.

events.id: The Grogans 'Stagger' NZ Tour 2025-San Fran, Wellington-Under The Radar
events.name: The Grogans 'Stagger' NZ Tour 2025
events.venue: San Fran, Wellington
events.description:
Ready to take these new tracks on the road, The Grogans new album Stagger is
out, plus the band are excited to announce a headline tour across New Zealand.
Exploring another side of The Grogans' music, Stagger is a patchwork of different
sounds and sonic inspirations that all come together in the one album, it came
from this idea that it was a jagged and stylistically different album track to
track, explain The Grogans.
Kicking off their tour at Loons in Christchurch on Wednesday 3 September, the
band then head to Yonder in Queenstown on Thursday 4 September, San Fran in
Wellington on Friday 5 September before wrapping up at Double Whammy
Auckland on Saturday 6 September. Prior to their Aotearoa dates, the trio will also
be playing a seven date tour throughout Australia along with stops in LA and New
York for North American shows this June.

Capturing the magnetic energy of their live shows, Stagger touches on themes of
mental health, taking care of yourself and your loved ones, the occasional love song,
and more. As the catchy chorus first single and album opener ‘Oh Boy’ leads into
sonic powerhouse of a tune ‘Come Up (Goes Down)’, ‘In My Heart’ slows it down to
a new easy listening direction, followed by ‘Have a Little Dream’ - as dreamy as the
title suggests - and the big open echoed instrumentation of ‘Once In A While’.
Adding new textural effects in ‘Roll Back’ and last single ‘Roundabout’, ‘Happier
Man’ dips into a heavier psych realm with a reminder that striving to be a better
and happier person should be a goal for everyone. ‘Worry About Everything’
is an upbeat tune sure to have you worrying about nothing, and feel good album
closer ‘All My Days’ ends on a more serious note that outlines the beauty and the
beast of live music and the personal struggles that come with the lifestyle and
touring.

Mixing on the road definitely added something different to this album.
Usually, I’m in the same spot whilst mixing and can come and go from each
track mentally, but this time the album was attached to us at the hip. We would
bring a set up through most of America and record/mix in green rooms and on
the bandwagon. It was definitely worth it, as we had to work with what we had
to finish the album. Only being able to reference mixes on headphones and
JBL speakers towards the end of the album process was definitely harder than
in a studio. However, as a band, we have never really been able to sit still, so it
worked nicely. Each mix has its own personality, and I guess that’s what we
wanted for this staggered album. - The Grogan’s Quin Grunden on mixing and
engineering the album on the road across the US & Canada through June-July 2024.

Stream Stagger Album: https://thegrogans.lnk.to/stagger

Included in Rolling Stone’s Future of Music 2025 and described by triple j as 'one
of the most consistently hardworking live acts in the country’, The Grogans
commitment to making incredibly varied, distinct music, sharing good experiences at
their live show and genuine elation on playing together is clear to see and explains
why they are one of Australia’s brightest bands. In recent years, they have delighted
their international fans with a headline 2024 tour across Europe, Ireland, and the UK,
a stop at the Netherlands’ Misty Fields Festival, joining Ocean Alley on their North
American Summer Tour, and more. Never ones for slowing down, 2024 was filled
with local shows, sharing the stage with Teen Jesus and The Jean Teasers for their
‘Fix It With Salt’ tour, and a 5th anniversary tour of their LP ‘Just What You Want.

Tickets for all dates go on sale Wednesday 28 May at midday.

events.id: Financial Planning for Retirement-Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington-Wellington High School
events.name: Financial Planning for Retirement
events.venue: Wellington High School, 249 Taranaki Street, Te Aro, Wellington
events.description:
Financial Planning for Retirement
Massey University's annual Retirement Expenditure Guidelines study (2019) found:
Just 40% of pre-retirees believed they were well-prepared for retirement, and 57% considered retirement to be a concern.  They also confirmed, New Zealand Superannuation is not sufficient to fund the retirement most people want.
Ministry of Social Development (2020):
22% of all people receiving New Zealand Superannuation also receive additional support payments, with over 44,000 superannuants receiving additional accommodation support,
And if you needed to obtain Government assisted accommodation, at the end of March 2020, more than 16,300 households were waiting for state or social housing.
Living in a motel or boarding house with strangers (who may have other vulnerable backgrounds) is not an ideal or safe location to spend your retirement years.   But for many, it is the only option they can afford.
If you have not planned for your retirement, then this course is you! 
This course has been developed for people in their 50’s or 60’s that are looking at retirement and have no idea if they can financially survive it: what to do, what $’s they need, how or where they can generate additional income, or even where to go to get help. 
It is targeted towards those that still have some time (for some - not much) to make adjustments, learn some basic financial skills, make some big decisions, and positively influence the quality of their pending retirement. 
You will be introduced to a simple step by step guide to developing a financial plan for retirement. 
You will work though a case study in class, and can then go away and repeat the process with your own data/details.  You will be provided with comprehensive course notes to enable you to update the case study information with your own information. 
At each step, key considerations and financial concepts will be defined, explained and discussed to help you understand the financial requirements of retirement.  
Are you ready for the retirement lifestyle you hoped or dreamed of?  If not, then this course is for you.
[A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Disclaimer:  The tutors are not financial advisors.  No investments, products nor specific recommendations will be provided.  A step by step planning process will be taught by working through a case study.  Key considerations that should be used by the participants when looking at their own options to bridge the financial gap between what is available through superannuation and what is required to meet lifestyle goals will be provided and discussed.  Product names may be used in examples and explanations to help participants understand the financial concepts and the planning process.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.description:
Jewellery Making Intensive - Beginners' Workshop
Learn the essential skills and techniques needed to make your own creations. The morning will begin with simple design examples and techniques using specialist jewellers’ tools, working with copper or brass. In the afternoon you will form and craft your own ring from sterling silver.
 All materials included in course fee.  Please bring pen and paper and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment.  Limited to nine participants. Please note you cannot be late for this one-day course, you must be there from the start of the course when health and safety matters are covered.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
• Create a silver band 
• Demonstrate techniques for working sterling silver 
• Perform metal forming, piercing and texturing skills 
• Use essential jewellery-making tools accurately

Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

events.venue: Multiple venues across the Cuba Street precinct, Wellington
events.description:
Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St
Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.

events.id: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Hangman's Noose Tour (Sept 2025)-76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: Friends of Karori Cemetery: Hangman's Noose Tour (Sept 2025)
events.venue: 76 Old Karori Road, Karori, Wellington 6012, New Zealand
events.description:
Hangman's Noose Tour
In total, 85 people have been executed for crime in New Zealand with the first in 1842 and the last in 1957. Seventeen of those men were executed in Wellington and 11 are buried in Karori Cemetery.  This walking tour will visit some of their graves to account their crimes, trials and convictions. It will also visit the plots of some of the victims.

The graves are unmarked and placed in remote and disparate locations making this a tour about 2.5 hours long. The route is 2.5km and requires reasonable physical fitness due to the steep terrain and unsealed paths in places.
The tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions and so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

events.id: Aunty Donna — Drem World Tour-The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Aunty Donna — Drem World Tour
events.venue: The Opera House, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
It’s zany, it’s unpredictable, and it’s heading to The Opera House. Australian surrealist comedy group Aunty Donna is back on the road. The Melbourne-based trio have written a new show called ‘Drem World Tour’. Its first stop is The Opera House in Wellington. The group is known for wild, off-the-wall skits and a penchant for silliness. 
Formed in 2011 the group’s creativity has spawned live shows, a YouTube channel, a podcast, a studio album, and a television series. Their 2020 Netflix series ‘Aunty Donna’s Big Ol’ House of Fun’ further grew their fanbase. Members of the group have cited Monty Python, Shaun Micallef, and The Mighty Boosh as inspirations for their comedy. Join Mark Bonanno, Broden Kelly, and Zachary Ruane as they present a wacky night of comedy.

events.name: Leadership And Management Part 1
events.venue: AREA Meetings and Events, 1 O'Reily Ave, Wellington
events.description:
Learn how to make the transition from buddy to the boss and lead a successful team. Managing staff can be a very rewarding, interesting and fun role, it can also be a tough and demanding job. Between managing your own time and projects, helping your team members solve problems and complete tasks, and helping other managers, your day can fill up before you know it.
This workshop aims to maximise your leadership and management potential and help you become a more confident, effective and efficient leader and manager with information on understanding personality types, effective communication, setting expectations and goals, assigning work, effective delegation, motivating staff, leadership styles, giving feedback and having courageous conversations, understanding what is required to be a good leader and manager and encouraging teamwork.
 
The workshop is designed for those who have been promoted recently into a supervisory management role or for those who have been there for some time but need to improve their leadership and management skills. To book: email - info@biztrainers.co.nz or call 04 974 8790

events.id: Paul Kelly-Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand-Wellington NZ
events.name: Paul Kelly
events.venue: Michael Fowler Centre, Wellington, New Zealand
events.description:
Paul Kelly’s albums have ranged from bluegrass and country to funk and soul. The Australian has written and sung a superb catalogue of love songs spanning more than 40 years. He’s heading to Wellington’s Michael Fowler Centre to share his music. The tour will come a few months after the release of his next studio album ‘Fever Longing Still’. Joining Paul on stage is his band, who help bring these new songs to life. The album title comes from a line in ‘Sonnet 147’ by Shakespeare, whose writing has thrilled and inspired Paul ever since his school days. 
Bestowed with the Order of Australia in 2017 and with 17 ARIA awards and five APRA awards, Paul Kelly is a creative powerhouse. Australia is a constant in his song subjects. He regularly references its geographical landscape, its heroes and villains, and hopes and failings. 
For the Michael Fowler concert singer/songwriter Reb Fountain will open proceedings. The American-born Kiwi blends folk, art-pop, and rock into her act.

events.id: WELLINGTON - Governance Conference 2025-3 Pito-One Road, Korokoro, Lower Hutt 5012, New Zealand-Humanitix
events.name: WELLINGTON - Governance Conference 2025
events.venue: 3 Pito-One Road, Korokoro, Lower Hutt 5012, New Zealand
events.description:
Christian Savings is excited to be hosting our annual Governance Conference!
Christchurch on Wed, 27 Aug (location to be announced)
Auckland on Wed, 3 Sept (location to be announced)
Wellington on Wed, 10 Sept (location to be announced)
“If people can't see what God is doing, they stumble all over themselves; But when they attend to what he reveals, they are most blessed.” (Prov. 29:18 MSG)
This year the theme is "A Clear Vision for Confident Governance," reflecting the evolving landscape of the New Zealand Church. Our mission is to equip those serving in governance roles with practical governance skills, Gospel inspiration, and a humble understanding of the challenges that lie ahead.
Join us for a lineup of sessions that will tackle crucial issues facing the New Zealand Church and Charities, from leadership and succession planning to asset management and enhancing governance capabilities. Learn from interviews and interactive sessions led by esteemed keynote speakers and hosts, including Chris Clarke, Richard Black, Strahan Wallis, and Steven Moe.
As well as the opportunity to learn from leaders in this field, you will also be able to meet a diverse range of other people involved in Christian governance.
Ticket Info:
Day Session Only (9am-5pm)
Ticket includes sessions from our speakers, morning tea, lunch, afternoon tea.
Evening Session Only (6pm-9pm)
Ticket includes dinner and an evening Masterclass.
Day & Evening (9am-9pm)
Ticket includes sessions from our speakers, morning tea, lunch, afternoon tea, and tea and coffee, dinner, and evening Masterclass.
Evening Masterclass:
We're thrilled to be hosting an enhanced evening Masterclass, a unique and interactive workshop tailored to give a demonstration of good governance in practice. Building on the success of last year's feedback, this session promises a fun and informative experience, especially for those unable to attend the day session. Immerse yourself in valuable insights in an intimate setting, complete with dinner included in your ticket for added convenience.

We look forward to welcoming leaders, trustees, directors, officers, and elders of churches and Christian charities dedicated to governing with excellence. Stay tuned for more updates as we approach the event date - we can't wait to welcome you!
SOME OF OUR GUEST SPEAKERS

Chris Clarke
Chris Clarke brings over 30 years of leadership experience, including 20 years as a CEO, across public policy, health care, humanitarian development, and philanthropy. Currently, he serves as CEO of the Wilberforce Foundation and chairs two boards: The Emergency Alliance, and Arrow Leadership Global. His past roles include CEO of World Vision New Zealand and Hawke’s Bay District Health Board, with additional experience at the World Health Organisation and NHS. A law and commerce graduate from Canterbury University, Chris has been the Praxis Visiting Scholar at Green Templeton College, Oxford University, since 2009.

Steven Moe

Steven Moe is a partner at Parry Field Lawyers with a focus on governance and legal structures for purpose driven groups including Churches and Charities. He has 24 years of experience as a lawyer and is on several boards including Christian Savings. He is also the Chair of Community Finance, which has raised more than $163 million for social housing. He is a member of the Charities Services sector group, the Edmund Hillary Fellowship, the XRB Advisory Panel and is a facilitator on governance for the Institute of Directors and hosts their podcast ‘Board Matters’ on governance. He also is the host of Seeds - a podcast with 395+ long-form conversations on governance, leadership and entrepreneurship. He is coordinating the Christian Lawyers Conference in September in Auckland for about 150 lawyers.



Richard Black
Richard is the founder and director of Thriving Churches HQ, an organisation empowering churches and church leaders to make a greater Kingdom difference. He has always had a heart for the growth and wellbeing of churches, their leaders, and their people.

An ordained minister, qualified counsellor, and experienced communicator, Richard has been involved in people work for over 25 years. He founded the counselling and wellbeing organisation, Mind Health, and holds a BA, Bachelor of Divinity, Bachelor of Theology (First Class Hons), Masters in Counselling (Distinction) and is a Member of the New Zealand Association of Counsellors. His research has explored key saboteurs undermining church leaders and strategic factors that enhance pastoral effectiveness and wellbeing.

Richard has developed three significant transformation courses for the church and leaders and is a regular voice on Radio Rhema. He is passionate about seeing churches fulfil their purpose in God. Richard is an excellent communicator with the knack of being able to communicate complex issues in a way that is practical and easy to understand.

He is the author of Centred: Knowing who you are in an off-balanced world and a children's book, There’s a Happy Moon in My Side. Richard is married to Jennifer, and they have three adult children.

Strahan Wallis

Strahan is one of New Zealand’s most experienced and recognised Public Relations leaders. With more than 25 years-experience he has led and delivered internationally awarded communications campaigns as well as orchestrating some the highest profile issues and crisis management responses for a range of clients around the world. Strahan was a Board Director and CEO of the Clemenger Group, New Zealand’s largest and most awarded marketing services company, up until March 2024 and is now an independent board director and consultant. He is currently senior counsel at WALLIS&CO and takes on a limited number of clients.

Raised on a farm in Raglan, he lives at Red Beach with his wife Racheal, their three children and Poppy, their wee Maltese-Shitsu.

He is a Fellow (nominated by peers) and an Accredited Member of the Public Relations Institute of New Zealand (PRINZ) and a Certified Member of the Institute of Directors (IOD).
